PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in the Vietnam War from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.

Your humble petitioners pray that the Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH (PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS DETERMINATION REVOCATION AND TRIBUNAL MEMBERSHIP) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the National Health Act 1953 to revoke a determination of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal, provide for qualified membership of the Tribunal, and for related purposes.
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purposes of this Bill are:
to disallow the August 28 determination of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal;

to amend the composition of the membership of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal to provide for two of its members to have qualifications, knowledge and experience relevant to the pharmaceutical profession and industry; and

to provide that in the conduct of its inquiries the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal have regard to the need to ensure that variations in the Commonwealth price of any pharmaceutical benefits have the effect of facilitating the efficient and effective provision of national health services.

Mr President, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme is currently in a state of crisis. It is imperative that in the health care interests of the community urgent action be taken to ensure that the delivery of pharmaceutical services is not placed in jeopardy.
The Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) is an essential part of Australia's health care system. For almost 40 years it has been one of the most stable and enduring parts of that system.

The underlying principles of the PBS, the public subsidisation of the delivery of the most reliable and modern pharmaceuticals at affordable prices, with the maximum assistance going to those in greatest need, are basically as sound today as they were when the scheme was first implemented.
This is not to say that the PBS is without need of improvement.
Changes to the PBS which have been made in recent times, however, with the possible exception of the introduction of the Safety Net, have not served to deliver such improvements.

The Government has committed itself to the aim of ensuring access by the Australian community to necessary cost-effective prescribed medications. What it appears to be overlooking is that it cannot deliver this promise by itself.
The Government needs the assistance of community pharmacists to honour its commitment.

On the 28th August 1989, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal ruled that there be a reduction of $1.05 per prescription in the amount paid to pharmacists and the elimination of any mark-up on the cost of prescription goods.

There is no doubt that the implementation of this decision, based on the findings of a highly questionable data base survey, will result in significant losses in remuneration and have a dramatic and detrimental impact on pharmacists' ability to deliver services to the community.

Without appropriate remuneration pharmacists will inevitably be forced to reduce their staffing levels and stock holdings. As a result patients may face considerable delays in having their prescriptions filled.

Despite the serious reservations expressed about the validity of the data base survey which covered only 0.3% of Australia's 5,600 pharmacies, the Government has supported the PBRT's determination because it will save money.
Government efforts to cutback on the cost of the PBS by reducing the level of its payments to pharmacists are misguided.
Pharmacists cannot in any way be held responsible for the increases in the cost of the PBS which have occurred in recent years. They do not originate prescriptions, they only fill them.
The Liberal and National Parties deplore the way in which the Government has adopted a ``them and us'' attitude towards pharmacists.

The Government is ignoring the fact that the success of the PBS is totally dependent upon the maintenance of a co-operative partnership between government and the pharmacists. It is reliant upon community pharmacies to discharge its obligations under the PBS.
As a consequence of this it is incumbent upon the Government and the Tribunal to provide pharmacists with a fair and reasonable level of remuneration.
Population growth and the rising number of aged people in the community make increased demand for PBS services entirely predictable and inevitable.
Furthermore, the development and utilisation of new, more effective and more expensive therapeutic products will inevitably contribute to cost increases.
In addition, there are two important points which the Government appears to be overlooking.
The first of these is that money spent on pharmaceuticals can yield savings by way of lowering the need for even more expensive forms of treatment and care, such as hospitalisation and surgery.
Secondly, it is the prescribing practices of doctors which influence the demand for goods and services under the PBS.
Given these factors it is outrageous for the Government to act as if it is the pharmacists who are responsible for the rapidly escalating cost of the PBS.

The Government has announced its intention to restructure community pharmacies. It is clear that in doing so it is motivated by a desire to reduce costs and that it expects to achieve this by reducing the number of pharmacies.
This is an absolutely fallacious assumption.
It is not the number of pharmacy outlets which contribute to the cost of the PBS, but the number and type of prescriptions which are written and dispensed.

The implementation of the Government's `restructuring' will see the inevitable closure of up to 1,000 pharmacies. These closures will be totally indiscriminate. They may involve small pharmacies in low socio-economic areas serving a high proportion of pensioners, and other low income earners, i.e. the biggest consumers of PBS services, or they may be large pharmacies operating with high overhead expenses.

Quite clearly, it is imperative that amendments be made to the operations of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal to stop the rot which is undermining the whole fabric of the PBS and jeopardising patient care.

The disallowance of the Tribunal's August 28 determination is essential in order to avoid the wholesale and indiscriminate closure of pharmacies. Unless this determination is overturned it is clear that the aged, who are both the greatest users of the PBS and the least mobile members of our community, will be robbed of much needed access to high quality pharmaceutical services.
The Tribunal has based its determination on a data base survey the validity of which has been widely challenged for a number of reasons.
For instance, the survey's findings were based on an extremely small sample. Questionnaires were sent to a random sample of 150 of Australia's 5,600 pharmacies, of which only 53 responded.

In addition to this insignificant statistical base, pharmacists believe that the methodology of the survey is unreliable and that it is fundamentally flawed because the figures used were out of date and the key costings, such as wages and rent, based on unrealistic figures.

But despite the fact that these reservations have been loudly and clearly expressed both the Tribunal and the Government have been prepared to accept the survey's results as the basis of the Tribunal's August 28 determination.

The Liberal and National Parties believe that such a travesty would not have occurred if members of the Tribunal had qualifications, knowledge and experience relevant to the pharmaceutical profession and industry.

It is for this reason that we propose to alter the composition of the Tribunal so that it may reach its determinations on the basis of a genuine appreciation of the impact of its decisions on pharmacists' ability to deliver a high quality and comprehensive service.

Further improvements to the operation and outcome of the inquiries of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal will also be achieved by the passage of our amendment to require the Tribunal to ensure that its inquiries take account of the need to facilitate the efficient and effective provision of national health care services.

The Government has stated its desire to develop a professional role for pharmacists, over and above the role they already fulfil in the dispensing of drugs, it must realise that the closure of 25 to 30 per cent of Australia's pharmacies will do nothing to assist in this process.

Those community pharmacists who manage to survive in what is now an extremely adverse climate will be reduced to the assembly line dispensing of prescriptions. They will have neither the time, nor the resources, to even maintain their current contribution towards counselling patients and participating in public education programs, let alone take on an expanded role in the delivery of health care.
Clearly the result of the implementation of the Tribunal's August 28 determination will be the decimation of community pharmacy as we now know it.

The loss of pharmacy outlets and the reduction in services from those pharmacies which continue to fight to stay in business will impose considerable burdens on consumers, the majority of whom are elderly. Many people will be forced to travel considerable distances to reach a pharmacist and they will experience increasing delays in obtaining the medication they require.

The Opposition is not preparing to countenance such a situation and therefore urges the Senate to adopt these amendments to the National Health Act so that the Health care interests of the nation can be safeguarded.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to repeal the War Crimes Act 1945.
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

I think it is well known that I opposed the amendment to the War Crimes Act 1945 from the outset. I regarded it as one of the most dangerous and badly drafted bills I had ever seen. Nevertheless, I think it is common ground that it is beyond reasonable doubt a number of atrocious war or genocide criminals of the World War II period are now residing in Australia. How many we do not know, but the really serious offenders would be relatively few. I think it is also common ground that the crimes against humanity committed during the second world war were as bad as any committed in the long history of man's inhumanity to man. But that is not the end of the problem; it is only the beginning.

The War Crimes Act, as amended last December, has a very large number of highly offensive characteristics. First of all it is retrospective, which is abhorrent in the criminal law. It is retrospective because it gave extraterritorial jurisdiction to Australian criminal law, and also introduced new offences unknown to Australian criminal law, and also introduced new offences unknown to Australian criminal law of the relevant period. Worse still, the international law on crimes against humanity that it purported to be enforcing did not exist at the relevant time. It was the position of Australia in 1945, when the Nuremberg Charter was being discussed, that crimes against humanity were not covered by international law, but should be dealt with under the laws of the country in which the offences were committed. Yet nearly all the alleged crimes which have been mentioned are crimes against humanity for which, as I said, there was no international law at the time they were committed, and I believe there is no satisfactory justification for Australia purporting to enforce non-existent international law.

This is not to say that there is not now some international law covering crimes against humanity. In 1949 there was a series of Geneva Conventions covering the wounded and sick in armed forces in the field and at sea, the treatment of prisoners of war, and the protection of civilians. This was brought into Australian law in 1957, but it should be noted that it does not cover such matters as genocide, and it was not retrospective.

Genocide was covered by a separate Convention of 1947, and ratification of this Convention was approved by an act of Parliament, the Genocide Convention Act of 1949. Presumably, it was felt that genocide committed inside Australia could be adequately dealt with by our existing laws, but it is important to note that it did not give any power to Australian courts to deal with genocide committed overseas, whether by Australian residents or by anyone else. These ratifications of conventions of 1947 and 1949 are, of course, post facto as far as the Second World War crimes are concerned. They did not comprise international law of the period the War Crimes Act deals with; for these crimes the accepted statement was the Nuremberg Charter, which did not deal with crimes against humanity except those connected with defined war crimes.

Yet another objection to the War Crimes Act is its limited coverage. It covers only war crimes committed in Europe during the Second World War-a small part of one war which ended nearly half a century ago. What has happened to all the other wars? Since the Second World War there have been at least 70 wars, and 10 of them are still going on. In the last 60 years there must have been 100 million people killed in horrible crimes against humanity, yet nearly all of these are excluded from the War Crimes Act. What went on in Pol Pot's Cambodia, for instance, is as bad as anything that went on in Hitler's Germany, yet the Act does not cover these. If someone committed a war crime today in, say, Cambodia or Lebanon, and subsequently migrated to Australia, he could not be tried for those war crimes here. The Act does not cover them.

Since the Second World War we have taken in migrants from all over the world, and the last thing we want is to have the battles of their homelands, whether it be the religious troubles in Northern Ireland, the disintegration of Lebanon, strife in occupied Palestinian territories, the tribal fighting in Africa, or any other of the world conflicts, brought here. The last thing we want is to have conflicts of their native lands-the bitterness, the atrocities, the charges and countercharges-refought in Australian courts. When people come to Australia we hope they leave the troubles of their homelands behind. That was what was behind the statement made by this Parliament, with only one dissenter, to the migrant community, that those migrants who have been allowed to make their homes and lives here must be allowed to live in security with new lives under the rule of law, and the time had come to close the chapter on the crimes of World War II. This pledge was given in 1961, 28 years ago. There was no suggestion that any alleged war criminals should be put on trial in Australia. The 1988 amendment to the War Crimes Act was a clear breaking of this pledge.

Then there is the possibility of World War II Australian airmen being liable for prosecution as war criminals on the grounds that some of their bombing attacks in Europe-Dresden in February 1945 for example-might have been held to include wanton destruction of cities, towns or villages, or devastation not justified by military necessity, to use the words of the Nuremberg Charter. The amendment that the Senate incorporated-to say it is not an offence if the act was reasonably justified by the exigencies and necessities of the conduct of war-adds nothing. This is already covered under the Nuremberg Charter law of military necessity. I am not for a moment suggesting that our World War II bomber veterans should be charged. Of course they will not be charged. But what we are saying to them is, `The Australian Parliament regards what you did in the Second World War, under orders and under conditions of enormous danger and very heavy casualties, as a war crime; but don't worry, we won't prosecute you'. What sort of a country do we think we are?

How then did such an objectionable Bill ever pass our Parliament? The only serious argument advanced for it was that, whatever its legal weaknesses, it was necessary in order to allow justice to be meted out to a small number of horrible criminals who had migrated here in the confusion after the Second World War. There is no doubt, in my mind, that if there had been a free vote in the Senate, after the Senate had considered the Bill, its defects and its likely effect on our migrant community, the Bill would then have been overwhelmingly rejected. Nevertheless it was passed on party lines.

Objectionable though I thought the Act was, what has happened since it was passed has disturbed me even more. Recently the Attorney-General, Mr Bowen, said it was quite likely that no one would be prosecuted under the War Crimes Act, which, if true, destroys the only serious argument advanced for passing it. Worse still, the Head of the Special Investigations Unit, Mr Greenwood, QC, has been reported as being very pleased with the co-operation he has been receiving from the Communist Bloc countries of Eastern Europe in supplying evidence against Australian residents who fled or migrated to Australia from those countries. Mr Greenwood has also reached agreements with a number of these countries. The trouble is that these agreements deal exclusively with the problems of the prosecution. They make no arrangements for providing an effective defence. But surely if someone approaching 80 is to be charged with crimes committed, say in Ukraine in 1943, if he is to mount an effective defence he will need to be able to go to Ukraine and contact potential witnesses, who will need to have exit visas and a credible assurance that they will not be punished for giving defence evidence. The defendant, who under our law will be presumed to be innocent-even the War Crimes Act does not change the presumption of innocence-would need to be able to examine records and possibly the site of the alleged crime. Frankly, I do not see how any of this is likely to be possible, but if it is not done fair trials will be impossible, which is one of the arguments I used against the Bill when it was in the Senate. I think the whole business has become a sorry farce.

Fortunately, the decision of whether or not to prosecute does not rest with Mr Greenwood; instead, responsibility is with the Director of Public Prosecutions, and I have no doubts as to the integrity of that office. I am sure he would not allow prosecutions to be launched unless there was a reasonable chance both of a conviction and of a fair trial, and for that reason I cannot believe any prosecutions will be launched. Some people have been talking about the desirability of having show trials to bring home to the Australian people the depths of man's inhumanity to man, even though there was no likelihood of the accused actually being convicted. If that were a desirable objective, one would have to ask why these show trials should be limited to one particular area of one particular war which ended nearly 50 years ago. But in any case show trials are abhorrent to our legal system, and I am quite sure that the Director of Public Prosecutions would never contemplate cooperating in one.

For all these reasons I think that the Government should immediately close down the Special Investigations Unit, and stop wasting the millions of dollars that have been spent on this exercise. It would also stop the tensions that are being caused in our migrant community. We must remember that since the Second World War we have taken in 150,000 migrants from Germany and 400,000 from Eastern Europe and the investigations of the Special Investigations Unit have already been extremely disruptive in these communities, many of which are fierce opponents of communism, having experienced it first hand.

One might ask why I am bringing forward this Bill, because quite clearly it will not be passed unless the Government has a change of heart, either by permitting a free vote in this Parliament on this complex legal, moral and social issue, or by accepting its having made a mistake.

The purpose of my Bill is to focus attention on what is going on in this war crimes area, on what is going wrong in this area, and in the hope that by focusing community attention on this deplorable business, to put pressure on the Government to act in the way that its-or at any rate an overwhelming proportion of its members-know to be right, and repeal the deplorable War Crimes Act.
