PROCTEXT.PARA: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1989

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we interrupted Senator Boswell last night, so I will yield and let him finish his speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night we were considering Opposition amendments Nos 34, 35, 36 and 37. I was supporting my colleague Senator Peter Baume and pointing out certain matters to Senator Coulter, who had some objections to the Opposition's amendments. Senator Coulter pointed out a contrary point of view to the Democrat position that Aboriginal people had placed a different significance on the ownership of land. I pointed out then that I believed that Senator Coulter and Senator Tate had missed the point of the Opposition's amendment. What the Opposition is saying is that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission will have a budget of around $800m to administer all needs and to fund all Aboriginal projects and that under the legislation at the moment a very significant proportion of that $800m could be used to acquire land. In fact, most of that money could be used to purchase land if the commissioners of ATSIC wanted to.

SPEECH.PARA: We are saying that many other needs have to be administered by ATSIC, for example, roads, health services and legal services. The legislation, without amendment, would give the Commission almost an unlimited right to spend that $800m in acquiring land. The Opposition is saying that there has to be some other direction that this money can be used to fund other Aboriginal projects.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Boswell for being so explicit about his concerns. If it were the case that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission spent the whole of its funds-which he modified late last night to say `a substantial proportion' of its funds-in the acquisition of land, then there could be some diminution in the services that would otherwise be provided in relation to the provision of fresh water, health services and all those other requirements of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people that ought properly to be met out of the moneys appropriated by this Parliament for ATSIC. I think that is the key term-`appropriated by this Parliament for ATSIC'.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Boswell does not give sufficient weight to the fact that the appropriation made by this Parliament requires an estimates procedure. It requires the estimates to be provided in such detail as the Minister requires to be put to him for his consideration and, of course, they would be open to scrutiny by the Estimates committee of this chamber. In that way the sort of total disproportionate funding of that element of their function which allows for the acquisition of land to the detriment of other Aboriginal programs, I believe, would not survive the test-the scrutiny by the Minister of the estimates. Certainly it would be open to much criticism in the Estimates committees of the Senate chamber itself.

More fundamentally, Senator Boswell seems to be going against the tenor of his contribution to this important debate so far, because he does not seem to be putting enough confidence in the ability of the commissioners of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission to get the balance right. He has said time and time again that occasionally they will make wrong decisions. Perhaps they might spend a fraction more than Senator Boswell would if he were a commissioner in relation to the provision of sewerage services, the provision of some sort of health scheme, or the acquisition of land. By the way, that is at market prices, out on the open market. We are not talking about the compulsory acquisition of land.

In relation to those matters, we expect the Commission, fundamentally, given the tasks that it has to perform and the various matters which it might undertake on behalf of its Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island communities, to do its best to devote its funds in a way which, not necessarily in any one year, but over a period of time, gets the balance right. It would be very wrong to try to circumscribe in advance the sort of devotion of funds that it would wish to make to these programs. That scrutiny of its allocation of funds will come through the proper Estimates procedures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister really has opened up an argument now because he says we must have confidence in the commissioners. But last night the Minister would not accept that argument from us when we said that one way to express that confidence in commissioners was to give them the right to appoint their own chief executive officer. We have gone around and around this. I remind the Committee that this is the same Committee that last week gave to the Aboriginal Development Commission the right to appoint its own chief executive. We agree with the Minister that we have to have confidence in the commissioners. That is not at question.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are saying to the Minister is that the amendments we have proposed, we believe, will enable the achievement of the very outcome which the Minister identified in his last few remarks. The words we have added do not in any way seek to prevent the acquisition of land or the making of grants for the purchase of interest in land. They simply say that it should be done for certain purposes. Let me go back over what the Minister said. Certain amounts of the ATSIC budget will be designated for land acquisition or for loans or grants functions. When we get the estimates in the Parliament they will be identified. What Senator Boswell is saying is that we want to be sure that a commissioner does not use those moneys for what is essentially a political purpose.

We have moved four amendments together for several purposes. Firstly, we want to try to be economical with time if we can, and this is one way to go about it. Secondly, as Senator Coulter pointed out last night-I think the Minister also pointed it out-the last two of those four amendments are the substantial ones and those which contain the argument. The first two amendments are, as it were consequential or associated amendments.

Senator Coulter raised last night a quite important point that requires an answer. He wanted to know when we said `occupy land' whether we were being in a philosophical sense exploitative, whether we were looking at land as something that must be used economically. I take his point, but we were not doing that. In our minds we have a fairly broad and generous interpretation of the words `occupy land'. After all, I have administered the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act in my time and I am well aware of the breadth of interpretation that may have to apply to the term `occupy land'. We made a grant of the Tanami Desert. I am not suggesting that there have to be houses there and people living there all the time. If Senator Coulter is unhappy with the word `occupy', I just say to him that we are not trying to use it in an exploitative sense; we are not suggesting that it implies or requires the economic use of the land. We are not suggesting that it has to be turned into citrus orchards, that it has to be used for grazing cattle, or whatever. If that is what comes across it is unfortunate. Perhaps the honourable senator could help us with a word that better describes what is in our minds. The amendments make it quite clear that we are not opposing the function but we are concerned about what wilful or foolish commissioners might do. After all, we have a responsibility in the Parliament to put into the statute what we want people to read and follow later on.

There is one other matter. People ask why we would wish to tie the hands of the commissioners if they chose to devote a large amount of their resource to land acquisition as we have suggested they might do. I digress to say that, as clause 15 is written, it will be quite competent for the commissioners, using the phrase `on such terms and conditions as the Commission determines' to say to an Aboriginal corporation, `We will make a grant to such and such an Aboriginal corporation to acquire interests in some land which will then be registered in the name of', and the Commission can then name anyone it wishes. It could be a land council; it may not be the organisation itself. As we read the clause, there will be a capacity for the Commission, on such terms and conditions as it determines, to go about this exercise.

I get back to the point I wanted to make. Many honourable senators have drawn attention in the second reading debate to the extreme degree of need and deprivation that characterises Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and their communities. I drew attention in the second reading debate on the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill, and my colleague Senator Boswell has a particular interest in the Torres Strait, to the recent press report which featured the chief medical officer on Thursday Island. He is appalled at the health status of the people in Port Kennedy. Given the degree of deprivation and need, I would like to see the commissioners at least giving a priority to overcoming that deprivation and need. All we are saying is that if they wish to put money in quite substantial amounts into the acquisition of property, it should be in some way for the benefit of Aboriginal people.

The theory of opportunity cost is known to all honourable senators. Not every dollar that goes into property can go into providing Senator Coulter's sewerage line in Western Australia-or whatever the example was that we have been using throughout this committee stage debate. After all, our amendments propose that the Commission should be able to make grants for the acquisition of interests in land and personal property as the Commission considers appropriate for the purpose of enabling Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders who are members of those corporations to occupy that land. We added the words `who are members of those corporations' because if a grant is made to corporation X we want it at least to be understood it is for the benefit of the members of corporation X. We cannot see why that amendment will not improve the legislation. It will not prevent the activity being undertaken by the Commission. It merely says that if the Commission does that it must be for the benefit of the Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander people who are members of that corporation.

In the same way, amendment No. 36, the preceding one, the other substantial amendment, merely seeks to add the words `for the purpose of enabling Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders who are members of those corporations to occupy that land'. Again I say to Senator Coulter-and I am interested in what he will say-that if his interpretation of the word `occupy' is that it is exploitative, I seek his assistance in finding a better word. Without those words there is no limit on the ways in which commissioners might utilise that part of the ATSIC budget which comes within this functional area to acquire land and property at large and, in so doing, because of the opportunity costs involved, ignoring the needs and interests of other Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people.

I will not argue for the other two amendments because I think we have all agreed that these are the two more substantial ones, but I urge the committee to give sympathetic and considerate attention to what we have argued and to the Opposition amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid I must say to Senator Peter Baume that, while I found some of his earlier arguments really quite persuasive in dealing with other clauses, in relation to amendments Nos. 36 and 37 I do not find any persuasion at all in what he said. I really do find these amendments quite objectionable, and the inclusion of the word `occupy', despite what Senator Baume says, does connote physical occupation and/or exploitation of the land. I do not really think one can get around that implication if this were ever to be tested in a court of law further down the track. If one were to leave out not only the word but the sorts of connotations which I think Senator Peter Baume agrees should not be in there, then there ceases to be a great deal of point in the amendment that he is seeking to put in because the sense of it would mean that the Commission may, on such terms and conditions as it determines, make grants of money to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations for the acquisition of interests in land in the interests of the Aboriginal people or Islanders within those corporations.

SPEECH.PARA: Surely that is implicit in the whole idea that the Commission can buy the land. It would buy the land in the interests of those people. So it seems to me that if one takes out the concept of occupy or the concepts to which Senator Baume agrees, we might find some objection. If that is taken out, then there seems very little point because all one is doing is putting in a tautology. But beyond that I come back to the point that I made last night, and that is, let us recognise that as a society we have created a situation in which many wealthy people in this country can buy and sell and speculate in land and there is absolutely massive misallocation of resources in terms of what really needs to be done in our society.

The history of government in this country has largely been the protection of a system in which certain classes of people have been able to buy and sell land and speculate and do all sorts of things so that as a society the effect has been that there has been massive misallocation of resources away from areas of needs. It does not necessarily follow that if we were genuinely concerned that Aboriginal people under ATSIC may also misallocate resources, therefore we should countenance it just because this misallocation has been countenanced in other parts of society. That does not follow. However, it does follow that we should be very careful about pointing the finger at the Aboriginal people who might finish up on ATSIC and say, `Look, you might be naughty; you might buy land when in fact you should be building these sewerage lines in Western Australia'. Let us recognise that as a society we have not done very well in the way we have allocated the resources that are available.

The third point I would make is that ATSIC of course will be under scrutiny and should it go excessively in the direction of buying land for speculative purposes or purposes other than the welfare of Aboriginal people, clearly that is something that can be picked up. Frankly, I think the Opposition is drawing a very long bow here when it talks about the possibility of ATSIC spending virtually all its money on land acquisition and totally ignoring the plight of its own people. This will be a representative body drawn from Aboriginal people all over Australia. Surely the whole point about this is that these Aboriginal people know the needs of the local communities; they will, in formulating the ATSIC draft budget, have before them the draft budgets of the regional councils; there will be the bids in there from the regional councils in relation to their needs. I think it is extremely unlikely that the sorts of bizarre and excessive examples to which Senator Baume is pointing us would in fact happen. I think it is very unlikely. For all those reasons I find amendments Nos (36) and (37) really quite objectionable. As we all have agreed, if they go then the first amendment in this series, No. (34), probably becomes irrelevant anyway and it may well be that No. (35) is one which could go in; but perhaps, as I indicated last night, Senator Baume would not want to proceed with it if Nos (36) and (37) were not accepted. I certainly do not find them acceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Coulter. I understand what he said. I do not want to prolong the debate unduly in the light of what he said, but there are several points I will make in response. First, scrutiny is one thing, but it is fairly meaningless if the statute is not drawn optimally. We had a rather distressing time in 1988 watching and scrutinising certain actions by some ADC commissioners who were able to ignore everyone because the statute did not require them to respond. I could take the Senate through all the disasters of last year-the Woden Town Club, the Oasis Hotel and a few other things-but I will not do that. I imagine that members of the Committee can remember, as I can, some of those events. Our job, if we are to do it properly, is to try to get the statute right.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that Senator Coulter takes a different view; I am not going to go over and over the same points. I will just say that, without the amendment the Opposition has proposed, the Bill could authorise ATSIC, if it was so minded, to become itself or to finance selected Aboriginal corporations actually to become traders in and holders of land. If Senator Coulter is concerned about the speculative activity that has gone on, I point out to him that, if we agree to this clause as written, there could be Aboriginal corporations themselves trading in land and themselves being part of that speculation. I can, of course, draw upon the Aboriginal Development Commission Act as the model from which we work. The purpose of acquiring land, we believe, ought to be expressly stated, as it is in section 23 of the ADC Act. The Opposition is not suggesting something that is unique or new; we are suggesting something that should be carried over from the existing ADC legislation.

Very briefly, we believe that amendment 35 actually has some merit on its own. Senator Coulter's last comment was that he did not know whether we would wish to proceed with that amendment on its own. We think it has some merit on its own. The Government gave us some cautious support for that amendment. Depending on how things run, we will ask that that amendment be agreed to.

I would like to suggest, Mr Temporary Chairman, that we proceed as follows. Amendments 36 and 37 actually have two legs to them. The first leg is that the grants should be for the benefit of members of the corporations, and the second leg of the amendments is that they should then occupy the land. The Clerk looks puzzled, but I will read it:
for the purpose of enabling Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are members of the corporations to occupy the land.

They are, in fact, two elements in the amendments. Senator Coulter has said to us that he finds offensive particularly the provision in the words `occupy the land'. The Opposition, for reasons which I have set out and will not repeat, wishes to press those amendments. Should we be unsuccessful, I will then invite the Committee to look at a more limited form of words, picking up only some words such as those used by Senator Coulter a moment ago, words which might mean that the acquisition must be made in the interests of those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who are members of the corporations, because we believe that is part of what the amendments are trying to achieve and at least we would try to get that.

Lastly, I would repeat that we would like to get amendment No. 35 agreed to. I therefore suggest, Mr Temporary Chairman, in the light of the debate, that you divide the question, to put amendments Nos. 34, 36 and 37 together, to put No. 35 separately, and, depending upon the outcome of the vote that may ensue, I may come back with another suggestion. Perhaps I might ask, through the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), whether, as the Second Parliamentary Counsel is sitting there, having heard what I intend, he might try to help me get it in some appropriate form.
Question put:
That amendments Nos (34), (36) and (37) (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 35 agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I understand that some words have been drafted-they are just being handed to the Minister for Justice now-which would pick up my foreshadowed intention should the division result as it did. Could the Minister read out what has been prepared and we might get it circulated, and then I might move those amendments. Amendment Nos (36) and (37) have been unsuccessful, but since they each had two elements we are now seeking to pick up one of those elements only. We have had some assistance with getting some words drawn; I just need to get them around the chamber so I can move and argue them.
—Perhaps the Minister could move them himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to move them, Mr Chairman, but I will certainly read them. The first reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 10, clause 14, line 24, insert ``for the purpose of furthering the economic, social or cultural development of Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are members of those corporations'' after ``corporations''.
I will ask the attendant to provide some copies.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the other one?
—The other one was in relation to clause 15. We will just adopt the same language, I take it.

—Mr Chairman, I foreshadow those two amendments. In terms of what Senator Coulter read out, I indicated words like `in the interests of those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people'. The Parliamentary Counsel tells us that the words that have been selected are words that appear fairly frequently-they are standard words that appear in clauses of statutes. Senator Coulter has said to me that they may be, as it were, almost unnecessary, but the concerns of the Opposition were twofold. Those words would in fact meet one of our concerns. The Committee has decided not to meet the other. We accept that, and will not go back over it. But the words that I have proposed and which have been prepared by the Parliamentary Counsel-for which I thank her-would in fact meet part of the concern of the Opposition. It would mean that any land or interest in property that was acquired would be in the interests of and for the purpose of advancing-using the words that were used there; it is fairly widely drawn-the interests of people who are members of those corporations. That at least would give to us some comfort and we believe in the long run might lead to better outcomes for Aboriginal people in terms of the great unmet need to which we have all referred during this debate.

—Very briefly, I cannot see that those words add anything to the meaning of the words that we have in front of us in the Bill. Nor do they constrain the Commission in the way in which I think Senator Baume is intending they should constrain the Commission. If, for instance, he is concerned about speculative activity, it seems to me it could certainly be argued that within those words a corporation could still buy, sell and speculate in land. It could certainly be argued at times when land prices are rising rapidly that speculation in land is in the interests of the Aboriginal people in that community. I do not feel that the words add anything, nor do they actually curtail the activity of the Commission in the way in which I think Senator Baume is seeking to curtail the powers of the Commission with respect to the acquisition of property. They just seem to be unnecessary, tautological and ineffectual.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter has said that this will not prevent speculative activity. I say to Senator Coulter that it was he who raised the problem of speculative activity. That was not part of our argument in chief. He says that this will not stop it; that may be so. But that has not been our main concern. Our main concern has been to look at the differences between the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation in this matter and the Aboriginal Development Commission Act, and to say, `Why has this happened?'. As I pointed out last night, in clause 88 of the ATSIC Bill we find what an Aboriginal corporation is. It is any body corporate owned or controlled by Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: We come back to clauses 14 and 15, which provide that ATSIC could make grants of interest in property to any Aboriginal corporation for any purpose-that is, other than a business purpose, which is dealt with elsewhere in clause 14 (4). That is what is stated. I reminded the Committee last night that corporations could include each of the regional councils themselves; they could become landholders. It could include the Northern Territory land trusts or land councils. It could include the New South Wales land councils. It could include bodies such as the Aboriginal Coalition, which is a land rights body. It could include the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation. It could include Aboriginal legal, medical and other services. It could include an Aboriginal shelf company.

Because of that very wide group of bodies which would be permitted, if one considers clause 88 together with clauses 14 and 15, to acquire interests in land, these words in fact do assist. The words proposed to be added as an amendment to both clause 14 and clause 15 are `for the purpose of furthering the economic, social and cultural development of Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are members of those corporations'. The words can do no harm at all. The Opposition believes they can do some good. We believe that they will assist in reassuring a number of people who are concerned about some of the intentions of land councils.

A former Premier of a State north of here with whom I had to negotiate extensively some years ago was concerned at every meeting that there may be a de facto land rights program being developed under his nose. We were able to reassure him because we were working at that stage under the Aboriginal Development Commission Act. We were able to point to sections of the Act and he agreed that they did give him reassurance. As a result, as Senator Jones would recall, there was a fair amount of land acquisition possible in that State. The States are sovereign in matters of land acquisition. A State tomorrow, if it were worried, could determine that no-one with red hair could own or purchase property in certain areas. The States are quite sovereign in the area of land acquisition. We believe that these words would help to assist former Premiers, such as the one with whom I dealt, and would help to reassure a number of people who are concerned that there is some hidden purpose in the provision written as it is and in the fact that it has been varied from the provision in the ADC Act. It can do no harm. The Opposition believes it could help.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment has now been circulated. Senator Baume, I believe you want to move the same amendment to clause 15 as has been circulated for clause 14. For the purpose of identification, I will number those two amendments (37a) and (37b).
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (37a) Page 10, subclause 14 (1), line 24, ``after `corporations' '' insert `` `for the purpose of furthering the economic, social or cultural development of Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are members of those corporations' ''.
(37b) Page 11, paragraph 15 (b), lines 17 and 18, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph and words:

(b) land and such personal property as the Commission considers appropriate; for the purpose of furthering the economic, social or cultural development of Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are members of those corporations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, the Opposition is now moving what we should term a fallback position by inserting after the word `Corporation' the words `for the purpose of furthering the economic, social and cultural development of the Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are members of those Corporations'. What Senator Baume is saying is that under the legislation as it now stands any organisation or corporation, no matter for what reason it is set up-health or legal or any other Aboriginal instrumentality-can become an investor in land and can acquire land. That is not the purpose of these Aboriginal instrumentalities. They are there to fulfil a need in the Aboriginal community. They are there to provide health services and legal aid-some sort of service to the Aboriginal community.
—And in doing that they may need to buy land.

—Senator Coulter rightly raises the point that to provide those services they may need to acquire land. We do not object to that. Our amendment says that if it is in the best interests of those organisations, if it is for the purpose of furthering the economic, social or cultural development of Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are members of those corporations, then we agree. If that is required to further the interests of that particular organisation, then they should buy the land, but they should not buy the land just to have a great swag of land out there because they particularly like to have land. That is not going to further the interests of Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coulter seems to be arguing against himself now. He was the one who made the statement that many people exploit land for various reasons, and I think he mentioned that the wealthy people in Australia have the right to buy, hold or do whatever they like with land. We are saying quite categorically that if it is in the interest of Aboriginal communities to own land, or if it is going to further their economic development, they should buy it. But they should not spend a huge part of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) budget on acquiring land and not developing the services that are required to be given to the Aboriginal communities. I do not see how Senator Coulter can mount a genuine argument against the amendment that Senator Peter Baume has just presented to the Committee. If he does mount such an argument, he is really arguing against his last statement to the Committee about five or six minutes ago. I hope Senator Coulter can support the Opposition amendment. It certainly cannot do any harm. It does put down guidelines; they are not as strong as the Opposition would like, but they are certainly better than no guidelines at all.

I think Senator Coulter knows the direction in which the Opposition is heading. We want that part of the budget that is allocated by taxpayers of Australia to be spent serving the needs of Aboriginal communities, whether it is spent on a hypothetical sewerage project in Western Australia or in various areas of roads, health, or legal aid. But the legislation should not state that any part of the budget can be spent on land because that is not the purpose of ATSIC. The purpose of ATSIC is self-determination, self-management and the allocation of the money for the needs of Aboriginal people. Those needs include not only a requirement for land, but also a delivery of services in various areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with great interest to the argument developed by Senators Peter Baume and Boswell on the one hand and Senator Coulter on the other in relation to this matter because it is put forward as a bid to get Senator Coulter's support. I have found Senator Coulter's argument more persuasive and I do not think I need to add anything to the way in which he has developed his rebuttal of the proposal.

—I take one minute to say that the Opposition will divide on the amendments. We understand that each division takes five minutes or so, so I will not speak for very long. We believe very firmly in what we have proposed. I have been in this place long enough to know that people will throw back at you some times, `But you didn't even divide on this matter'. We do believe in it; I indicate we will press it, that we will divide on it, and then we are prepared to go on to group 6 amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell has suggested that I am not debating this point logically. The logic of it is this: in his remarks a few moments ago Senator Baume indicated that he was concerned that he could not give an assurance to, I take it, the former Premier of Queensland, in relation to land grabs by Aboriginal people.
—People like him.

—People like him. If that is the purpose of putting in these words, even though I disagree that that construction can be put on them, as I have said earlier, if Senator Baume really believes that that construction can be put on them, I am sufficiently concerned about those words that I cannot support them.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (38) Page 77, clause 199, lines 14 to 25, leave out the clause.

Mr Chairman, amendment No. 38 refers to clause 199, which is to be found at page 77 of the Bill. Honourable senators would be aware that this was clause 198 in the former print of the Bill. This clause concerns the staff of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd and states that they are to be public servants. We have included this amendment as a grouping on its own; it is the only reference we make to Aboriginal Hostels in the amendments and it is necessary to refer to them only once.
The clause has three subclauses. Subclause (1) says:
The staff required to assist Aboriginal Hostels Limited . . . shall . . . be persons appointed or employed under the Public Service Act 1922.
Subclause (2) says:

The General Manager of Aboriginal Hostels Limited has all the powers of, or exercisable by, a Secretary under the Public Service Act 1922, so far as those powers relate to the branch of the Australian Public Service comprising the staff referred to in subsection (1) . . .
In other words, giving the General Manager of Aboriginal Hostels the capacity to act as if he were a Public Service employer. Subclause (3) says:
In spite of subsection (2), Aboriginal Hostels Limited shall be taken not to be a Department for the purposes of Part VII of the Audit Act 1901.

So the effect of this, apparently, is that the staff of Aboriginal Hostels are to be made public servants, but Aboriginal Hostels is not to be a department of the Public Service-quite specifically provided for by subsection (3).

In order to try to understand what the Government was doing and why it was doing it, I turned to the explanatory memorandum. And remarkably unhelpful it was. It merely restates, in simple language, the three things I have told the Committee. It merely says that the staff would be appointed or employed under the Public Service Act; it merely says that the General Manager would have all the powers exercisable by a secretary under the Public Service Act in relation to such staff; and it says that subclause (3) would ensure that Aboriginal Hostels Ltd would not be required to comply with the requirements of Part VII of the Audit Act that apply to the Department.

That is really very unhelpful, because the issue the Opposition wishes to raise is this: Aboriginal Hostels Ltd is another one of these long-standing portfolio agencies with a very long, proud and successful history. Aboriginal Hostels Ltd has operated successfully under its charter now for more than 15 years. I recall it has had some very distinguished directors. I believe Miss Lois O'Donohue has been the Chair of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd in recent times, and there is no Australian more distinguished than she. She was Australian of the Year a few years ago. In all that time one of the things that have characterised Aboriginal Hostels Ltd is that it has enjoyed the flexibility of employing people, particularly Aboriginal people-and the word `flexibility' is important here-under private sector conditions. It has been possible for them to create employment packages which have been necessary for certain of the people they have employed who in fact may not have been comfortable or happy being employed only under the Public Service Act. The Public Service Act, while it confers benefits, also has some disadvantages to it.

The question I put to the Committee is: Why is this change being made? Aboriginal Hostels, as I say, has been successful. It has operated within its budget, and its measure of success has been in outcomes so that every night of the year there are thousands of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people actually in the hostels, being housed. So it is successful in the sense of achieving outcomes, and after this time the Government has decided these people should become public servants. The question we are entitled to ask is why. Why is this necessary? There is no evidence available to the Opposition that the Aboriginal Hostels Ltd board has been consulted on the proposed change in the status of its employees; certainly there is no evidence that it was consulted in advance, unless it happened in some of those portfolio meetings.

Senator Coulter will remember, and Senator Boswell will recall, that when we were conducting the inquiries for the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs we did spend some time considering the position of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd. We were unable then to get any expression of view from Aboriginal Hostels Ltd. That was fine and that was its right, but I refer my colleagues to paragraphs 3.48 and 3.49 of our unanimous report where we drew attention to these matters. There is no evidence that the employees have been consulted; there is no evidence that the Public Service trade unions have been consulted. Indeed, if they have been consulted we do not know what the view of the trade union movement is on this matter. I come back to the Minister and say to him again: there is a long history of successful operation by Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, during a period when it enjoyed the flexibility of producing employment conditions for its Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander employees-and it is an almost completely Aboriginalised agency.

So, given that record and given that Aboriginal Hostels Ltd has been able to operate within its budget, has been able to achieve the outcomes which to me are so important, and given that it has actually fulfilled its charter, the question is: why is it necessary now to make this change and to bring these employees under a different system of employment merely because ATSIC has been created? The Government has put this clause in because it feels it is necessary for that end to be achieved, but without this clause it would be possible for what was a successful and satisfactory arrangement to continue. It is for that reason that the Opposition proposes that the clause should be omitted. We are not in any way trying to make life more difficult for Aboriginal Hostels Ltd; on the contrary, we are trying to make life easier, trying to leave with Aboriginal Hostels Ltd the flexibility which it has enjoyed and used for 15 years. We believe the amendment, unless it is justified-and it has not been justified publicly up to now-simply is not worth keeping in the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will recall that in the last 12 months there has been very extensive scrutiny of the whole Aboriginal affairs portfolio. A number of very important inquiries have been conducted principally arising from evidence to the Senate Estimates Committee of either maladministration of major financial areas that needed to be addressed. I remind the Senate that Aboriginal Hostels Ltd has never come in for criticism in any of the extensive scrutiny of the Aboriginal affairs portfolio. In fact, on the contrary, the evidence given by Aboriginal Hostels to the Senate Estimates Committees has been complimented by senators on the Estimates committees.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the amendment moved by Senator Peter Baume. Aboriginal Hostels has been, along with the Institute, probably one of the most successful agencies in the whole area of the Aboriginal affairs portfolio. As Senator Peter Baume has so rightly pointed out, it has a unique social function. It has operated administratively most efficiently and effectively. Financially it has operated with full accountability and has not ever been called into question. The presentations it has made to the Senate Estimates Committees, with the explanatory memoranda, on the activities it conducts for the thousands of Aboriginal people who need to utilise the services of Aboriginal Hostels have been praised and complimented by the Senate and, therefore, by the Parliament.

I find it very strange that the Government is pursuing this approach of putting all the employees of Aboriginal Hostels under the umbrella of the Public Service Act. I think we need to look very carefully at the functions of Aboriginal Hostels and the nature of many of its employees. It is providing basically a hotel-motel-hostel and counselling type service to many people that require special accommodation.

TALK.START.PARA: —And in locations that would not otherwise be covered.

—That is very true. I am certainly familiar with that in the Northern Territory and with the very good role that it plays in that regard. The employees that work for Aboriginal Hostels on many occasions will be casual employees. Whether they are in management positions or whether they are employed in domestic and other functions, they will by nature be part time in many instances. They will often have to have special contracts. They sometimes will be people that are related to the management or closely related to the communities in which they serve. If we impose on Aboriginal Hostels all of the constraints and requirements of the Public Service Act, I believe we would be removing from Aboriginal Hostels the very flexibility of operation that has guaranteed its success. I therefore fully support the amendments proposed by Senator Peter Baume.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too support this amendment that staff of Aboriginal Hostels should not have to be public servants to obtain a position in the hostels. I cannot understand this legislation seeking to change an Aboriginal instrumentality that has worked so successfully for 15 years. It seems that we are asking for change for change's sake. Hostels have worked well. They provide a very efficient and very good service. I have never stayed at one of the hostels but I have certainly been to them on many occasions. One that comes to mind is the Abigail Ban Hostel at Port Kennedy on Thursday Island that services the Islander people as they come in from the outer islands. I think that is where the Senate Committee had its meeting. I have been there for functions and for meals on numerous occasions and it is really well run. I know that employees of the Abigail Ban hostels and other Aboriginal hostels do, on occasions, work on broken hours, broken shifts. There is part time employment being offered. This will all be put at risk if we do not give the hostels the mobility to run their own organisations. For instance, they may have a particular function for a visiting dignitary. The community may wish to put on a function that will require the hostels to employ three or four extra people to provide the catering and cleaning facilities. All that will be put at risk if this Parliament insists that the hostels must employ people under the Public Service Act. It is taking away the flexibility that has made hostels so successful over the last 15 years.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot understand why, if things run successfully, this Government seems to say on a number of issues, `Things are running well. Let's see what we can do to stop it running well. Let's see whether we can provide some barrier, so that we can make sure that if something has worked for 15 years we can do something to stop it working successfully'. The Minister must give us a decent explanation and not just some Labor Party philosophy on why we have to change something that has been so successful for a number of years and change it to take away that flexibility of hostels being able to function in the way that they have and provide such excellent services to the Aboriginal and Islander communities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that the way in which the Aboriginal Hostels Ltd (AHL) has provided services in the past will be jeopardised by the intended manner of its organisation or the coverage by the Public Service Act of its staff that is proposed by the Government. In fact, in relation to the Institute, for example, once again it operated in a way which the whole of this Senate wanted to see continue as far as its integrity and its autonomy and so on were concerned. We have passed the second reading and various amendments to the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill, where the Opposition did not challenge the fact that its staff were to become members of the Public Service. They found that that was not incompatible with the expectation they have that the Institute should continue to deliver the requirements of its charter with the high excellence which we have seen in the past, and I am sure that will continue with Aboriginal Hostels Ltd.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed there has been consultation, of course, with Aboriginal Hostels Ltd. It will be recalled that the original proposal was that Aboriginal Hostels Ltd be somehow merged into ATSIC. That was resisted and led to the solution which makes it clear that the status of the Aboriginal Hostels under the ATSIC umbrella-to put it that way-does not submerge the personality, the hard-won goodwill and reputation, which Aboriginal Hostels Ltd has built up, and for that reason Aboriginal Hostels Ltd has welcomed the manner in which the hostels are to be run within the framework of the legislation that we have before us.

As far as the members of staff at the hostels are concerned, Senator Boswell and others seem to think that because they become members of the Public Service that will somehow be to their disadvantage. On the contrary, of course: what it will do will be to allow those staff members, having acquired a certain level of skills and expertise and ability, to show their capacity to undertake the sort of work that they are allocated at whatever level within the provision of services by Aboriginal Hostels Ltd. They will of course gain the ability to work themselves out of that area of the Public Service into other areas. It may be that they will then be able to get the opportunity to move into perhaps a program administered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training or the Department of Social Security or whatever, and thus have a greater mobility than they have at the moment to use those skills which have come to fruition under the initial employment they have undertaken with Aboriginal Hostels Ltd. I believe that that would explain why, as far as I know, the staff have not indicated any unhappiness with this proposal. I am sure that their unions would be protecting their terms and conditions and the ways in which they will be working within the description of section 199.

I am advised that the unions support the proposals. After negotiations with the unions it has been agreed that staff of AHL in non-administrative roles will be engaged as continuing employees under the Public Service Act but under separate awards agreed with the unions. So it seems that the unions protecting the interests of the staff have managed to reach a position where they can go to their members and secure their support for this notion that they should be engaged as continuing employees under separate awards agreed with the unions. I am sure that that sort of protection afforded by their unions explains the fact that, as the advisers tell me, there has been no dissatisfaction expressed by the Aboriginal Hostels Ltd organisation in regard to the manner in which section 199 proposes to treat the staff of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly true, as the Minister has just indicated, that in relation to the hearings of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, when the Committee sought the opinion of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, no strong views were expressed on this clause.
—No views of any kind.

—No views of any kind. I accept Senator Baume's correction. If I remember correctly, we actually had to go to Hostels and ask it what its opinion was. It did not volunteer any views at all. In considering this matter, we are not dealing with an area in which there has been strong lobbying one way or the other, and it is therefore necessary to make some objective assessment as to the merits of the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister two questions. Is it the intention of the Government in putting in this clause that employees of Aboriginal Hostels gain the flexibility within the Public Service that they hitherto lacked? He implied that they would gain that, but I wonder whether that was the intention. I accept that that is a legitimate intention and there would be an advantage to some Aboriginal people to be able to move into other areas of the Public Service. One other matter which Senator Baume raised-it might have been Senator Tambling; I am not sure-was the matter of part time employees. I am not familiar with the Commonwealth Public Service Act, but certainly in the South Australian State Public Service Act-because I worked under that Act for many years-there is quite adequate provision for the employment of part time people. That is quite adequately covered within the ambit of the Act and does not create problems at all. I ask for the Minister's assurance on that matter also: that the casual or part time employment of Aboriginal people by Hostels if this clause is inserted will not be put in jeopardy in any way.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be possible for the staff of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd to enjoy the flexibility within the Public Service that I indicated. It is certainly the intention of this provision to permit that to happen. As far as part time, casual and other forms of employment are concerned they would be subject to the awards which are negotiated on behalf of the staff by the unions concerned. I have indicated that agreement has been reached that in non-administrative roles the continuing employee category under the Public Service Act will be utilised under separate awards agreed with the unions. I am quite sure that gives the scope which would permit that variation in the types and duration of employment to be provided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an old rule from New England-I think I have mentioned it before in this place-`If it ain't broke don't fix it', and that really underpins what the Opposition is trying to say. We are looking at something that ain't broke. In fact, it operates very well. Some of the arguments advanced by the Minister really do not hold up to any kind of analysis. The Minister says that it will be easier in some ways for people to move within the Public Service. People who work for Aboriginal Hostels Ltd today can apply for appropriate positions in the Public Service if they have the extra qualification.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Minister was not acknowledging, and what Senator Tambling did draw our attention to, is that many of these employees are part time employees, as it were, in the hotel-motel industry. They are cleaners, they make beds, they are housemaids, they are cooks; they are people for whom flexibility in employment is extremely important.

For 15 years Aboriginal Hostels have developed mechanisms by which it has employed these people; it has given maximum opportunity to Aboriginal and Islander people who may not otherwise have had employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —And used the DEET training scheme.

—Aboriginal Hostels has used the various government training schemes, such as those offered by DEET. When we went to Aboriginal Hostels, it was not quite as Senator Coulter said. It gave us no information. The response from Aboriginal Hostels, I seem to recall, was that the matter would be considered at its next board meeting. That was the extent of input we got from Aboriginal Hostels on the whole Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission matter. That is okay, that is their right. I am not worrying about that. But we received no documentary input of any kind. At no stage did the Minister outline negotiations on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Aboriginal Hostels, under its existing arrangement, has operated effectively, with great flexibility and with great distinction over 15 years. The change which is proposed, we believe, is unnecessary and is likely to be unhelpful in the longer term. Since it is more akin to a hotel-motel industry situation, we cannot see what benefit will accrue to these employees if they are brought under the Public Service Act. We think their circumstances will not be improved. We think their circumstances are likely to be slightly more difficult. We cannot see, in the light of the very good history of Aboriginal Hostels, why we should support this clause. We therefore press the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister advise what provisions under the Public Service Act would accommodate an Aboriginal hostel that wanted to employ a casual employee on a once a month basis for a function, say, for three or four hours?

SPEECH.PARA: If there were a convention or a visiting Senate Committee how would that particular hostel provide services under the Public Service Act? Under what provisions would it employ people for four or five hours, maybe for two or three days, on a particular convention or Senate inquiry, where that particular hostel had to provide services out of the normal? I see that it would place great restrictions on the hostels. I see that the Minister is getting advice. He must explain to the Senate what would happen under those circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister an answer?

—I hope so, Madam Chair. Thank you for encouraging me to give it to Senator Boswell. The fact is that under section 82-I do not have it in front of me-of the Public Service Act there is provision for casual and part time employment. But I would imagine that the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union covers many of the staff members who operate in the sorts of categories to which Senator Boswell has referred and it would be in that award that he would find the provisions that allow for the employment of those staff on proper terms and conditions. As I have indicated, separate awards and the membership and coverage of unions would be the basis on which the staff being taken on in the circumstances indicated by Senator Boswell would be protected in their employment terms and conditions.

—I have a very quick question to follow up. In some remote communities there may be a need to employ people rapidly for short times. Can the Minister tell us the flexibility that exists in the speed of employment and how much paperwork is necessary to put someone on under the Public Service Act 1922? We believe at the moment Aboriginal Hostels through its delegations gives to its local managers considerable flexibility and minimum bureaucracy. If in Port Kennedy, for example, there is a need to take on someone very suddenly who has not previously been in the Public Service-someone may be sick-we cannot see how Aboriginal Hostels would be able to do its job as effectively and we cannot understand how the Government can say that there will not be some loss of flexibility in the process.

—I think the point to make is that the management of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd has been well aware of this proposal over a long period now and it does not see any difficulty in the provision of services by the movement of its staff into this Public Service structure where the awards, as I say, are negotiated by the respective unions. I believe that the sorts of problems to which Senator Baume alludes would have been considered by that management team under Mr Clarke and had it felt that it could not deliver the services which are universally held to be of a very high standard it would have protested. If it has not it must think that it has the flexibility and the capacity to undertake the engagement of staff to deliver those services as required.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, through you I also direct a question to the Minister and ask what consultations have taken place between the ATSIC task force and the management of Aboriginal Hostels with regard to the employment conditions that will apply under the Public Service Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might ask what negotiations the Opposition has undertaken in respect of the amendment which it has moved to this Bill? Has it spent the winter recess talking to people in Aboriginal Hostels Ltd about this particular matter?
—Yes. In fact, it has.

—Well, in that case I am surprised that it has not received the same answer as we have. The fact is that Mr Clarke of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd has of course taken the primary responsibility, and it is his role, to discuss the structure that is proposed with the ATSIC task force, originally under Mr Gray. It came, after that early proposal about a full merger, to what one might call an amicable understanding that Aboriginal Hostels Ltd could work within the ATSIC umbrella. In fact, that is the term that Mr Clarke used in a letter of 28 November 1988 to Mr Gray, as chairman of the ATSIC task force. The letter reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Bill
I am writing to confirm our discussion regarding status of AHL under the ATSIC umbrella.
Your confirmation that it is not intended for AHL to be a subsidiary of the Commission in accordance with the definition given in the Companies Act is welcomed by the Company.
The Company will however, continue to be supportive of ATSIC and will work with the Commission to achieve the best possible delivery of service to our client group.
Directors of AHL will welcome the agreed three ATSIC Commissioners to the Board of AHL at the appropriate time which will ensure a commonality in policy.
In the meantime, I suggest that some word other than `subsidiary' be used to describe our close relationship with ATSIC.
Thank you for your co-operation.
Yours sincerely
R. C. CLARKE

Obviously, there has been quite extensive consultation and negotiation, and since that time there has been no indication that the board of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd or the person vested with the main responsibility for the day to day running of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd across the nation, have any difficulties of the sort that have been outlined by Senator Baume with the provision of delivery of service to the client group.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I indicate that amendments Nos. 39 and 40 put by the Opposition are acceptable to the Australian Democrats. To avoid the process of going through a long debate on those clauses I indicate that now and perhaps we can proceed more expeditiously.
—That is very helpful but Senator Peter Baume has not moved them yet. It might be best for him to move them first; then the applause from the audience can follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (39) Page 22, subclause 42 (1), line 3, leave out ``such meetings'', insert ``at least 4 meetings of the Commission in each calendar year, and may convene such other meetings''.
(40) Page 22, subclause 42 (3), line 9, leave out ``4'', insert ``8''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note for the record that the Government accepts these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (41) Pages 16 and 17, clause 29, line 32 (page 16) to line 25 (page 17), leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Basis of holding office
``29. (1) The Commission Chairperson holds office on a full-time basis.
``(2) The other members of the Commission hold office on a part-time basis.''.

This group of amendments relates to the commissioners. Amendment No. 41 is an amendment to clause 29. Clause 29 at page 16 of the Bill concerns the basis on which commissioners will hold office. Indeed, the matter which concerns us is that of full time and part time commissioners. As the clause is written it says that the nonelected commissioners may be elected on a full time or part time basis. It says that the persons who are elected to the first round of zone elections shall all be appointed on a part time basis and that, subject to clause 4, the persons elected on subsequent zone elections shall be appointed on a part time basis. Then it goes on to give the Minister discretion to appoint people full time if that is what the Minister wishes to do. Let us talk theoretically. I am not using any ad homineum argument here, but there are good and bad Ministers in any government and governments come and go. To give a Minister the capacity to appoint someone full time gives that Minister a certain power of patronage. Proposed subclause (4) of clause 29 states:
If the Minister is satisfied that it is necessary for the efficient performance of the Commission's functions . . . the Minister shall appoint those persons . . . on a full time basis.

So the Minister has a capacity if in his opinion he is satisfied that it is necessary to make some of the commissioners full time. The Opposition's amendment would say that we are quite satisfied that the Commission chairperson hold office on a full time basis. I will explain that. We think that the chairperson will occupy an enormously important, significant role. We have drawn upon our experience with the Aboriginal Development Commission and we are aware of the role which, say, Shirley McPherson had to fulfil and which she fulfilled with such distinction. It could not have been done properly, we believe, other than on a full time basis. If, as Senator Boswell says, and let us use the ball park figure, we are going to look at the availability of up to $800m a year-even if the figure is less it is a very substantial amount of resource-it is proper that there be a full time chairperson oversighting the Commission.

I think Senator Puplick has quoted to the Senate before, if not to the committee, the old saying that we did not do away with the divine rule of kings to take on the divine rule of experts. We think that if we do not have a full time Commission chairperson we will in fact find the Commission is run not by the elected commissioners but by the Commission bureaucracy. We think that to have a full time Commission chairperson, as we have had with Shirley McPherson, is desirable. We think that is necessary and we do not see any reason why the other commissioners should be there full time. If the Government had some particular project it wished to be carried out, for example, when it wished to appoint Mr Pat Dodson to another position, it simply did so by a separate instrument. He was not moved over as an ADC commissioner from part time to full time employment. He was moved on to the Royal Commission.

We cannot see any reason why it would be necessary here to move commissioners from part time to full time employment. Certainly it retains flexibility. But the clause as it is drafted gives the Minister considerable discretion to decide who shall be full time and who shall be part time. To put it bluntly, any Minister would then be able to play favourites and say to someone, `You will be full time', or, `Whether you remain full time is a matter for my pleasure'. We think it is far better to have the statute state quite clearly what the situation should be. We believe that there should be a full time chairperson and part time commissioners. We think that is far more in accord with what the ADC has done fairly successfully. From my experience in the portfolio that is, I imagine, all that would be necessary. I cannot see why it is necessary to put in a provision for possible full time employment of the other commissioners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —These provisions were put into section 29 of the proposed Act at the request of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, following extensive consultations by the Minister. This is an example of where the changes were made due to commitments given to Aboriginal communities as the Minister engaged in consultations.

SPEECH.PARA: It probably would be the expectation that a chairperson of such a Commission, with such a range of functions and powers and such a budget, would be full time. But it may be that the best person possible cannot provide his or her services full time because of other obligations. It would be disabling to the Australian community to put in a provision which restrained and curtailed the capacity to make an appointment of such an outstanding person who may not, for one legitimate reason or another, be available for a full time appointment. It is simply a question of providing for flexibility in regard to that particular appointment.

As regards subclause 4, I have confirmed that when instructions were given it was drafted by Parliamentary Counsel, on the basis that the Minister cannot pick or choose between commissioners and make some of the elected commissioners full time and leave some part time. As the clause reads, if the Minister is satisfied that it is necessary for the efficient performance of the Commission's functions for the persons elected at subsequent rounds of zoned elections to be appointed as commissioners on a full time basis, the Minister shall appoint those persons as commissioners on a full time basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you say all the elected commissioners?

—Yes. It is not meant to allow him to pick and choose between particular persons and to show favouritism and partisan patronage, which I think is the basic fear lying behind Senator Peter Baume's amendment. For that reason I believe that his fears are somewhat unfounded. In fact, the Parliamentary Counsel has suggested that to make that absolutely clear, at page 17, clause 29, line 4, where it reads, `now the Minister shall appoint those persons', the word ``all'' be inserted after `appoint'. It would read, `The Minister shall appoint all those persons as Commissioners on a full-time basis'. I think that would do away with a lot of the fear of patronage and favouritism which Senator Baume has referred to. For that reason, I seek leave of the Committee to insert the word `all' after `appoint' in clause 29, page 17, line 4.
—Senator Tate, we will deal with the other amendment first and you can move that at a later stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that response. In order that the Opposition can evaluate what the Minister has said, we really need to ask him a question. He said that the clause is drafted as a result of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander input. That input-the nature of the input, the time of that input-is quite unknown to the Opposition. We would like to get some details of the input to which the Minister was referring and on which he bases the justification for the clause. Perhaps he can get his officials to give him some information on that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Minister for his response in relation to our concerns about selective patronage. We note what he said. But I return to our concern: we have envisaged the board of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) as being rather like the board of a large commercial corporation. Typically, members of the board work on a part time basis in that job. We still think that is the appropriate way in which ATSIC might be constructed. If we were unsuccessful in what we are seeking to do, of course, we would look favourably upon the amendment which the Minister has proposed. As our first position, we still believe that on the analogy we draw, say, with the Qantas Airways Ltd board, or the Reserve Bank of Australia board or any others, most of the members should be part time members. To use the Minister's own example, we believe this will give the possibility of a wider range of talents being available to ATSIC once it gets under way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My advisers are not able to give me community by community examples over a period, but they tell me that this was a theme of the consultations which the Minister undertook from late 1987 onwards, particularly in central Australia. Those views were made known. What we are saying, basically, is that that sort of flexibility which Senator Baume seems to think is useful in relation to allowing the talents of part time members to be made available as elected commissioners is provided for within this clause. Part time members will be the norm. It is only if, after a period, the Minister comes to the view that it is not working as it should to perform its functions that there would be a move for all these persons elected at subsequent rounds to be elected on a full time basis. The consultations indicated that that was the wish of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. That is confirmed by my officials. In fact, I am informed, Senator Baume, that Shirley McPherson was first appointed on a part time basis and later made full time.
—We think that is the appropriate way to make the appointment of chairperson-full time.

—Yes, but I am pointing out that-and I do not know the history of the appointment-for one reason or another in those initial stages of her holding the chair a part time appointment may well have been most appropriate from her point of view and it was only later that a full time appointment was mutually agreed upon. I believe that flexibility should be retained in the present arrangements. Indeed, I am told that section 13 (6) of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act does not require a full time chairman, and we believe that flexibility should be retained.

—As we said in the Senate, it was possible for Mrs Shirley McPherson to do her job as well as she did only once she was full time. We believe that her example tells us that, whatever the initial appointment was, it was only when Shirley McPherson was full time in the position of Chairman that she really did take control of the Commission. We believe that is the appropriate way to go. I am grateful to the Minister. I do not want to prolong the debate, but I did want to respond.

—Mr Chairman, may I make a suggestion? I think we are all interested in getting as much done as possible. The Government does believe that it is important that we have the flexibility with the Chairperson that was demonstrated in the case of Shirley McPherson, as provided for in the Aboriginal Development Commission Act. If perchance the outstanding candidate could not otherwise be appointed because he or she could not take up a full time position, that would be a disaster. It is not ad hominem. I have no idea who is in mind, if anyone. But I believe we should keep that flexibility. As to subclause 4, to be quite frank it is not going to happen in the first two years. I do not want to argue any more. We should drop that subclause, and leave it for the two-year review. If the Commission wishes to make a case that it has been unable to perform its duties satisfactorily because of having only part time members, it can make a case at the end of the two-year review. So subclause 4 can be deleted. Let us get on with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, as I understand it, the way we should proceed is to resolve the amendment before the Committee, and then come back to deal with subclause 4 as suggested by the Minister.
