This is a long amendment and it relates to page 17 of the Bill where we seek to leave out clause 30 subclause (2) which appears at lines 29 to 32, with a view to inserting a new subclause. Subclause (2) of clause 30 states:

A person is not qualified to be appointed as a Commissioner if the person has been convicted and is under sentence for an offence punishable under a law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory by imprisonment for 5 years or longer.

Just let me say, in the simplest summing up, that this is altogether inadequate as a protection for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people from the kinds of persons who should be disqualified from being appointed as commissioner. Let us look at what it says. They are not qualified:
. . . if the person has been convicted and is under sentence for an offence punishable . . . by imprisonment for five years or longer.

If it were a bad offence punishable by two years imprisonment, the person could still be appointed a commissioner. If a person was convicted but not under sentence, he could still be appointed a commissioner and so on. We think that is altogether too lenient. The 1988 Bill, now superseded by the present Bill, is useful here. The disqualifying provisions in that Bill were too lenient as well. That Bill, in fact, referred to disqualification for persons who were subject to imprisonment for one year or longer for an offence. The new Bill disqualifies a person who has been convicted and is under sentence for an offence punishable by imprisonment for five or longer. The proposed amendment which the Opposition is putting up takes a slightly different approach. We propose to put in a new subsection (2) which states:
. . . a person is not qualified to be appointed as a Commissioner if he or she-
we outline a number of conditions which are not unreasonable, and which I list here-
(a) is an undischarged bankrupt . . .
If he is an undischarged bankrupt he should not be a commissioner of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. Our amendment continues:
(b) has been convicted of an offence against a Commonwealth, State or Territory law and sentenced to imprisonment for one year or longer; or
(c) has been convicted of an offence against a Commonwealth, State or Territory law involving dishonesty.
I will turn to that in one moment. To continue:
(3) In spite of subsection (2), a person covered by paragraph 2 (b) or 2 (c) is not disqualified by that paragraph . . . if . . .

Then there are some other conditions, because we do not want to make people ineligible for life. We do not want to be harsh in what we are proposing. We actually want to try to be reasonable and to promote the best interests of the Commission itself. So, if the person did not serve a term of imprisonment for the offence and at least five years have elapsed since the person was convicted, we say, `Wipe the slate clean' in terms of appointment as a commissioner. Or where the person did serve a term of imprisonment for the offence and at least five years have elapsed since the person was released from prison, we say, `Wipe the slate clean'. In any case the Federal Court of Australia on application by the person could declare that in spite of the person's conviction he or she ought not be disqualified from being appointed.

We have tried to provide an appeal procedure where someone says, `Look, this is not fair. I may have been convicted but in fact I should be capable of being appointed a commissioner'. Then that person could go to the Federal Court and argue his case. Our amendment actually seeks to put in better safeguards for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people for whom the Commission is supposed to operate. It seeks to identify certain people who should not become commissioners but at the same time to provide mechanisms which will build fairness into the system and which will in fact wipe the slate clean after a period of five years. The Minister for Justice will know where we got the period of five years from. I think it relates to directors and trade union officials. There are similar provisions in other legislation relating to people who have been convicted, and whether they can then be appointed to certain positions.

There is one matter I have not come back to and that is the question of a conviction for an offence against a Commonwealth, State or Territory law involving dishonesty. In every community in which I have worked there are honest and dishonest people, and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities are no different. There are saints and sinners, there are good and bad people and there are some dishonest people. It is just not right if dishonest people are able to be elected as commissioners of ATSIC and to have control of or a significant say in the very onerous responsibilities which will attract to that position. We have proposed that the Minister would have the responsibility of declining to appoint as commissioner, a person who, in his opinion, had committed an offence of such seriousness and so recently that he was not a suitable person to have financial responsibilities.

When I was Minister we had, for example, evidence presented to us of blatant dishonesty involving the misappropriation of Commonwealth funds within an Aboriginal organisation but we could not get sufficient evidence actually to convict someone. We had many witnesses' statements, we had much information, we knew who had had the money, we knew who suddenly had the new motor cars and we knew what had happened even if we could not get a conviction. That is why we say that such people are not suitable. We have drawn the amendment more narrowly. We have used the words `is an undischarged bankrupt; has been convicted of an offence against a Commonwealth, State or Territory law and sentenced to imprisonment for one year of longer; or has been convicted of an offence against a Commonwealth, State or Territory law involving dishonesty'. We are saying any conviction for dishonesty should disqualify someone for five years from occupying a position of trust such as would be involved in becoming a commissioner of ATSIC. As I said to the Committee, Mr Temporary Chairman, we have written in a series of protections to make sure that people will not be unfairly treated by this provision. I have to say to you that we have drawn upon laws which exist in other areas of Commonwealth responsibility to try to model the way in which we might respond here.

I emphasise that there is no party partisan politics in what we are suggesting here. It relates only to the type of people who might be commissioners for ATSIC and it relates to the kinds of disqualifications which are necessary and advisable. I remind the Committee that one of the people who argued most vociferously for ATSIC before the Select Committee is now in prison for a serious offence. People do go to prison and it is not appropriate that those people should become elected commissioners. Of course they would not become appointed commissioners because, we hope, the Minister would take such appointments to a Cabinet Committee and they would be appropriately vetted at that level. But we think it is necessary to be rather more realistic and comprehensive in the way in which clause 30 is drawn and we believe our amendment will be to the advantage of the Commission and lead to the protection of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

In other words, both conditions have to be satisfied: the person has to have been convicted and be under sentence; which means that the person has been convicted and is either awaiting imprisonment or is already in gaol-that is the way I read those words-and has been sentenced to gaol for five years or longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is `punishable'; it is not necessarily a gaol term.
—We will come back to that.

—Perhaps I am misinterpreting the words. Perhaps I may explain my understanding of the words and then the Minister may like to correct me. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister seen a report in this morning's Australian Financial Review that Australia has the fourth lowest tax regime in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD)? What do these statistics reveal about the accuracy of the welfare state tag put on Australia by some conservative commentators and political figures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report and last week I also received a table, from Treasury I think. I am not sure from which publication it was drawn. The table shows the same thing as the Australian Financial Review report reveals, so I presume the source is common. That is, taking total taxation as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP), Australia stands at 31.3 per cent, and at the top of the table we have countries such as Sweden on almost 57 per cent, Denmark on 52 per cent, and virtually all of Western Europe falling somewhere between. Indeed, the only countries in the OECD that have a lower level of taxation as a proportion of GDP are Japan and the United States. In those two cases they are only marginally lower at just over 30 per cent. Turkey is right down the bottom at 24 per cent of GDP for total taxation.

ANSWER.PARA: The question referred to a welfare state. Perceptions of what a welfare state is are somewhat variable. In the case of Australia, we do have what would be generally regarded as a welfare state but is very much a targeted welfare state. That is largely responsible for the differences in the levels of taxation applying in Australia and in most of northern and Western Europe, although there are some variations in the composition between those countries. In Australia, for example, in the short term, unemployment benefit payments are relatively low compared to a number of European countries but over the long term they are more adequate than the levels prevailing in those same European countries. Japan and Turkey rely less on governments for welfare payments than does Australia or, indeed, probably any other country in the OECD. In the United States there is a much lower level of public expenditure on health. In the United States only about 40 per cent of total health expenditure is publicly financed. In Australia the percentage is almost 85 per cent. But the United States-and this is a very important point-has a very much higher total level of health expenditure as a proportion of gross domestic produce (GDP) than does Australia. Indeed, it is some 3 percentage points higher. This demonstrates, I believe, that both our public health and welfare sectors are efficient by world standards in delivering equitable outcomes relative to the level of taxation in this country.

There are from time to time demands from both sides. On the one side there are people who believe that the number of free or subsidised services that are available should be increased or their quality, and therefore their cost, improved. They believe that the welfare system ought to be less targeted than it is and/or pay higher rates. That, of course, can be responsibly accomplished only if there is a commensurate increase in the level of taxation and, as I pointed out last week publicly, the most effective resistance to higher levels of taxation comes from the work force in general which pays most of the taxation. That resistance is expressed through the Australian Council of Trade Unions among other sources. On the other hand, we have people who claim that the welfare system should be more tightly targeted than it is. That is a point of view. But, in view of the commitment which I am told Senator Stone gave to the National Press Club today that a coalition government would not be cutting pensions, I am wondering which elements of this mythical Australian welfare state the Opposition is proposing to cut should it be elected to government. As soon as that promised list is revealed-I think it is supposed to come at the end of this month or something like that-I will be studying it with great interest.

I ask: Given, firstly, the increasing concern in the community about the environmental effect of a wide variety of consumer products and, secondly, that the Victorian and Western Australian governments have developed environmental labelling initiatives known as green spot programs, can the Minister explain what action the Government is taking to enable consumers to make informed choices about purchasing environmentally sound products?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Aulich for raising this important issue, which is of concern to a growing number of people throughout Australia.
—Has it reached double figures?

—No, Senator Alston, it has not reached double figures. With that sort of attitude Senator Alston probably will not be here after the election, either. People are becoming much more environmentally conscious--
—Order!

—Mr President, this is a serious issue, despite the rumblings on the other side. People are becoming much more environmentally conscious. Not only are they prepared to make decisions responsive to the environment for themselves, but also they expect governments to intervene to protect the quality of life. That is one of the principles guiding this Government. This area is one which has been given up to us as an example of where governments can intervene to assist people making informed choices. Not only has this come to us from consumers but also we have noticed in recent months a growing number of industry organisations responding and putting out programs in this area.

ANSWER.PARA: We believe the Government has a role to ensure that consumers are not misled about what products may be environmentally sound and also that industry has a nationally uniform framework in which to act and in which to coordinate its proposals. As I say, this consideration, this concern, in the community has been acknowledged by the Government. In recent months we have had some discussions with consumer groups and conservationist groups. Also, representations have been put both to me and to Senator Richardson by industry groups. We announced a little while ago that we would give attention to how we could respond to the area. Today both Senator Richardson and I will be announcing and setting up a national inquiry into the marketing and promotion of evironmentally friendly products. The inquiry is to look at all parts of the development of the process, including production. It will also look at different ways in which we can respond, whether it is by, for instance, endorsing specific products, specific qualities in products, or generic ranges of products. The alternative of an education promotion campaign better to assist both industry and consumers is also going to be looked at.

The inquiry will be run by representatives from both my Department and the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and in its considerations will be consulting with States, industry and public interest groups. It will also have a charter to look at what is happening internationally, and at what groups industry is putting up within Australia, as well as the conservation movement. We expect that the first report, a general summary of what is happening internationally and nationally, will come to us by early October. We anticipate a final report early next year.

In conclusion, as I said, the inquiry will be set up this afternoon. The Government is concerned to ensure that people who are concerned about making environmentally conscious decisions and buying environmentally friendly products will not be misled; that they will have the information that should be available to them. We are also concerned that industry act within a coordinated, uniform framework.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Further to my question on funding for research into the prevention and cure of mesothelioma, which the Minister answered on 26 May this year, I ask the Minister: Firstly, has the National Health and Medical Research Council reported that medical research and experimental treatment in Perth by Dr Bruce Robinson, Dr Musk and others warrants further funding on the basis of its scientific and humanitarian merits? Secondly, is the Minister aware that as a result of the cessation of funding to this program it is in danger of imminent collapse and a number of dying cancer victims have been obliged to resort to procedures of witchcraft and Chinese herbal medicine as their only remaining health care option? Thirdly, has the Minister been informed of the plight of Mr Brian Kirk, aged 33 and the father of two children, and of Mr John Walshaw, aged 67, both of whom in the absence of any alternative treatment for mesothelioma are to undergo surgery to cut all the nerves surrounding their spine and lungs which will both relieve their unendurable pain and cripple them? Fourthly, will the Minister undertake to approve further funding to the program without delay?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me take those questions in the order in which they were asked. To the first question I can say that I am advised that the National Health and Medical Research Council has not reported on funding proposals for 1990. Recommendations are not expected before October of this year. To the second question I can say that funding for the research being conducted by Dr Robinson and Dr Musk will continue until 31 December 1989 when their current three-year project funding expires. The project is funded as research, not as treatment programs. The provision of appropriate health care services in Western Australia is a matter for the Western Australian Government in that sense. To the third question, the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, is not aware of cases raised by Senator Jenkins. Treatment arrangements are not the responsibility of the Minister. They are matters for the patient and the treating clinician. As already pointed out, overall responsibility for health services in Western Australia is a matter for the Western Australian Government.

ANSWER.PARA: To the last question asked by Senator Jenkins, the Minister will approve funding for further research by Dr Robinson and Dr Musk beyond 31 December 1989 only if the National Health and Medical Research Council advises that their proposed research has sufficient scientific merit to attract funding in competition with other applications.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. On 26 May the Minister said exactly the same thing, that the research will be approved if the National Health and Medical Research Council recommends that continued research warranted the further funding. I therefore ask the Minister whether he is aware that at least one top level researcher has already left that team of researchers, because if members are kept on edge until the end of the year obviously they cannot be kept on tap and only be given a few weeks' notice as to whether or not their research qualities will be needed for next year. I ask the Minister: will he report that to Dr Blewett, please?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, let me answer the question as it has been put. I say thank you to Senator Jenkins for acknowledging consistency, at least, in terms of the answers of 26 May and today. Secondly, I will certainly draw her remarks to the attention of Dr Blewett. Thirdly, if it is true that one top level researcher has already left I again observe that funding is in place to carry through on the projects that have been approved until the end of this year. In October of this year the National Health and Medical Research Council will report on funding proposals for next year. Therefore, if that researcher has left on the basis of uncertainty about funding, and for no other reason-I am not sure whether there are other reasons-then I would have to say that that is a premature decision and that that researcher would be better advised to continue on until the funding position is determined.

ANSWER.PARA: I conclude by saying that these funding decisions are made by the National Health and Medical Research Council and then recommended to the Minister. I am not quite sure whether the Minister actually has discretion in approving them or in fact he is bound to accept them. But leaving that point aside, one has to say that the best qualified minds in Australia to make a medical assessment of the need and veracity of this research in competition with other projects is being applied in this case and we should await their outcome and not make premature or startling claims before the process has been completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. With regard to the Government's commitment to micro-economic reform, has the Government monitored the benefits that have accrued to the petroleum industry since the deregulation of the crude oil market on 1 January 1988?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, the Government has maintained a monitoring of the effects of the deregulation of crude oil marketing in Australia. I should mention to the Senate that this was a policy brought in by the then Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, and that we have monitored the effects of it by looking at the activities on the ground, by holding discussions with the various companies, by examining the comments made by those companies at shareholder meetings and in their annual reports and by examining the comments made by industry observers. I think sufficient time has now elapsed since 1 January 1988 to enable a summary or conclusions to be made about the effects of that deregulation, and I should point out that one of the key expectations of the deregulation would be that it would bring forth a considerable improvement in the refining capacity within Australia for various types of crude oil including oil from outside of this country as well as oil from within it. That was regarded as one of the benchmarks for whether or not this deregulation would be successful.

ANSWER.PARA: In summary, the oil companies and the observers all report that they believe that the deregulation has been successful and one of the ways in which we can establish that beyond doubt is to look at what investments they have now made in extra plant and equipment. BP Australia Ltd has now announced the commissioning of a residue cracking unit at Kwinana to process heavier crudes. Those crudes classically are crudes that might be purchased from the People's Republic of China and elsewhere. Ampol Ltd has announced a $100m investment for the construction of a platinum catalyst reformer at the Lytton refinery to produce high octane feed stock for unleaded petrol. Shell Australia Ltd has announced a $400m investment in a catalytic cracking unit at Geelong and a $200m investment in extending and upgrading the Clyde refinery. Caltex Australia Ltd has announced a $57m investment in the rationalisation of the Kurnell refinery, with improvements in control instrumentation and conversion units being modified to take heavier crudes with improved product yields. We have now seen a massive investment in the refining capacity in Australia which I believe can be routed back to the deregulation decision. Indeed, observations of that character are made in the annual reports.

The other reason this investment has been forthcoming is that if one examines all of the annual reports of the oil companies in Australia for 1988 one can see that while some of them lost money in areas of their operations, only two of them had an actual loss and all of them made a substantial profit over 1987 in their refining and crude oil divisions. I think that is also a feature of deregulation. We have here a stunning record of micro-economic reform achieved by the Hawke Government, and making a move to deregulation has massively increased investment in refining capacity in Australia and is a shining example of the commitment of this Government to continuing through micro-economic reform to achieve efficiencies in the industrial infrastructure of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance in his own capacity and as Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware that estimates indicate that possible losses as a result of the Western Australian Government's disastrous business bungles could amount to as much as $750m? Does the Minister have any concern that the huge losses confronting the Dowding Government may ultimately lead to a request for special funding from the Commonwealth, and what would be the Government's attitude to any such request?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans would no doubt recall more of the details of this than I do, but some years ago the Western Australian Government requested some financial relief from the Commonwealth because of the disastrous consequences of the take or pay contract that that pompous old fraud Charlie Court signed some eight or nine years ago. On that occasion I remember that the Commonwealth bent over backwards in forgoing its own royalties-and I think one or two other matters as well-in order to help the Western Australian Government out of that financial jam.

ANSWER.PARA: I recall that the costs over the long term of that disastrous contract were in excess of $1 billion. I also remember ringing, shortly after the Federal election of 1983, the relevant Minister in the Western Australian government of the day and suggesting to him that he sack the State Electricity Commission (SEC) commissioners who had signed that contract, that he call them up and asked why they had signed that contract. If they said, `Well, we signed that because we thought it was good business', they should have been sacked for incompetence. If they were to say, `We signed it because Charlie Court was twisting our arms', which is the real reason they signed it, they should have been sacked for being toadies of Charlie Court. I still believe that that was a bit of good advice, which unfortunately the Western Australian Government did not act upon. As a consequence of that omission, the State Government was lumbered with a $1 billion-plus bill, because of this contract, which a megalomaniac who happened to be Premier at the time, back in the late 1970s, had forced the State Electricity Commission commissioners to sign.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a bad deal now, though, is it?
—I must say, Senator Panizza, I do find it incongruous, to say the least, that this same--

—On a point of order, Mr President: the Minister is clearly debating the question. I have not taken a point of order earlier on the abusive language which this Minister is engaging in because I understand that as a retired member of parliament Sir Charles Court is not protected by the Standing Orders. But I draw your attention to the fact that the Minister was asked a question about the immediate likely responsibilities of his Government with respect to the carrying on of a Labor government in Western Australia with which the Minister is closely associated. The question is a relevant question, touching on the public interest and the public duties of the present Government. I ask you, Mr President, to direct the Minister to cease debating the question in an historical and abusive way and to direct his answer to the specific matters which have been put before him which relate to the depredations of the Labor Government in Western Australia and what impact that may have on the Commonwealth finances.
—Order! I ask the Minister not to debate the question that he was asked, and to conclude his answer as soon as possible.

—Certainly, Mr President. If the Western Australian Government should make an approach to the Federal Government for special financial assistance, my response will not be sympathetic. But I was pointing out that on a previous occasion, because of the very much larger losses incurred by a stupid decision of a previous Western Australian Government, the Commonwealth bent over backwards to relieve it from some of the financial consequences. That was done because the amount involved was vastly larger and probably in those days the Commonwealth Government was not running as tight a general fiscal policy as it is now. My attitude will not be sympathetic, but I say again, Mr President, that I find it rather offensive that the Western Australian politician who engineered the greatest losses ever inflicted upon the taxpayers and consumers of Western Australia is the same Western Australian politician who is now being holier than thou and conspiring with a number of other people in Perth in an attempt to crucify the State Government for having made some mistakes, the magnitude of which is insignificant compared with the magnitude of his.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. In the light of the logic of the way in which the Minister has argued the question that I asked, would he say clearly whether he regarded the State Government's investment via the State Government Insurance Corporation in Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd as a good or bad investment?

—The evidence available to me suggests that it was certainly not a good investment. However, I repeat, Mr President, it is dwarfed by the stupid decision engineered by Sir Charles Court 10 years ago and thrust upon the State Electricity Commission by him.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of the widespread interest in the very fast train VFT project and the likely impact of this project on many individuals and communities near the proposed rail routes, will the Prime Minister make available the report of the interdepartmental study group into the very fast train project that was reported in some detail in the Sydney Morning Herald of 18 August 1989? Is not the Prime Minister's public endorsement of the project, somewhat premature in view of the reservations expressed in the interdepartmental report, and the fact that neither the environmental impact statement for the project nor the Senate inquiry is completed?

—Mr President, the report referred to in the Sydney Morning Herald was based on documents prepared for Cabinet which included materials from several sources. It included materials of a commercial-in-confidence nature supplied by the joint venture partners dealing with the technical, financial and economic aspects of this planned private sector project. For these reasons it is not possible to release the report as it stands. Those parts of the report which do not contain, or are not based on, commercial-in-confidence material can however be released to the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. It was in recognition of the widespread interest in this project and the need for full public discussion of a number of important issues associated with it that Cabinet decided to make a reference on the very fast train to the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. Together with the normal environmental impact statement and procedures, this will ensure that full public discussion takes place.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to reports that the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) has decided to look at the Bond Corporation's ownership of what is known as the old Emu Brewery site in Perth which, it was revealed last week, that company had sought to sell to the Western Australian Government. Will the National Companies and Securities Commission be investigating the very tangled web of dealings involving the Western Australian Government and the Bond Corporation which has been revealed over the past week?

—Mr President, as I am advised, NCSC staff are investigating certain land transactions involving companies in the Bond group. One of the transactions being investigated is the purported sale of land known as the old Emu Brewery site involving Bond Corporation and its associates and the FAI insurance company and its associates. Investigations are continuing and the NCSC is considering whether it will hold a formal hearing into the matter. As the matter is under investigation by the NCSC, it would not be appropriate for me to discuss the matter further as it could be prejudicial to the investigation and the parties involved.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Minister answered only the first part of my question. I asked him: Is the NCSC investigating or will it investigate the great tangled web of dealings involving the Western Australian Government and the Bond Corporation which has been revealed over the past week?

—I tried to indicate that the investigation that the NCSC has indicated it is undertaking relates to a transaction between FAI and Bond concerning that piece of land. Whether it considers that it ought to hold any further or more extensive investigations, and indeed whether it will hold a formal hearing into the matter that is of concern to it immediately, is a matter for its judgment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article entitled `Income Splitting' which was published in the August 1989 edition of the journal Family Matters? Can the Minister confirm that permitting family income splitting for income tax purposes would have the types of drawbacks spelt out in the article?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article. I have not read it thoroughly. I have glanced through it briefly. It is the work of two researchers with the Institute of Family Studies whose names, I think, are Frank Maas and Peter McDonald. The article reached the following three broad conclusions: Firstly, income splitting helps the wrong families, `wrong' being defined as those who are not particularly needy. Secondly, and fairly obviously to anybody who is at all numerate, it would be extremely costly unless of course the tax rate scales were to be changed and the tax rates significantly increased. Thirdly, it would discourage married women from working in the paid work force or preparing themselves to enter the paid work force. I have not checked the precise figuring that is reported in the article but I can confirm that the three broad conclusions are soundly based.

ANSWER.PARA: Income splitting of the type discussed in this article is similar, as I understand it, to income splitting proposals which emerge in the Opposition from time to time and get regularly bucketed by Senator Vanstone, among others. In particular, I understand Senator Vanstone on the Keith Conlon show in Adelaide on 22 August very effectively bucketed the idea that her leader was touting at that time. Apparently he had thought through his position on income splitting about as thoroughly as he had thought through his position on the taxation of nominal or real interest rates. Both I suppose spring from the common denominator-that, as he admits, he does not take an accountant's approach to Budget preparation. But income splitting of the type discussed in the article could lead to a significant number of low income families paying more tax while families with a single income earner on $70,000 or more could pay less. In the words of the authors:

If the introduction of income splitting were to be cost neutral (that is, that no government revenues would be lost) major cuts to other government programs such as health, education and welfare would be necessary. Families on the lowest incomes would be hit hardest by these across-the-board cuts, regardless of whether they were receiving one or two incomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask a question of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, to wake him up, but my question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I am sure the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade will be interested in the question in any event, but I draw the attention of the Minister for Finance to a chart in the most recent edition of the Economist magazine which shows the world's 10 top debtors on the basis of external debt to banks, plus non-bank trade related debt in 1987-88. Is the Minister aware that Australia has the dubious distinction of third place on this list? That is, we are the third highest debtor nation after Brazil and Mexico and ahead of the Soviet Union and Argentina. Does the Minister consider this performance is cause for concern, especially as we are continuing to increase indebtedness while even Brazil and Mexico are beginning to claw it back?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the table in question. Foreign debt or the seriousness of a foreign debt burden can, of course, be interpreted in a number of different ways, all of them having an element of legitimacy in them-for example, debt as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP), the cost of servicing debt as a proportion of export income and so on. Those various measures all have some relevance in demonstrating the underlying reality. But basically, without going into the detail or endorsing the particular interpretation that may have been put on that table, the basic question that I have been asked is: Do I regard Australia's debt problem as serious? My guess is that I have made at least a dozen speeches in the last 12 months in which I have answered that question in advance. Of course I regard it as serious. I regard as equally serious the fact that we continue to run a large current account deficit, largely, of course, because of the cost of servicing the existing debt. There can be short term variations in measures of debt as a proportion of GDP caused by valuation changes which may or may not tell us very much that is meaningful about the underlying or the fundamental position. But of course I am concerned about it.

ANSWER.PARA: There are ways of eliminating current account deficits. In New Zealand's case, for example, the current account deficit either has been eliminated or is very close to being eliminated. That, however, was done in conjunction with an increase in unemployment of around 5 percentage points, without even counting what was exported to Australia-that is, the unemployment that was exported to Australia. That is one way of overcoming a current account deficit. It is not, in my view or the Government's view, the best way of overcoming a current account deficit. That is essentially the way Australia overcame the same sort of problem in the 1930s and, I suppose, likewise in the 1890s, although there are few, if any, reliable statistics available for the 1890s period. It is one way of overcoming it. It is not the optimum way, and it is not the way in which either the Government or I would like to see it done.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware of recent claims that Chinese students in Brisbane have been harassed by visiting officials of the Chinese Embassy? Has the Australian Government reminded the Chinese Embassy of the need for its officers to remain within the bounds of proper diplomatic behaviour?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of press reports from Brisbane and other State capitals alleging that Chinese authorities have been applying pressure on Chinese students involved in protests against the actions of the Chinese Government. I have to say that if these allegations should prove to be substantiated they would be of very great concern to the Australian Government. On 29 August officers of my Department raised with the Chinese Embassy claims from Adelaide of harassment of Chinese students by Embassy officials. We made the point that it was the Government's view that Embassy staff should not exceed the appropriate functions of diplomatic representatives. In response the Chinese Embassy officer stated that the officials were engaged in their normal task, as he put it, of taking care of Chinese students in Australia, and he asserted they had acted completely in accordance with their role and responsibilities as diplomats.

ANSWER.PARA: We will keep these situations under very close review and look very carefully at any further evidence that should emerge of activities on the part of the Chinese Embassy which are colourable in the way that I have described. Finally, let me make the point that, of course, we do support the right of Chinese students to hold peaceful protests in this country and we would deplore any punitive actions taken against them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care. I draw the Minister's attention to an article in the Melbourne Age on Saturday, 2 September, which indicates that the demonstration project of the Victorian Hawthorn Council in extended hours home care for the frail aged is expected to close in October. Is the Minister aware that the cost of this project to the taxpayer is $162.19 per week for each of its clients, as against $476 per client per week in a nursing home or $2,408 per client per week in a public hospital bed? If the extended hours service were to close, three of its clients will need urgent admission to a nursing home and a further 15 are likely to need admission sooner than they otherwise would, as they will no longer be able to manage at home. Does the Minister acknowledge that caring for these people would then happen at a considerably increased cost to the taxpayer? Will the Minister undertake to have his colleague the Minister for Housing and Aged Care investigate urgently why only half the $89,000 bridging funding sought from the home and community care program to enable the service to operate until 31 December has been promised; and, secondly, why none of the promised bridging funding has so far been received, leaving the Hawthorn Council to fund the project entirely from its own resources since June? I would appreciate it if the Minister would undertake to provide me with an answer before the Senate rises on 7 September.

—I have not seen the report referred to by Senator Patterson. Therefore I am not able to verify that the circumstances that she asserts in this particular case do obtain. As a consequence, I will refer her question to the Minister for Housing and Aged Care and I will undertake to get an answer as soon as that is reasonably possible.

—My question is directed to the the Minister for Finance. On Monday in the Senate, speaking to the Government's response to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs report on income support for the retired and the aged, Senator Walters said that the tax recoupment for 1989-90 will be $885m from superannuation and `it does not take a great deal of thought to work out that if the Government is ripping off about $880m extra this year, the pensioners and indeed all superannuants will be down by that particular amount'. Can the Minister say whether Senator Walters's conclusions are correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The conclusions, of course, are not correct and, indeed, Senator Walters was mouthing the same innumerate drivel in a question to me in the Senate, I think on Wednesday of last week. She is either incorrigible or ineducable-
—Or both.

—Or both, because even after she was put straight last week, as Senator Crowley says, she repeated the same drivel two days ago in the Senate. What she either fails to understand or refuses to recognise is that the Government has changed the timing of the taxation of funded superannuation schemes and payments in such a way that some of the tax is paid when the money goes into the fund with a more than commensurate reduction-I will return to that in a moment-in the amount of tax which is paid on the way out.

ANSWER.PARA: The change has no negative effect in leaving all superannuants-as Senator Walters says-down by that particular amount. It just means that a slightly lesser amount of tax is paid at different times, some of it up front and some of it further down the track, without any detriment to the ultimate payments to be realised by the individuals. It applies to funded schemes only and because a tax of 15 per cent is applied on the way in, the two taxation rates which previously applied to lump sum payments on the way out of 15 per cent and 30 per cent have been reduced to zero and 15 per cent. The reason that the total amount of tax paid falls marginally is that what is now the 15 per cent tax levied when a lump sum is taken out of a fund is levied on an 85 per cent base whereas previously it would have been levied on a 100 per cent base. I know that Senator Watson understands the arithmetic underlying that and since Senator Walters sits alongside him I suggest that she try to arrange for Senator Watson to give her a tutorial on this, preferably using large numerals and multi-coloured pencils to attract her attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a press report in yesterday's Canberra Times stating that Mr Dawkins had been blasted by the Federation of Australian Scientific and Technological Societies for failing to fill, for the past three months, two vacancies where the appointees must also serve as chairmen of grant assessment panels on the Australian Research Council? Is the report correct? Does the Minister agree with Professor Frank Larkins, the President of the societies, who said that the failure to fill these vacancies was deplorable and resulted in the scientific community losing confidence in the Council? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the reason for the delay, when these vacancies are expected to be filled and the steps the Government plans to take to restore the scientific community's confidence in the Council?

—Mr President, I did not see the report. I do not know whether it accurately reports what Professor Larkins, or whoever it was, said or indeed whether Professor Larkins, if he was accurately reported, was correct in saying what he said. I do not know whether the two positions on some council are vacant and have not been filled for some time. I will try to get an answer to those questions from Mr Dawkins.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to comments made recently by the Opposition health spokesman, Mr Shack, regarding the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal? Do these comments include allegations that the PBRT is not independent and that it reached its recent findings on a database which was fundamentally flawed? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the accuracy of these serious allegations and advise on what basis the PBRT reached its decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports attributing to Mr Shack remarks of that character. I do not believe in communicating through the press, so I do not necessarily accept that Mr Shack made all those remarks in the particular way in which the report I saw indicated. However, there are allegations of this sort abroad. Let me deal with them. I regard those allegations that the Tribunal was not genuinely independent as nothing short of a foul smear of the Tribunal. The National Health Act, amended during the period of the Fraser Government when Mr MacKellar was Minister for Health, requires that the Tribunal be independent. The Act was observed in this case by the Government, in the full sense of the word. Therefore, if there are allegations emanating from Opposition health spokespeople then they are against an Act which is a Liberal Party Act.

ANSWER.PARA: But, as well, I understand that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, my colleague Peter Staples, on this occasion asked the President of the Industrial Relations Commission to select a chairman from amongst his deputy presidents. He did that. The selection, therefore, was not one undertaken by the Government. He selected a distinguished deputy president, Mr Joe Riordan, who has had a long and distinguished career in industrial relations and who is regarded on both sides of the industrial relations fence as being an outstanding deputy president of the Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is about as long and distinguished a career as a member of the House of Representatives.
—Are you making an innuendo, Senator? Are you making an innuendo?
—Order! Senator Puplick will cease interjecting and Senator Cook will address the Chair.

—Thank you, Mr President. I was just emphasising the eminent standing Deputy President Joe Riordan has on all sides of the industrial relations community. I regard, therefore, that innuendo against him and the other two independent members of the Tribunal as nothing short of slanderous. This has brought up what I think is a flaw in the legislation, in that there are not contempt provisions for people who make slanderous remarks about three individuals who hold a judicial appointment. If there were contempt proceedings under the Act and those people could be identified, the Tribunal would be able to deal with a contempt of its members in an appropriate way. I think that that is a gap in the Act. The second allegation concerns the database. I know that Mr Shack has said that the database is flawed, but he has not said where it is flawed or how it is flawed, nor has he adduced any proof, presented any evidence to support his assertion, or said by whom it is regarded as flawed.

ANSWER.PARA: Seven government departments were involved in the preparation of the Government's submission to the Tribunal. All of them accepted that the database was valid, that the database was compiled on methodology recommended by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and that it conformed to that methodology; it is a database approved, therefore, by the ABS. I do not know that anyone wishes to sully the reputation of that organisation. The three independent members of the Tribunal also accept that the database is accurate. Therefore, arguments by assertions which are meant to shake the confidence in an objectively prepared database can only be seen as political manoeuvring and since no evidence has been adduced or presented to establish the allegations, as frankly a fairly shameful political act.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. How many defence and civilian personnel were involved in the nuclear tests at Maralinga, Emu and Monte Bello in the 1950s and in the clean-up operation soon afterwards? Is it the case that only 12 of these personnel are expected to be eligible for compensation under the Government's recently announced compensation scheme? If not, how many are expected to be eligible? Is it the case that only sufferers of two specific ailments will be eligible for compensation under the scheme? How many families of the 60 or so personnel who are known to have already died from cancer subsequent to their involvement in the tests will be eligible for compensation under the scheme? Finally, is it the case that Mr Doug Rickard, who was a focal case in the setting up of the inquiries into these nuclear tests, and whose myeloid metaplasia and myelofibrosis have already been acknowledged to have been caused by his involvement at Maralinga, is still not eligible for compensation under this scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reply to the question by saying that any ex-serviceman who took part in the British atomic tests program in Australia in the 1950s and 1960s and who has an illness or disease which it is considered results from participation in that program, has always been entitled to apply for compensation under the Commonwealth compensation legislation. Honourable senators might recall that in 1986, in response to a recommendation of the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia between 1952 and 1963, the Government extended compensation eligibility to non-Commonwealth employees, pastoralists and Aborigines who were on the test site and, as a consequence, compensation is available to any of the 15,400 people involved in the atomic test program. In regard to the round figure of 15,400, it is not possible to give a precise figure for the reason that there is no record of the actual number of Aborigines in the area. Therefore we have to make an approximation.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, as announced on Monday, the Government has now decided to set up a special administrative scheme to compensate any test participant who has, or has died from, multiple myeloma or leukaemia other than chronic lymphatic leukaemia. The decision is based on maintaining equity between Australian and British atomic test personnel following action taken last year by the United Kingdom Department of Health and Social Security to pay a war pension to any UK test participant with either of those two diseases. I point out that this recent decision applies only to the conditions of multiple myeloma and leukaemia other than chronic lymphatic leukaemia. It does not change the situation regarding other medical conditions. In these cases the individuals would still need to put in a claim for compensation to Comcare.

Senator McLean asked for some particular details. In terms of the first part of his question, I have given him the figure of 15,400 and the reason why we say that is an approximate figure. In terms of the second part of his question he asked, referring to the 12 personnel, `Are they expected to be the only ones eligible?'. We only know of 12 people who have the two conditions that qualify in this case for special arrangements, but if any others come forward they too, if they meet the criteria, will be eligible. I also emphasise that if there are any other conditions-individuals may not qualify for this compensation, but nonetheless they may have a claim-that claim can go before Comcare and be dealt with. Senator McLean also asked-I think I have answered it-this third question: Do they have to have the two specific ailments to be eligible? He asked: How many families of the 60 or so personnel who are known to have already died from cancer subsequent to their involvement will be eligible? I do not know where the figure of 60 comes from. I cannot verify the figure of 60, but of course anyone who comes forward will be eligible if they meet the criteria.

Lastly, I confirm Senator McLean's observations about Doug Rickard but say that he has already been paid compensation for these conditions. He came forward several years ago. He proved that he has the condition and that he was present at the tests. His claim was accepted and he was awarded compensation. What is now being made available is the same conditions to others at the same level. Therefore, to provide him with a particular claim in this case would be to provide him with a doubling up, and that is not appropriate in the circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. To sharpen the point of the question, will the Minister not acknowledge the fact that to qualify for compensation under this scheme one must be either dead or dying?

—Some people whose survivors qualify for compensation under the scheme are dead; that is a fact. Others who qualify for compensation under the scheme will have myeloid metaplasia and myelofibrosis. That is a very serious health condition. It could be said that those people were dying. This is a compensation scheme for a set of circumstances which, I think, has been canvassed adequately in the Royal Commission. It is not a set of circumstances that can be laid at the door of this Government. Nonetheless, the compensation to meet the unfortunate outcome for those individuals is now available.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Puplick proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The systematic attempts of the Australian Labor Party to transfer the costs of its re-election campaign from its own coffers to the public purse, plundering the pockets of the Australian taxpayer.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —For as long as it has been around, the Australian Labor Party has had a chronic inability to distinguish between its own coffers and public revenues; between its treasury and the public treasury; between its purse and the public purse. Whenever it goes to put its hands in its pockets for electoral expenses, somehow, mysteriously, but unerringly, it manages to put that hand into the pockets of the Australian taxpayers instead. With the advent of its latest $3.2m theft of public money from the taxpayers by way of a stamp allowance to members of the House of Representatives, by way of that rort it has hit new heights of public contempt for probity and new depths of political immorality. This is but the last and the latest in a long, tawdry, sordid but systematic campaign to transfer the costs of its election campaigns from its own coffers to the public purse, thereby plundering the pockets of the Australian taxpayer yet further.

SPEECH.PARA: Not content with being the highest taxing, most grasping government in Australia's history, it now reveals itself as the greatest thief of public money for its own political purposes. There has been a whole series of these particular undertakings. Let me simply list some of them: the system of public funding; the proposals for free media advertising; the postage allowance; the variety of government propaganda glossies; the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS) operation; the deliberate cuts imposed in the budget of the Senate, where it can be at least held to scrutiny; the unlimited provision of certain resources to the House of Representatives members only; the public payment of telemarketing campaigns of members of the House of Representatives; the secret public opinion polls paid for out of public funds; the price watch exercise. We will come to each of those in due course.

Let us look at the magnitude of that amount. In terms of public funding, on the last occasion the Labor Party was paid $4.8m out of public revenues. On Government television advertising of Labor Party schemes, there was expenditure of at least $8m, going up in some instances perhaps to as high as $10m. On replacing its own advertising on television with a system whereby other people will have to pay for television advertising, it could cost at least another $5.5m. The stamp allowance paid to members of the Australian Labor Party is worth $2.6m; the price watch exercise, a quarter of a million dollars; and the covert subsidies to members of the House of Representatives of another $1m; giving in total a figure of between $23m and $26m worth of public expenditure on campaign expenses which ought properly to have been borne by the Australian Labor Party and the members of the Labor Party.

Let us come first to that question of public funding. In 1983 public funding was introduced by the Labor Party into the electoral system with the connivance of the Australian Democrats and in the face of the opposition of the Liberal and National parties, which moved as an amendment to that Bill that the section of the Bill regarding public funding should be deleted because we do not believe and never have believed that paying money out of the public exchequer for that particular purpose is in fact the correct way to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you take it, don't you? You take it every time.

—Senator Ray interjects. Let me make it perfectly clear to him: despite the fact that the system has been rorted by the Labor Party, we are not going to stand back and allow it to double its advantage in that regard because we have said consistently that when we are returned to government public funding will be removed. It will be removed and we will see whether the Democrats, or what is left of them after the next election, are prepared to be part of that particular arrangement. At the last election campaign $4.759m of public money was, according to the Electoral Commission, paid to the Labor Party-money which could have been paid to do something about the sorts of promises made in that last election campaign. Do you remember them, Mr Deputy President? No child will be living in poverty by 1990. That is the sort of promise the Labor Party will be prepared to dishonour, while keeping its own snouts in the public trough for $4.8m worth of public money in public funding terms.

SPEECH.PARA: We come next to the question of the proposals put forward again by a Labor-Democrat majority of the members of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters to replace the cost of advertising on television with subsidies out of the public purse once again. If we look at the last report of the Joint Committee we see that in the 1987 election somewhere in excess of $10.25m was spent by the political parties on advertising, of which there was something like $7m spent in terms of television advertising. The Labor Party's share of that will be transferred to somebody else to pay for, and at the end of the day, of course, it will be out of the public purse. If we look at the article by Ross Dunn in the Australian Financial Review of 8 August, it talks about the way in which at the next election campaign that cost may be $15m but that will be transferred elsewhere. Dunn says:
But in order to save these millions, the major parties will have to agree to . . .
They will have to agree to something and the only people who will save money will be the political parties. The Sydney Morning Herald in its editorial of 9 August, said this:
If there is to be assistance for political parties to advertise on television, there would be an honest and a dishonest way of providing it. Our politicians-
and I interpolate here, the Labor Party-Democrat majority of politicians on the Committee-
having little difficulty with the question of whether their parties should get public assistance, are, typically, proposing to go about it the dishonest way.
It is dishonest to pretend that $15 million worth of television time has no cost simply because it is appropriated rather than bought.
If the politicians had been honest-
I interpolate again, if the Labor Party and Democrat politicians had been honest-

they would have found $15 million from the public purse to distribute to the political parties so that they could buy the commercial television advertising time they say has become beyond their means.
The dishonest suggestion that compulsory advertisements will cost no-one anything helps avoid inconvenient questions about just how far public assistance to political parties should go.

It has nothing to do with improving the quality of democracy in this country. It has nothing to do with fundamental standards of probity and decency in public life. It has everything to do with saving the Labor Party money.

We come next to the question of stamp allowances. My colleague Senator Vanstone will have more to say about this matter. We must remember what the shabby deal is. The shabby deal is to bypass the Parliament, to bypass the proper legislative steps that need to be taken in this regard, to bypass the Remuneration Tribunal. I do not know how Senator Cook or anybody else can come in here and talk about the decisions of the umpire as far as pharmacies are concerned, because as soon as the Labor Party sees a potential advantage to it, it is prepared to take the matter out of the hands of the tribunal in order to put it in the pockets of members of the Australian Labor Party.

We come next to the question of glossy advertising. The Department of Social Security-the Department which has presided over a decline in the real standard of living of Australian pensioners, of dependants, of children-embarked on an advertising campaign on family allowances, featuring pictures of a $20 note being handed over to buy new shoes for children; a campaign costing about $5m. The Age Pensioners News-sent out to everybody to try to persuade them that they were better off, when everybody who read it knew they were manifestly worse off-cost about $1m. The Australian Taxation Office's campaign used the marvellous heading, `We're here to help you'. After all of the bad press it has received, the truth is, as everybody knows, the only help that the Australian Taxation Office provides at the moment is to help to put the Labor Party's hands in the pockets of the taxpayers of Australia at every conceivable opportunity. That campaign cost $750,000.

What about the environment and multicultural advertising? According to the Government, it was the greatest statement ever issued as far as the environment is concerned, except in the minds of everybody who knows anything about the environment. I wrote to Senator Richardson and asked him how much it cost. He wrote back to me and said he did not know and that I should write to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and ask him. The last one to which I refer is the Australian Sports Kit-a lovely glossy kit. It includes a little picture of Senator Richardson. If one looks at his face, resting upon his hands, smiling into the camera, one would never have thought he would have capped a knee or kicked a head in his life. If he thinks that portraying himself like some superannuated koala bear on the front of such a kit means that he will get away with anything, he has another think coming.

The cost of these sorts of glossies is now more than $10m. The Federal Labor Government is the third largest advertising buyer in Australia. It spends more than $35m on its advertising campaigns. Remember the $4m spent on Priority One? Remember the $6.5m spent on the tax file number? Remember the $4m that was spent before that on the identity card? Remember the $3m that was spent on a one-sided advertising campaign on the 1988 referendum, despite the fact that the Parliament said the Government should not do that? It should be remembered where it goes. It goes to Mojo MDA, its mates in the advertising industry, which received somewhere in the vicinity of $10m of that money. Some $300,000 goes to John Singleton Advertising. About $3m goes to Forbes Macfie Hansen. One thing one can say about the Labor Party is that when it is stealing money out of the public pocket it likes to make sure that its mates get a percentage on the way through. They are perfectly happy with that.

Then we come to the National Media Liaison Service. We do not know exactly what it is going to cost this year, because in the explanatory memorandum of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories for its estimates this year we find that there is only some of it in there. Then we get this quaint little line, `In addition, the administrative costs of the National Media Liaison Service are met from within this subprogram. Salaries and allowances for the NMLS are met by the Department of Administrative Services'. If we go to the estimates for the Department of Administrative Services, those figures are all buried in the rest of its salary components. So we cannot work out exactly what the cost is. In fact, if we look at the answers given to Senate Estimates Committee E, to Senate Estimates Committee D and by Senator Button in the chamber on 15 August 1989, we are given three quite different figures. But they are all between $1.2m and $1.5m. The figure was $1.5m when the National Times in August 1983 exposed what was going on. An article in the Adelaide News on 23 September 1988, in relation to Mr Colin Parks, the head of NMLS, stated:
He works in Parliament House and is paid by the Hawke Government with taxpayers' money.
His brief is to chip away at the Opposition . . . The Hawke Government's use of the NMLS is a disgrace, providing it with an unfair advantage at no cost to party funds.

The Labor Party does not have a free rein here in the Senate. When we put up, through the Appropriations and Staffing Committee, a request for proper funding, Senator Walsh, with the sort of attitude that he takes to the Senate, cuts it back by $1.765m despite the fact that he can find twice as much as that for the stamp allowances of members of the House of Representatives where the Labor Party does have a numerical advantage. Again, he does not want the Party's programs and behaviour put under scrutiny. In the House of Representatives this Government provides unlimited stationery so that members of that House, predominantly Labor members, can print their political newsletters for distribution to their constituents at public expense. They do that on their House of Representatives unlimited stationery and now postage. The Labor Party provides, through its telemarketing advice and from the software it has got from the United States, the programs for its members to telemarket and poll their electorates. The Department of Administrative Services pays the cost of those telephone calls. The Party runs an operation--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about telephone calls out of Greiner's office?

—I am not in the least bit interested to hear interjections from somebody whose political career in Sussex Street was born, nurtured and promoted by the most corrupt political machine and organisation ever known in the history of this country. When he can come clean he can come in here and make comments. What have we found with things such as the Price Watch Committee? A number of selected Labor members are provided with additional staff and additional computer equipment. They put advertisements in the papers, with their photographs attached to them-the way that Mr Snowdon, the honourable member for the Northern Territory, does. The cost of that extra facility, extra staff, extra advertising and extra computers for Labor Party members-exclusively Labor Party members-is somewhere in the vicinity of another quarter of a million dollars. Finally, there are public opinion research operations, mainly undertaken through Australian National Opinion Polls and through Mr Cameron, which governments of Labor Party persuasions have been prepared to indulge in at public expense, involving gross sums of money, for a large number of years.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not as though this matter relates exclusively to the behaviour of the Labor Party in Canberra. Prior to the last State election in New South Wales, we saw the Unsworth Government-one of whose the political apparatchiks, Senator Faulkner, will take part in this debate later-pour vast sums of public money into advertising campaigns of all sorts. We know that Senator Faulkner, given his particular ideological bent, was more likely to have opened champagne than hemlock when the results of that election came in. Nevertheless, we have seen consistently throughout the Labor Party this attitude to what is the proper expenditure of public money.

This matter of public importance today is designed simply to draw to attention the fact that the stamp allowance is not some isolated incident. It is not some one-off, occasional occurrence. It is part of a systematic plan, which the Australian Labor Party has had in place since it was elected in 1983, to realise the opportunities available to it. It reminds me of the famous words of Leo X, the last great Medici pope who, when he was elected to the Chair of St. Peters, remarked to the College of Cardinals:
Seeing that it has pleased God to give us this office it is our duty bounden to enjoy it.

There is absolutely no doubt that that is precisely the attitude that the Labor Party takes to being in government. It has access to the Treasury. It has access to the administrative services network. It has access to the wherewithal to keep itself in office. So, through public funding, media free time, postage allowances, a variety of glossies, the aNiMaLS operations, the cuts to the Senate, the House of Representatives stationery allowance, the campaign by telephone paid for at public expense, the public opinion polling paid for by the Government and the price watch operation, it is determined to get as much value as it can for its $23m to $26m worth of public money improperly subverted into paying for what it should be paying for out of its own resources. The tragedy for the Australian taxpayers at the end of the day is that they have to put up with it. The one hope they can take from the whole thing is that, at the end of the day, it will not damn well work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
