TALK.START.PARA: —Tomorrow I am going to cancel my subscription to the Bulletin. I only buy it for one reason, and that is to see the latest opinion poll. I can always tell when I hear one of Senator Puplick's hysterical contributions in this chamber whether we have drawn level or gone ahead. I always look for motive when trying to assess a motion. The only motive the Labor Party would ever have to dip into the public purse to support itself is a fear of defeat. That fear does not exist. I think we should look at the reasons why it does not exist. It does not exist because the Opposition is a total shambles. It does not exist because the Opposition has no policies. That is why we have these red herrings drawn across the chamber today. Opposition members have no policies; they do not want to discuss the serious issues of the day. We have not got a tax policy out of them. When is that coming? It has been promised at different times but no appearance, Your Honour. The Opposition has no immigration policy. We have got an environment policy, a wimpish policy dictated to the shadow Minister by a few rednecks in the National Party. But on the whole, we have nothing from those opposite-no policies at all.
—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy President. The Minister is speaking arrant nonsense. We have published 35 policies.
—Order! Senator Teague, that is debating point, not a point of order.

—I draw Senator Teague's attention to the Standing Orders and suggest that he read them one day. As I say, the Opposition has absolutely no policies; there is just a lot of waffle going on. Therefore, Opposition members have to come up with red herrings. In addition to having no policies, they have no leadership. Senator Puplick wants to quote Pope Leo X. The thing that the Liberal Party reminds me of is the Avignon split. It has two Popes, one in Kooyong and one in Bennelong, who alternately take leadership of the Liberal Party. The Liberal Party has no leadership. I never thought the day would come when I had to feel sorry for the Liberal Party, but I do. It had poor old struggling John Howard; its members publicly butcher him. The people who butcher him admit that they deliberately lied about that. They must have broken a mirror. The moment they do it, the moment they butcher Howard, his popularity goes up; the new pope's popularity crashes.

SPEECH.PARA: Even at this moment, as they debate in this chamber, the slimy apparatchiks of the Liberal Party are out looking for a new leader, looking for a new messiah to bring them out of the cold, out of opposition. Who can they look towards? First of all, they looked to Mr Elliott as the great white hope, but unfortunately they could not get rid of Mr Shipton out of Higgins and therefore Mr Elliott could not be brought in. Anyway, he is earning a few extra million dollars through a few procedures out there in privatising a company; why should he want to come in here at fifty grand a year? So Mr Elliott is out. Then they decided that Senator Chaney might be the answer, so Senator Chaney was endorsed for a lower House seat. Maybe he is the next prospective leader. But everyone in this chamber knows that that is not on; leadership needs a special quality. Senator Chaney has all the qualities in the world but that one, unfortunately, of leadership.

TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going to become relevant? When can you address what Senator Puplick said?

—Just for Senator Teague's information let me lay it out. Do we have a motive? Should we not be worried? I have already said that the Opposition has no policies; now it has no leadership. Thirdly, as the Opposition has proved today, it has no cohesion. Members of the Liberal Party are too busy backstabbing each other to be a cohesive force and an alternative government. We are not a particularly popular Government, amongst businesses and others. Every time we mix with them the first thing they do is criticise this Government. I accept that. But they always add, `But that Opposition; aren't they just hopeless?'. There is no cohesion at all.

SPEECH.PARA: A classic example took place this morning. I walked into this chamber and I sought to see who the shadow Minister was, leading in the debate on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill. But the shadow Minister did not lead. He had to bring in a hired gun, a very talented one, Senator Peter Baume, to do all the work on it. Because the Opposition has a shadow Minister stuck here, because it has to have a ratio with the National Party and because there is no other National willing to serve on the front bench it has to bring in a hired gun as its shadow Minister. But it so lacks cohesion that it still will not offer him a shadow Ministry. The reason is that it has already had to accommodate another 31, an all time record in this Parliament. The Opposition needed 31 shadow Ministers and it needed to give out another six or eight petty jobs to the hangers-on. That was the only way it could get a coalition together to get Mr Peacock up. Everyone had to be put on a promise. It is a pity the Opposition did not choose its shadow Ministry on the basis of ability. But it does not. I know it has a very narrow pool to regard in that way.

To answer Senator Teague, there are three things lacking in motive for the Labor Party: no policies; no leadership; no cohesion. When we look outside the Parliament there is a fourth reason. The Liberal Party machine is nothing short of being pathetic at the moment, absolutely pathetic. Let us look around the States. In New South Wales, it had to get rid of its State director, Starr. In Victoria Michael Kroger and company are sacking staff hand over fist.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Knowles

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to the Standing Order regarding relevancy, and I repeat the words of this matter of public importance today:

INTERJECT.PARA: The systematic attempts of the Australian Labor Party to transfer the costs of its re-election campaign from its own coffers to the public purse, plundering the pockets of the Australian taxpayer.
That is what has been put to the Senate by Senator Puplick. I put to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that Senator Ray is not addressing that subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to address the subject of the matter of public importance.

—With due respect, Madam Acting Deputy President, if I do not believe there is any substance to the matter of public importance, I believe I am entitled at least to go to other reasons as to why this matter may have been brought up today. I will leave that subject and come back--
—Are you ignoring the Chair's ruling?
—I am just about to move onto something else. Senator Knowles is just trying to waste the time of this chamber. I have not said that.

SPEECH.PARA: What is really involved here is one of the most crass exercises in hypocrisy I have ever seen in this chamber. Let us go through some of the issues raised. As regards polling, Senator Puplick says we are dipping into the public purse by using polling. Every government in the 1970s and 1980s has used polling. Opposition senators have had the list produced as to where the account goes for polling. The honourable senator just mentioned ANOP; he did not mention all the other firms or do a percentage breakdown of how much ANOP does; nor did he go to the point as to who tenders for what. It may be true that ANOP has four times the polling of, say, Roy Morgan and Co., but who tendered for the contracts? Did Morgan put in for them all? Of course he did not. The honourable senator did not mention that the various firms used by the Liberal Party are used by this Government for polling. He does not mention that his Government not only polled in 1982 but refused to release the results of those polls. He did not mention the 1982 post-Budget survey that took nine successive Estimates Committee meetings for former Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle to produce.

So, when Senator Publick brings up the question of polling, he is doing nothing more than putting a very hypocritical Liberal Party position. In government-and I bet anything you like the Greiner Government is polling it sits by and says nothing about it; so do not bring up the question of polling.

Senator Puplick brings up the question of government advertising, and amnesia strikes again. The Liberal Party advertised time and time again when it was in government between 1975 and 1983. Remember the 1982 post-Budget election ads that went on. Senator Teague was here. Does he acknowledge that the Liberal Party did it? Of course it did it. In the programs for next year on government advertising we intend to spend $4.7m on an AIDS campaign-totally justified-$2.75m on a drug offensive, and $16m on defence. Every time Opposition senators quote the global figure of $35m, do they ever mention that $19m is for things like employment advertisements for the Public Service? No, they do not. They never mention those things at all; they distort the figures for their own benefit. So on the questions of polling and advertising, it is exactly the same.

Then Opposition senators bring up the point about the aNiMaLS group. The aNiMaLS group costs somewhere between $1.2m and $1.4m-exactly the same amount as the Government Information Unit that operated when they were in government and that did the same thing as the aNiMaLS. And they all sat back. They never said a thing in that period about the Government Information Unit. They justified it. Let us have a look at that. I have here a media guide for the Liberal Party put out by the Federal Secretariat. In it they say, `You as a Liberal backbencher or as a Liberal should go and use the Government Information Unit'. So, when in government the Liberal Party used the Government Information Unit.

Another confidential document was produced in December 1978 when their government was setting up the liaison officers group. Do honourable senators not recall that? One of the requirements of these liaison officers was that they maintain close contact with party officials in the State, keeping them fully informed of developments on the Federal scene. What hypocrisy we hear from those opposite! It should be said of Trotskyists that they were simply Stalinists out of power. It seems to me that the Liberals today are simply out of power. That is the only difference that those things make. So, on the question of polling, government information, government advertising, et cetera, where is the difference?

On the question of public funding, that is a very common thing throughout the world. Senator Puplick says it is stealing from the public purse. The Liberals and the National Party opposed public funding in this chamber. They then took public funding. The National Party not only opposed it on principle but opposed it morally. It took the money. The moment Senator Puplick and his party took the money, they just showed how much their principles are worth. They put a price on his principles. They said, `We stand on principle on this matter but we will sell out for X amount of dollars'. So do not come in here and say public funding of election campaigns is simply stealing from the public purse; it quite clearly is not.

I turn to some of the other matters raised. The matter of the views on advertising of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters was raised. Those are the Committee's views; they are not the Government's views yet. Honourable senators know that the Government has not responded to that report. They could also guess that it is unlikely that it will respond to that report quickly, because it involves substantive issues.

So it is of no use saying that the Labor Party or the Labor Government is trying to get free time on advertising. It may be, it may not be, but Senator Puplick is pre-empting a Government response that is some months away, and I can assure him that there is quite a difference of opinion within the Government on these matters. Some clearly favour free time; some clearly favour a total ban on advertising. There is an equally strong group that says to leave it as it is.

Then Senator Puplick came up with another amazing statement-that there is a conspiracy to cut back Senate appropriations to reduce the effectiveness of the Senate. I do not know how well the Senate did this time vis-a-vis the House of Representatives. Generally, though, the complaint I hear continually is that the Senate, through its competence and its negotiating skills and its secretarial backup, does better comparatively than the House of Representatives in estimates. Maybe not this year but on average over the last six years the Senate has done better than the other House. To allege that there is some sort of conspiracy to cut back the Senate is nonsense. It has to be understood that the amount of money expended by government in this country as a percentage of gross domestic product has gone from 30-odd per cent to 24 per cent of gross domestic product. Every department, every institution, has been cut back, and to come up with that sort of stupid conspiracy theory simply amazes me.

Summarising the hypocrisy of members of the Liberal Party: they oppose public funding but they will take it; they oppose the postage increase but not one of them has said that he will hand it back; they oppose polling yet they do it themselves and do not publish the results; they oppose Government advertising yet they did it themselves; they oppose the aNiMaLs group-the National Media Liaison Service-yet they had the Government Information Unit. I ask everyone to draw his or her own conclusions. The hypocrisy really hits home when we realise how silent they are when it comes to other conservative parties in power in this country and the corruption in which they get involved in an electoral sense. In today's Australian-I did not hear Senator Teague comment on this-we see the heading `Queensland electoral office ``a gold mine for rorts'' '. So not only do we have a malapportioned electoral system, a gerrymandered electoral system, but the Nationals in Queensland make sure they have charge of the Electoral Office. Let me just quote some of the activities in the Queensland Electoral Office in the last year:
A superior officer had ordered him (an electoral officer) to process an enrolment form which he believed had been `blatantly and illegally witnessed' by a National Party MP in February 1988.
Office staff were subjected to National Party intimidation `should they rock the boat'.
Use of deceased persons names to vote was a common practice.
Guidelines for the removal of the names of senile elderly people were not being followed.

So we have in this country a State government which not only rigs the electoral boundaries but then puts the fix in in the Electoral Office. I have never heard anyone on the other side say anything about that, and this is the great dilemma. What makes it even more pathetic is that the major victim of the boundaries, the major victim of the electoral malpractice, is the Australian Liberal Party Queensland branch. It almost reminds me of those jokes about sadists and masochists, the sadists being the Queensland National Party and the masochists being the Queensland Liberal Party: `Beat me, beat me', says the Liberal Party, and they get some sort of mutual enjoyment out of it.

We never hear those opposite comment about those problems in Queensland, yet they are relevant. They are relevant if we want a proper, democratic process to exist in this country. We must be consistent, I believe, in defending democratic process, not selective, as a hysterical Senator Puplick has been today, not selectively quoting, saying we spend X amount of dollars on advertising when he know absolutely certainly that a lot of that money goes into standard things like tendering advertisements, et cetera. Senator Puplick should not come in here and say that the Government should not poll. I believe governments should always poll but I always say that, as much as possible, all that material should be released so that everyone gets the use of it. That is the best way to proceed. But no, Senator Puplick comes in here with some sort of selective Liberal amnesia, strutting around and saying that the Labor Party has to put its snout in the public trough to survive.

The reason why this debate is on today, absolutely clearly, is that the Liberal Party has lost its self-confidence. It cannot produce policies. Every time it produces a leader it comes up with a dud. It is as though it broke a mirror and got seven years bad luck. Every time Liberal senators look outside the chamber for support they see a pathetic Liberal Party machine. I always thought the Labor Party was pretty tolerant of failures. As a Labor Party member and a Collingwood supporter, year in, year out, season in, season out, we used to get drubbed. We were always tolerant. We used to give leaders three goes. We gave Bob Rose of Collingwood three or four goes to win the premiership. But here is the Liberal Party with a Federal Director, Mr Eggleton, who has been done one, two, three times-in 1983, 1984 and 1987-and they have left him there to go for the quadrella.

That is where most of the Liberal Party's problems lie; they do not lie with the Labor Party trying to use public funds for campaigning. We have no motive to do so. We have no need to do so. What this country needs is a competent and strong Opposition. It does not have it. It has had a very pathetic Opposition, wracked with obvious internal discord. The most classic case of this is Mr Ian Macphee. Ian Macphee has been a representative in this Parliament, I think for 15 years. He fronts up for preselection in a very acrimonious public debate and is defeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember what Don Grimes said about you when you did over Jean Melzer.

—I think that is perfectly consistent with what I am about to say. He took his chances at the preselection; he got done. That is the way things occur. I never whinge about that. But what was amazing after that in terms of party management? Everyone in here and in the other chamber is vulnerable to fronting up to a preselection and getting rolled--

—As is Senator Puplick, but I do not want to rub that in. But what do Liberal members do in terms of management of the Liberal Party? Liberal Party members have a massive public brawl, they have a massive public reconciliation, they find a solution, and they cannot deliver a seat which still requires a 2 per cent swing against the Labor Party for the Liberal Party to win. The essence of this matter is that the Liberal Party is absolutely pathetic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -We are debating today a matter of public importance introduced by Senator Puplick in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The systematic attempts of the Australian Labor Party to transfer the costs of its re-election campaign from its own coffers to the public purse, plundering the pockets of the Australian taxpayer.

I have been listening to Senator Ray's response to this and, given Senator Ray's acknowledged grasp of political history, he went back to consider some of the things that occurred during the Fraser Government. I would like to look forward and use the example that Senator Ray used with regard to government polling. Government polling was used quite extensively by the Fraser Government. Government polling has been extensively used by the Hawke Government. It will be extensively used by any incoming Peacock government.

There was an opportunity for Senator Puplick, in leading for the Liberals in this debate, to make a comment on this. He chose, however, to make a comment with regard to the public funding exercise, which I will return to later. He made a promise that he knows he will not have to deliver. When he got onto the polling exercise, quite properly, quite carefully, he made no promise. The reason for that is simple. Any elected Liberal government next year would use government polling. Any incoming Liberal government would also use a media exercise, as the Labor Party has done. Any incoming Liberal government would use every one of the current facilities which are available.

Senator Puplick made only one promise in regard to the whole range of items that he put forward to the Senate that he proposed to do anything about-public funding for election purposes. That was the only one about which he made any promise. I would like to respond to that because he linked the Australian Democrats with that proposition. It is perfectly true that we voted in favour of the legislation which was passed by this chamber which established public funding. As Senator Puplick knows, the Democrats will hold the balance of power in the next parliament. I say to him that we will not vote in the next parliament to overturn the public funding legislation passed by this chamber, whether the Peacock Liberal-National Party coalition or the Labor Party is in government. Of course, the Labor Party will not decide to change its mind. If the Liberals attempt to fulfil the promise uttered today by Senator Puplick, it will not be passed. Senator Puplick knows that. He can add up. He knows what the numbers in this chamber will be after the next election. They have been predetermined by the system that is in operation. It was a hollow promise.

When one looks at all of the issues raised in this debate, one finds that Senator Puplick was not able to refer to one item that a Liberal-National Party coalition, in government, would actually change. Everybody in the electorate is very much aware of these sorts of exercises. Indeed, Senator Puplick referred to the famous quote by the Medici pope, Pope Leo, that since God had given him the papacy, he was here to enjoy it. That is not applicable precisely to the Labor Party; it is applicable to governments. All governments of all political persuasions operate in the same fashion.

I want to comment on one other issue that was raised by Senator Puplick in terms of the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters that handed down a report in this chamber not long ago on a number of items, two of which have been of some public interest; that is, the complete disclosure of all electoral and party donations-a position which is the Democrat policy and has been so since the party was founded in 1977. Half of the recommendation has been implemented-that is, donations for election purposes. We hope that the other half of that recommendation of the Committee will be accepted and implemented by this Parliament. There was another recommendation with regard to free radio and television advertising. Anybody who listened carefully to Senator Ray would have got the wink and the nod that absolutely nothing will happen with regard to that in this Parliament.

Senator Puplick, in his normal histrionic fashion, relied heavily on referring to the party allegiances of Committee members. Senator Jean Jenkins, the Democrat member of the Committee, signed the majority report as a member of the Committee. It so happens that the Democrats-I do not know what the Liberals do-operate as individual senators. They listen to the evidence, weigh it up, come to a conclusion and then either sign the majority report or possibly put in a dissenting report. They operate as individual senators. We respect and support that position. Indeed, we believe that the Senate committees have been as successful as they have been only because senators have operated in that fashion. They are not party appointees; they are individual senators from a variety of parties who bring to bear all points of view on a common problem.

What happens as a result, further down the stream, with regard to other members of the political party to which those members belong, is a matter for the parties to decide. Within our party structure, we are not embarrassed by any report signed by any of our members, because we know that they operate in a conscientious and thorough manner. Whether we agree with them is a totally different matter. We determine that at the appropriate time, if any legislation appears in the chamber. But, as I say, those who are listening to Senator Ray will know that no such legislation will appear in this Parliament.

For the remaining time that I have I want to have a look at another matter and that is one that Senator Puplick made a fair amount of play on early in his contribution. I refer to the downstream effect with regard to public funding. I think it is important to put on the record some of the facts surrounding this exercise. There have been two elections with public funding in this country at the Federal level-the 1984 and 1987 elections. In the 1984 election the Labor Party received $3.7m approximately, the Liberal-National Party $3.4m approximately, the Democrats $500,000 and the Nuclear Disarmament Party $200,000. In the 1987 election the Labor Party received $4.8m, the Liberal-National Party $4.7m and the Democrats $0.7m. I think it is interesting that the Liberal-National Party in the 1984 election was happy to take the money-it did not have to-and in the 1987 election it took the money. I think quite wisely the Liberal and National parties took it because they accepted the inevitability of the exercise, an exercise that most Western democratic countries are moving towards if they did not get there before we did, on the basis of trying to do something about the ever-escalating costs of democratic elections.

But I look, then, at an item which I think is very important and that is the breakdown exercise. The exercise with regard to advertising is quite fascinating. In 1984 the amount for advertising spent on broadcasts-that is, radio and television-was $4.5m. When we get to 1987 it goes from $4.5m to $9.2m, whereas the publishing costs-that is, costs with regard to print media-went from $4.2m to $5.7m, an inflation jump. The amount spent on radio and television almost doubled and, indeed, for the total increase, if we aggregate those together from 1984 to 1987, we are looking at 137 per cent. That is extraordinary and, indeed, it is a frightening exercise. But when one looks at countries in the West with regard to the costs in that area, one cannot but be worried that the amounts of money that are necessary to engage in that particular activity have to come from somewhere.

Senator Puplick would lead us to believe by his contribution today that there is such a thing as a free lunch. I am here to tell him that there is no such thing as a free lunch and that political advertising, whether it is paid through the public purse or elsewhere, is paid for by the people of Australia. All of that money is paid by the people of Australia. The way it gets to political parties may differ but it is all paid by the people of Australia-every dollar. Whether they pay it on the jam and the cornflakes that they eat, or whether they pay it in their taxes, that is where the money comes from that supports the democratic process. It is not manufactured; it does not come off a rolling printing exercise somewhere. It comes out of the pockets of ordinary Australians. There is no such thing as a free lunch with regard to political advertising. One can choose how it is done, whether one wants it as a grace and favour exercise through multinationals and others buying favours of a democratically elected government or whether one wants it controlled through the public purse so that one knows that the government of the day at the end of the exercise does not owe anybody a brass razoo.

We had this debate on public funding and the Democrats made it very clear where we stand. I like the title of that Joint Committee's report, Who Pays the Piper Calls the Tune, because that is precisely what we are talking about in this area. We believe that in our democracy the media's portrayal of political events and party policies is crucial. It is crucial for the electoral health of our democracy. We do not believe that financial resources alone from one's friends should determine which political party or which set of policies attracts the most media attention. We would hope that that may be more an independent media judgment and a judgment made in the interests of better government for the country as a whole.

Senator Puplick raised a number of points that I would like to agree with. I agree with the points he made about the $30,000 increase in the postal allowance for members of the House of Representatives. As we have said before, the way of dealing with that issue should have been through the Remuneration Tribunal. It was a disgrace, it still is a disgrace, that it was done any other way. The disparity between resources available to members of the House of Representatives and the Senate I would also like to refer to. I support, at least in part, what Senator Puplick said, not in exactly the same terms as Senator Puplick but in terms of the fact that that disparity will only cause frictions and problems for the future. It is an absurd exercise and it is occurring.

At the end of the day what we need to be very much aware of is that moneys that are spent should be spent openly and in the public eye so that the people of Australia are able to make their decision about whether any government of any political persuasion or any party is bowing to pressure from special interest groups. The only way they can do that is to know where the money comes from and how it is spent. It is the openness of the exercise which is necessary. We have to look very closely-and hopefully we will do so in this Parliament and the next-at our total electoral system and make sure that that occurs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise to speak in this matter of public importance raised by Senator Puplick today, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The systematic attempts of the Australian Labor Party to transfer the costs of its re-election campaign from its own coffers to the public purse, plundering the pockets of the Australian taxpayer.

Senator Puplick very neatly outlined for this chamber the ways in which this Government is sticking its hands into the till. That is probably the easiest way to put it. There is the cash register full of taxpayers' money, and in go the hands of the Executive to grab out what it can for the purpose of retaining government. It is not for the better government of this nation, not so that the children in the gallery will have a better education or a better health system, but primarily so that this Government will return to power. That is what it is all about; a systematic misuse of taxpayers' funds so that this Government can retain power. Power at all costs is what we are on about.

Senator Puplick outlined for us the ways in which this is happening. He referred to public funding, media free time and advertising; to a recent snout in the trough exercise, namely, the decision to give $20,500 more-$21,000 more-in stamp allowances to members of the lower House. I will return to that matter shortly. He referred to the use of glossy magazines to advertise what this Government is doing with Labor plastered all over it, not just the Federal Government but the Labor Government. Here is the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promising people this, promising them that; telling them that because of this Government they have got this, because of this Government they have got that. He gave some very good examples. I will be returning to those as well.

Senator Puplick raised the further example of the `aNiMaLS'-the National Media Liaison Service-which was so neatly used by Senator Walsh to misrepresent me this afternoon in this chamber. Perhaps I will return to that matter as well. But the taxpayers are paying for some public servants to sit around, monitor all the media programs and, as quickly as they can, rush round and put the Government's view to the Press Gallery, rush around and draw to the attention of members of the Government-not the Executive, but members of the government Party-things that they think will be useful to denigrate the Opposition; to denigrate the other side of the Parliament. That is what the `aNiMaLS' are being used for. The taxpayers are paying the bill.

That is what is happening, Mr Acting Deputy President-no more, no less. Now, of course, the situation is perpetuated. The House of Representatives has this somewhat unlimited postal allowance-$30,000 worth. As the honourable member for Adelaide, Mr Pratt, says, his franking machine will suffer meltdown if he puts that many letters through it. The corollary of that is a requirement for unlimited stationery for members of the Government to peddle out into the community their views as to why they should be elected.

Senator Puplick went on to refer to telemarketing, and the Government paying telephone bills. The Labor Party is using this method quite shrewdly-perhaps we can regard that as a compliment-to ensure that it is re-elected. It is nothing more, nothing less than that: `Here we are-we will use taxpayers' funds to ensure that we are re-elected. We will not go out to win people over and show them that we ought to be re-elected so they will give us some money and we will do a good job and win the election; not that at all. We are the Government; let us stick our hands in the taxpayers' pockets. Rip the money out of there and get ourselves re-elected and that is what it is about'. Further examples of that were raised.

There are two matters I want to concentrate on-namely, the stamp allowance and the Labor Party's use of Government advertising money to produce glossy magazines to tell all and sundry what the Government is doing. I want to address some remarks made by previous speakers in this debate. I firstly want to deal with the contribution of Senator Ray. Senator Ray did not think there was any substance in this matter of public importance, that nothing needed to be said, and on that basis he thought he could extend his argument into other boring matters not related to this at all--

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not say anything of the sort.

—If I were in his position I would not want to come in here and have to defend the Government sticking its hands in the till either. I would use every opportunity to talk about anything other than my hands being in the till, so I can understand why he avoided the substance of the matter being raised by Senator Puplick. Everybody else can understand it too. Anybody who was listening would have understood. This matter of public importance is about the Government using Government money to fund its re-election campaign. That is what it is about-it is not about the Opposition at all-and Senator Ray did not appropriately address himself to the substance of that.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what he did say. He said, `Why would we want to do this? We have no fear of defeat'. Of course one only has to look at the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, to see the ego that is attached there. One wonders how one human could have an ego that size; nonetheless, he does, and now Senator Ray provides us with evidence that he has the same sort of ego: `Here we are. We are invincible. No one can get rid of us'. Well, we have news for them. The Australian taxpayer will get rid of this Government at the next election. I am quite sure of that. One of the reasons they will do that is that they do not like an Executive putting its hands in the till. Australians are basically fair and they do not approve of misuse of taxpayers' funds. That is why this Government will be chucked out-because it is engaging in a systematic attempt to transfer the costs of its re-election campaign from its own coffers into the taxpayers' and the taxpayers will not wear it.

Senator Ray should understand that but by saying he has no fear of defeat-that Labor has no fear of defeat-he of course draws attention to another very important reason why this Government will be chucked out at the next election, and that is that it is so overconfident that it has got out of touch. It does not care what the Opposition has to say; it does not care what the man in the street has to say; it does not even care what its grassroots members have to say. This has become government no longer by the Labor Party sticking to its platform, and no longer, really, by Caucus. It is government by a Labor Executive and nothing more. We see in the papers over the last couple of days examples of where Mr Hawke, the Prime Minister, makes an announcement in the press as to what is going to happen. We are all told that at the Caucus meeting the Labor members, like good little lap-dogs, will go along with what the Prime Minister and the Executive say. It is not the Caucus deciding what will be done; it is the Labor Executive deciding what will be done. That is why the Government is out of touch. I thank Senator Ray for his contribution, for admitting how overconfident his Government is and highlighting in that respect exactly why it will be chucked out at the next election.

Senator Ray then went on to outline some reasons why he thought members of the Government could be overconfident. None of them related to the good job they were doing, and I can understand that. If I were on the Government side I would not want to come into this chamber and say they were doing a good job when in my heart of hearts I knew the country was going down the tube, as indicated by Senator Hill's question today. We are third on the list of international debtors, and above some South American countries. We have gone down the Argentinean road, and way beyond. Senator Ray says that he wants to defend the democratic process and go to the serious issues. Well, let us go to them. Let us go to the question of whether we want government by Executive or by Parliament. Let us do that by virtue of the stamp issue. Let us just look at what should have happened there. Ministers ought to say whether they have an interest in the Government being returned. If we are going to have the country run by the Executive, by ministerial letter, then why do we not just install fax machines around the country and let them do what they like? The stupidity of that suggestion indicates why we do not do it and why this Government should not be allowed to get away with it, constantly putting its snout in the trough.

A former Government member at least understood. I have raised this matter before but I will raise it again. SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It must seem very strange to the taxpayers who are listening to this debate that 34 people in Australia who sit on the other side of the Parliament are perpetrating the farce that somehow, with the problems confronting Australia, this is the biggest issue on which we should be concentrating our attention. We should not be talking about industrial relations because those opposite do not have a policy; they are too confused. We should not be talking about the economy because in all that wonderful list of policies there is no economic policy. We should not be talking about health because they are turning on their own committee members who dare to agree with the Government. We should not be talking about tax because that policy is no longer operative. So the Opposition says, `We will try to divert attention back to the glories of the past, to when we won a campaign about the Australia Card, when we won a campaign about the referendum. We do not have to be for anything then. Here is something we can just be opposed to'.

SPEECH.PARA: The concrete parts of the democratic issues before us were not referred to at all by Senator Vanstone, I regret to say. I want to concentrate my contribution on two things. The poor people listening who are taxpayers must have been very confused. They would have thought-listening to Senator Puplick and Senator Vanstone they would have been misled on this matter-that the stamps that are going to be provided from public funds somehow rather magically go only to the Labor Party, whereas of course everybody knows they go equally to all the parties. It is a legitimate matter of public debate whether or not those initiatives ought to be taken. It is not legitimate to pretend that somehow or other it is a peculiarly Labor Party initiative.

There are two big issues of democracy in this matter of public funding and disclosure. One is the question of the response to the report of the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters on election advertising and the provision of free time and the second is about disclosure. Although I think the people who have prepared this report, Who pays the piper calls the tune, have raised some important issues, I do not agree with what they have proposed. They have raised the issue. It is very important. It ought to be addressed and I intend to do that-it is a pity nobody else has-but I do not agree with their conclusion.

I think that in Australia we have to be more conscious of the fact-and the Opposition chooses to ignore it because it does not suit them-that the Recruit scandal of Japan is only one step away from Australia. In my view, and I think there is no-one in this Senate more able to accurately assess this matter, the next election will cost the major parties in Australia approximately $50m. Once expenditure starts to get to that level the fundraising pressures upon the political parties are enormous.

I agree with Mr Tony Eggleton, the Federal Director of the Liberal Party: I do not believe there is corruption in Australian politics despite that enormous pressure. I think we are lucky, and Tony Eggleton is one of the people who get credit for that. I regard him as an honest man. But we have to stop the corruption before it happens and not have the problem, as they do in other countries, of rooting it out afterwards. That is why the Committee has done us a favour by raising the profile of that particular matter, although I do not agree with its solution. There is enormous pressure on political parties when the level of political electoral funding gets to that height. It is easy for parties supported, or who think that they are going to be supported, by the wealthy people to ignore this issue and pretend that Australia is unique. Every country confronted by this problem has had to face up to the fact that the potential for corruption exists. There are people like Mr Fitzgerald who have found exactly the problem that can arise when these excesses occur.

My view is that what is wrong with the Committee's proposal is that it discriminates between political parties and others. I do not believe we can have a situation where electoral advertising is free to political parties and banned for everybody else. My view is that it should be banned altogether. There should be no electoral advertising. There is all sorts of hysterical nonsense being talked about how this is antidemocratic. There is no democratic right to buy elections. There is no democracy in measuring arguments by their quantity rather than their quality. That is what the existing situation means. It means that the people with the most money get the most say. That is not democracy; that is in fact plutocracy, and it is a very standard feature of democracies in the Western world that paid political advertising is not permitted. There is no paid political advertising in Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, France, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland or the United Kingdom-all legitimate democracies.

I sometimes wonder why the Liberal Party does not kick Margaret Thatcher out of the Liberal Democratic Union or whatever it is they are in. Countries in that Union have no paid political advertising, they have public funding of political parties, they have first past the post voting, they do not have any states. It must be terribly antidemocratic but they still meet with her because, of course, Britain is a very proud democracy and it does not allow parties to have their say measured by the amount of money that they can raise, and nor should it.

The existing system favours both the major parties and all the powerful interest groups, against minority groups, against minor political parties, against single issue groups which do not have the support of the great and the powerful. We should equalise that matter and there should be no political advertising. As I have said, it is not uncommon in Western democracies. For example, in the majority there is none and in those few where there is some, such as Canada, there is no political advertising in the last 28 days. In the United States, of course, they get a de facto subsidy because the television channels are in fact required to provide at a lower price.

I do believe that there needs to be a change. I do not support the Committee's proposal. I think election advertising should be banned and I think there should be a reduction in public funding to political parties as a consequence. The consequences of that would be that we would have to campaign for elections through the news programs, through current affairs, through talk-back radio, through getting out and talking to the electors, and I support doing those things.

The other side of the coin, which I support, and which is the other side of dealing with the looming problem of the enormous cost of elections, is disclosure. What we need to ask is: Why will not the Liberal Party support disclosure? We know why the National Party of Australia will not support it; it has been exposed in Queensland and in New South Wales. Is it that the members of the Liberal Party are just wimps, being run by the National Party again, or have they got something to hide?

There are some things about funding of elections in Australia in recent times that have not come out, and it is time they did. For example, in the 1987 election the biggest company in Australia had a debate at its board meeting about donations to political parties. The question of whether it should donate to both parties was raised. This is, of course, the board of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. What did it decide? It decided to donate $125,000 to the Liberal Party and nothing to anybody else. That is why the Liberal Party does not want disclosure; it does not want people to find out about that. That has not yet been disclosed. That is why it does not want public funding. It wants that sort of special advantage over everybody else-not just over us in the Labor Party, although particularly us-because it got $125,000 and we got nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know?

—I know because a disaffected person, who was there and who thought it was an outrage, rang me. If anybody wants to deny it, let them deny it. My view is that donations to all political parties should be disclosed. I have always supported that; I continue to support it. There should have been the capacity for spot checks-random audits of political parties. I am proud to say that we invited the Australian Electoral Commission to conduct a random audit of the Labor Party. SPEECH.PARA: We have in Australia a situation, defended by the Liberal and National parties, where big and powerful companies can try to buy the election. What they are saying is, `The old system used to give us an advantage; we used to get $125,000 while others got nothing'. They want to protect that. That can be repeated in the board rooms all around Australia. That is what they are trying to defend-the benefits of the wealthy. I do not want only the Labor Party to get it; I do not want anybody to have the advantage. I believe there should be none of that election advertising and that there should be a full disclosure of donations made.

We have had situations in the past where queries have been raised about decisions that have been made by governments, and whether they bore any relationship to donations. It is a matter I will come back to in the Parliament. I wish I had time to discuss it now. I am not making any accusations of corruption because I believe Australia has been very lucky. But we should not push our luck too far. We should set up a system that makes the political process transparent and equal. It is not a democratic system, it is not the ultimate in democracy, if we have a situation in which some people can get hundreds of thousands of dollars-both major parties are in this category-and spend several million dollars on their campaign but others can spend nothing. It is not an egalitarian society when some powerful interest groups can run very big election advertising campaigns but the opposing group has no funds to compete. That is not an election which expresses the equal voice of the people. It is not people being able to consider arguments on their merits. I have great problems with the existing system, significantly better as it is than anything that has gone before it, because we still have the situation where the capacity of people to successfully compete in elections is measured by the quantity of the argument, not the quality.

Of course I do not underestimate the voters. They can see through the most transparent of lies that are sometimes told in advertising. Sometimes the person with the most money does not win. That is to the great credit of the Australian people and there is the capacity for alternative views to be developed. We need to remove the hurdles from the people who do not have the support of the wealthy, who do not have the unfair advantage, and say, `This election ought to be an equal contest between people who have the capacity to put forward ideas and to compete equally to win the support of the Australian public for those ideas'. It is sad that we have to divert the resources of the Parliament that have been dealing with important legislation to pursue this irrelevant tangent that Senator Puplick has tried to beat up as a smokescreen to cover inadequacy in other areas and to cover the desire to maintain an unfair advantage in another.

I welcome the fact that this debate has given me the opportunity, which I was going to take in another forum to put before the people of Australia, to put forward my views from my experience in election campaigning about how election campaigns ought to be restructured and financed in the hope that we can get an equal go in election campaigns in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick and Senator Vanstone have already outlined in considerable detail the examples of this quite immoral rape of the public purse through Labor's public funding policy and its unconscionable proposal to increase the postage allowance for members of the House of Representatives by more than threefold, an action which, on advice we have received, is illegal. We will fight that matter if our legal opinions are confirmed; we will fight that matter in the High Court because illegality is the hallmark of the Government in the use of public funds and we will not allow it to continue.

The Government's provision of unlimited stationery to members of the House of Representatives and the postage allowance are for one purpose alone; that is, to give publicly funded resources of tens of thousands of dollars-$30,000-to each marginal Labor member of the House of Representatives, to flood his or her electorate with political propaganda in the run-up to the next election. That is the only reason these changes are being proposed. I mention also Labor's grand telemarketing schemes and its massive expenditure on advertising campaigns which Senator Puplick and Senator Vanstone have so ably demonstrated. The sole objective of those advertising campaigns is to promote the Labor Party and its so-called leading lights. We have seen the development to a high art form of scurrilous political propaganda through the National Media Liaison Service-the Labor Party's new thought police; Australia's Goebbels machine of the 1980s. TALK.START.PARA: —Before I get to the motivation behind Senator Puplick's matter of public importance, I want to place very clearly on the record my support of the principle of the public funding of election campaigns. TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare is a very valuable and useful report. I congratulate the members of the Committee and its research staff. The whole history of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare has been interesting. It will be recalled that when the Committee was first established-Senator Georges was its initial chairman-some criticism was made about the establishment of the Committee and what its impact might be in a large number of areas.

SPEECH.PARA: So far, the Committee has demonstrated that it has done extremely valuable work in all areas. As a result of its investigation of the kangaroo industry substantial improvements have been made in the way that trade is monitored and regulated. In relation to its comments on the investigation of live sheep exports, again there have been improvements. It will be interesting to know, when a final analysis is made of the current problems we are having with live sheep exports to the Middle East, whether following the Senate Committee's recommendations in toto might not have been the way to go. The Committee's report on the keeping of cetacea in captivity effectively laid to rest a large part of the debate about the inappropriateness of keeping cetacea in captivity. I am glad to see that in New South Wales, in particular, steps have been taken, acting on the basis of the Senate Committee's work and advice, to try to reduce the number of cetacea kept in captivity.

Last night when this report was tabled, Senator Brownhill drew attention to the fact that the impact that the Committee has had in its preliminary work, even before its report came down, was very much related to cleaning up the acts of the various universities and research schools around the place. In fact, they were required to take proper notice of some of the criticisms being made externally of their work and their operation, and the increasing role of ethics committees and of public scrutiny of the universities in relation to their use of animals for experimental purposes has led to substantial improvements being made all round.

I know that Senator Calvert in his remarks last night also drew attention to the fact that the Committee will be going on to investigate the operation of the racing industry, the treatment of racehorses and the treatment of greyhounds. Although I no longer have a direct interest in the matter, perhaps I should declare myself as a person who has had a long and very interesting association with the greyhound racing industry over many years and I look forward to the recommendations which that Committee may come up with. If they would like to call me I would be more than happy to tell them what effect it has on a racing greyhound if somebody slips him half a pound of butter half an hour before the race starts. Nevertheless, the way in which the animals are actually treated is an important issue to be addressed by the Committee.

The Committee makes a number of recommendations which are extremely important. It recommends, for example, an increase in the publication of data about animal experimentation and the use of animals in experiments in Australia. The British Home Office has had enormous success over many years in keeping and publishing effective records about the use of animals in experiments. Those records have, I think, by and large allayed a large number of fears expressed by animal welfare groups in the United Kingdom. I am delighted to see the recommendation for the Draize test to be banned in Australia. It is an appalling test which effectively amounts to this: take a large number of white rabbits, put them into machines which collar their heads, tilt their heads upwards, pin back their eyelids and drop substances into their eyelids until enough of them go blind to demonstrate whether or not the products, which are nearly exclusively cosmetic products-shampoos, perfumes and things of that nature-are sufficiently acceptable to be put on the market. With the rise of genetic engineering and the capacity to undertake cell tests, the Draize test is certainly no longer necessary and I am glad to see the recommendation for its abolition.

Similarly, there is a recommendation for the ban of the classical LD50 test. If anybody should ask, `What is an LD50 test?', LD means lethal dose. What dose does one have to give animals to get to the stage where 50 per cent of them die? Again, the capacity to replace that test certainly exists technically, and the Committee recommends that a classical LD50 test be prohibited but that the Minister be able to approve acute toxicity tests, which of course continue to be necessary for the proper testing of pharmaceutical products, veterinary products and medical products which at this stage do not have appropriate non-animal alternatives.

The Committee makes three recommendations in regard to a body called the Australian Council for the Care of Animals in Research and Teaching: firstly, that ACCART plays a role in drawing up appropriate guidelines and standard operating procedures for the capture of wildlife and their housing, nutrition and management in captivity; secondly, that it undertakes a study to determine the most effective means for production planning of laboratory animals in terms of minimising excess production; and, thirdly, that ACCART prepares guidelines on procedures and practices in relation to animal experimentation to supplement the code of practice. Here I declare a very clear personal interest in the matter. ACCART is a body sponsored by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the National Health and Medical Research Council. It has some 13 members on its executive and they are drawn predominantly from the scientific and technical and university community, from the CSIRO, from departments of primary industry around the States, and from the National Health and Medical Research Council. However, ACCART has two lay members who were invited to join that body to provide some external input to the work of ACCART and they comprise a distinguished lawyer from Melbourne and me. So I have been directly involved as one of the two lay members of the Australian Council for the Care of Animals in Research and Teaching, which has made a submission to this particular Senate inquiry and which has now published a newsletter and a series of monographs is under way which deal with questions about animal housing, about testing procedures, about the physiology and biology of experimental animals and about the practices which ought to be undertaken as far as laboratory animals and their care is concerned.

Indeed, in August 1987, I was able to give an address to the annual general meeting of the Australian Society of Laboratory Animal Scientists in Sydney under the heading, The Dilemma of Animals, Real and Political, in which I spent some time basically putting forward the proposition that it is necessary for those who are engaged in scientific activity such as this to accept as a fact of life the increasing public scrutiny of what it is that they are doing and to accept that as a positive element, not a threat, not a negative element but a positive element which will only increase in the years ahead.

It remains absolutely necessary for the public health purposes of Australia to continue to use animals in medical and veterinary experiments. There is no alternative for their total removal available at this stage. But cruelty to those animals must be minimised, the number of animals must be minimised, and the alternatives to the use of animals must be more appropriately pursued. I believe that this Committee report makes a significant contribution to advancing the debate in that regard. I hope it will be seriously read and studied by honourable senators and by others who are concerned with this particular matter, and, indeed, by members of the wider community. I conclude my remarks as I began, by congratulating the members of the Senate, their staff and researchers for the production of this excellent report.
