SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, when, as the Committee Chairman, I presented this report to the Senate on 16 August, I did not have the opportunity to present my tabling statement. Accordingly, I now seek leave to have that statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The report brings to a conclusion an inquiry that was begun in 1986 during the 34th Parliament by our predecessor Committee, the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, under the Chairmanship of Senator Gordon McIntosh.
The other members of the former Committee were:
Senator Aulich
Senator Black
Senator Boswell
Senator Sir John Carrick and
Senator Hamer, who is also a member of the present Committee.
Senator Cook and the former Senator Wood are former members of the present Committee.

The terms of reference for the inquiry did not relate to arguments for or against visits by nuclear armed or powered warships. They took as their starting point the fact that the visits took place. The Committee conducted its inquiry accordingly. The focus was one of ensuring, given that the visits occur, that adequate arrangements were in place to protect the public and the environment.
It should be noted that no visits by nuclear powered warships have occurred since 1987.

The terms of reference referred to vessels in Australian ports and waters, and so the Committee did not consider planning in relation to accidents on the high seas. The Committee confined its inquiry to visits that occur in peacetime, recognising that different considerations and arrangements might apply to wartime visits.

The only nuclear powered vessels that have visited Australia are those of the United States Navy. The inquiry concentrated on these vessels, and to a lesser extent those of the Royal Navy-which has approval to visit. The Committee did not regard as relevant the design characteristics, safety record, and so forth of Soviet nuclear powered ships, as these ships do not visit Australia.
Similarly, the Committee saw no need to inquire into the risks relating to inter-continental ballistic missiles with nuclear warheads, as vessels carrying these weapons do not visit.

The terms of reference refer to `current' planning. Accordingly, for nuclear powered vessel visits, the Committee examined the history of planning and superseded plans only to the extent necessary to evaluate planning for ports that currently receive visits. These are Brisbane, Darwin, Hobart, Gage Roads off Fremantle, Cockburn Sound in Western Australia and Jervis Bay.
It should be noted that other ports, such as Adelaide, Melbourne or Sydney, do not receive nuclear powered ship visits and lack current plans.
The inquiry received 102 submissions, which have led to a 492-page report containing 39 recommendations.
It became apparent to the Committee during the course of its inquiry that there was a widespread lack of accurate information in the Australian community on the subject matter of the inquiry.

The restrictions imposed by official secrecy accounted to some extent for this. But there was much relevant information in the public domain in fragmentary form which many of those interested in the subject did not appear to be aware of.

Accordingly, the Committee considered that it would be useful to document extensively the sources of information available and on which it relied. This, in part, accounts for the length of the report and the fact that it contains over 1300 footnotes.
Structure of the Report

Although a visiting vessel might be both nuclear powered and nuclear armed, the Committee considered that greater clarity is achieved by assessing the reactor and weapon risks separately. Accordingly chapters 3 to 10 of the report deal with nuclear powered ships; chapters 11 to 13 deal with nuclear weapons. However, the Committee used the same methodology in assessing the two types of risks.
The Committee's Methodology

An assessment of the adequacy of current planning has to be centred around the basic question: are the procedures sufficient to cope with the risks of accidents? Identification of the risks is thus an essential starting point.

This involves assessing both the likelihood and consequences of various kinds of accidents. Much of the argument put to the Committee by those opposed to the present arrangements focused almost exclusively on the consequences of possible accidents. The Committee considered it essential to focus also on accident likelihood: there is little value in considering in detail the consequences of a possible accident whose likelihood can be shown to be very remote.
The Committee did not conduct its own risk assessment from scratch. Rather, it reviewed in detail the assessments made by ANSTO and the Department of Defence.

In its review, the Committee evaluated two broad aspects: the historical safety record of naval reactors and naval nuclear weapons; and the ways in which possible accident scenarios might occur. In addition, the Committee had some regard to the existence or absence of contingency planning in other countries receiving visits. This provided a guide to how other countries have assessed the risks involved.

The Committee considered that, despite the effect of military secrecy, enough information was available to enable it to make useful conclusions on both weapons and reactors. On some matters of detail not affecting its overall conclusions, the Committee has recommended that further information or assurances be obtained.
NPWs-Safety Record

The Committee noted that, despite extensive Australian monitoring conducted during each nuclear powered warship visit since 1976, no radiation release had ever been detected. The Committee noted the United States Navy's claim that it has accumulated over 3200 reactor-years of operation with its naval nuclear reactors `without a reactor accident or any radioactivity release having a significant environmental effect'. Of these 3200 reactor years, 2 have been in Australian ports (since 1980).
After a careful analysis of overseas and local research material, the Committee found no reason to doubt this United States Navy claim in the context of the type of visits made to Australia.

Some claims put to the Committee about the safety record of nuclear powered warships concerned accidents which could not occur during visits to Australian ports, such as the high seas accidents which involved the USS Thresher and the USS Scorpion; accidents to Soviet nuclear submarines (which do not visit Australia); or accidents during construction and maintenance at home-port dockyards. It was not necessary for the Committee to come to conclusions on the validity of these claims.

Those putting allegations to the Committee about United States naval reactor accidents seemed unaware that many specific allegations had been subject to detailed and persuasive rebuttal by the United States Navy. Also, there was often a failure to distinguish allegations which related to relatively trivial accidents involving discharge of wastes having minimal radioactive content, from more serious accidents.
NPWs-Possible Accidents Scenarios

It is conventional in accident contingency planning to establish a scenario that the plan is likely to have to cater for. The characteristics of this so-called `reference accident' provide the basis for planning.

A key factor in the Committee's examination of a reference accident is the knowledge that the reactors on visiting warships are within a containment structure. This is designed to allow, at most, only a slow and limited escape of radioactive materials to the environment should there be a serious accident-that is, a core melt-down accident.

Current Australian planning is based on an accident scenario in which the containment is effective; to use the jargon with which Committee members had to become familiar, the reference accident is a contained core melt-down. Many submissions argued that an uncontained accident should be used instead-that is, a more serious accident whose consequences would be spread over a significantly wider area.

In the light of these arguments, the Committee evaluated the assessment made by ANSTO and the Department of Defence which led them to adopt a contained rather than an uncontained accident as the reference accident.
The details of this evaluation are set out in chapter 7 of the Committee's report. The analysis by ANSTO and Defence appeared to the Committee to have been thorough and detailed.

Constraints had been placed on the analysis due to lack of scientific certainty on some matters. Military secrecy resulted in a lack of information on others. However, the evidence supplied to the Committee indicated that on these matters safety-oriented assumptions had been made. Any inaccuracies created would be in the direction of over-stating the risk.

The Committee found no reason, after a careful and thorough analysis, to reject the use of the contained accident as the basis of planning. It evaluated the adequacy of current contingency plans on this basis.
NPWs-Overseas Planning
The Committee found that accident planning overseas was based on either something similar to the reference accident used by Australian planners or on a less serious accident.
NPWs-Recommendations Relating to Current Plans
By way of background to the Committee's recommendations, I draw the Senate's attention to some of the arrangements under which nuclear powered warships currently enter Australian ports:
- visits will not be for fuel handling or reactor repairs;
- vessel movements are restricted to daylight hours and conditions of good visibility;
- navigational controls on other shipping applies while nuclear powered vessels are entering or leaving; and
- radiation monitoring is conducted throughout the visit by Australian authorities.

In general terms, the Committee found that the current plans displayed an attention to detail, both at the Commonwealth and at the State and Territory level. The Committee found no evidence that there was any lack of cooperation between the various governments that compromised the effectiveness of the plans.
However, the Committee did find a number of deficiencies and matters that it considered required further attention. Among the recommendations made to deal with these, were:

- that no further nuclear powered warship (NPW) visits be made to Macquarie Wharves, Hobart or to any other berth where a major public hospital is within the zone which might require evacuation in the event of a reactor accident;
- that no NPWs visit approved berths at Port Adelaide or Townsville until they have been reassessed to ensure that changed land use near the berths has not affected visit safety;
- that no NPWs visit approved anchorages in Hobart and one in Darwin, or approved berths in Darwin and Brisbane, until evacuation arrangements are documented and in place;
- that a mechanism be created to ensure that changes to land use around approved berths, which might affect safety, be automatically notified to the Defence Department; and
- that plans be clarified to ensure that no hazardous cargo is handled in the vicinity of a visiting nuclear powered warship.
In addition, detailed recommendations have been made for improvement or clarification of the plans with respect to provisions on matters such as:
- some aspects of the removal of a vessel, following an accident, from its berth or anchorage to a more remote location;
- post-accident radioactivity decontamination;
- the possible role of firefighters;
- post-accident provision of information to the media and the public; and
- keeping appropriate, accurate, long-term records of those exposed to contamination by radioactivity in the event of an accident.
NPWs-Dissemination of Information to the Public

The Committee recommended measures to improve public awareness of, and access to, the documents which set out the current contingency arrangements, in particular that NPWs not be permitted to visit ports where the relevant safety plans are not publicly available.

In relation to this last recommendation, I might point out, Mr President, that the plans which were not publicly available when the Committee commenced its inquiry have now been released. I like to think that this happy result is due in no small part to the Committee's activities.
Nuclear Armed Warships
Mr President, I turn now to the question of planning for visits by ships that may be nuclear armed.

At present, there are no specific conditions applying to visits of vessels which might or might not be nuclear armed. Such vessels are subject only to ordinary navigational constraints. There are no specific safety plans relating to such visits.

Successive Australian Governments have concluded that specific safety plans are not required to deal with visits by vessels that may be nuclear armed. This conclusion rests primarily on the assessment that the likelihood of a nuclear weapon accident on a visiting warship is remote. A subsidiary reason is the existence of general port safety plans for dealing with shipping and hazardous cargo accidents, such as chemical or petroleum accidents, which could be used to deal with many aspects of the response to a nuclear weapon accident.

The Committee considered whether specific plans were needed, and in doing so concentrated on the issue of potential accident likelihood, including mechanisms which would have to exist for accidents to occur.

The Committee found that the two most serious potential accident risks were: nuclear detonation; and an accident in which the plutonium in a weapon was converted into an aerosol form able to be inhaled. The latter might occur if the weapon was engulfed in a fire, or if the conventional high explosive which forms part of the weapon's trigger mechanism exploded. Less serious accidents were also considered.

The Committee noted that the United States had assured the Australian Government that any weapons that might be on board a vessel would be securely and safely stowed in an unarmed condition during visits. The Committee accepted this assurance. It noted that the absence of any handling of weapons during occasional port visits to host countries sharply reduces the likelihood of accidents.
The Committee also noted the safety features of ships' magazines, and the excellent safety record of these magazines when used to store conventional weapons.

The Committee found that United States nuclear weapons of more recent design have enhanced safety features compared with those designed in the 1950's and early 1960's. Although the older weapons are now being retired from deployment, the Committee based its conclusions on the risks relating to them, as well as the newer weapons.
NAWs-Safety Record

Many submissions alleged that the United States Navy had a very poor record on nuclear weapon safety. In considering this claim, the Committee noted that the United States Navy distinguishes nuclear weapon accidents from less serious incidents. The United States Navy has acknowledged that it has had 3 nuclear weapon accidents, the most recent in 1968. All involved the loss of intact weapons during operations, including flight operations, at sea-circumstances that are not relevant to those which arise during a vessel's visit to Australia. A careful check of overseas research material by the Committee gave it no reason to dispute the United States Navy's claimed record.

In addition to the three accidents, a large number of incidents-over 600 in the period 1965 to 1985-have been acknowledged. However, many of these incidents involved false alarms, dummy weapons used for training, and trivial events such as scratched paint or a bent fin on training weapon simulators or flat tyres on nuclear weapons carriers. It could be argued that the requirement to report such minor incidents indicates the tight procedures that surround nuclear weapons, rather than a poor safety record.

Moreover, very few of the 600 incidents could occur while weapons were in safe storage during a port visit, and those that could, for example, accidental flooding of a magazine, would not lead to a radiation hazard.

The Committee was referred to a number of unofficial lists that have been published over the years of alleged United States Navy nuclear accidents. A further list was published in June 1989, after the Committee's report had been finalised.

In the Committee's view, these lists have to be read critically for several reasons. They are based primarily on media reports of allegations, not all of which have been officially confirmed. They are generally not based on any definition of what constitutes a nuclear weapon accident. The lists tend to mix the potentially serious with the trivial. Moreover, they include incidents that did involve a nuclear weapons capable vessel, but which could not have posed a danger to any weapon that might have been on board.

The items in the lists have to be examined carefully to see what relevance they have to weapons held in secure storage during a port visit. Allegations relating to navies that do not visit Australia, or to accidents during weapons handling, maintenance, flight operations, and so forth, even if true, are not relevant to the risks faced during visits to Australia.

Overall, the Committee considered that the known accident and incident records for naval nuclear weapons did not demonstrate a risk of sufficient magnitude to warrant contingency planning for occasional port visits.

The argument was put to the Committee that the records might be incomplete, due to military secrecy. The Committee considered that it was unlikely that the accidents of most interest to it-that is, during port visits and involving either nuclear detonation or plutonium aerosolisation-could have been successfully concealed from public notice.
NAWs-Possible Accident Scenarios
The Committee found that the safety features in the design and storage of naval nuclear weapons are such that planning for the risk of accidental nuclear detonation is unnecessary.

Next, the Committee considered a wide range of accidents which could lead to plutonium dispersal from a weapon. However, after a lengthy analysis it could not find a credible scenario leading to such an accident: accident likelihood was sufficiently low that there was no need for contingency planning.

Other, less serious, accidents may have a greater likelihood. An example might be the sinking of a vessel with intact weapons on board. But accidents of this sort can be dealt with under the general port safety plans for maritime accidents. They do not require special contingency plans.
NAWs-Planning in other Countries
No national government overseas was identified during the inquiry which required specific nuclear weapon accident contingency plans for occasional visits by nuclear armed warships.
NAWs-Overall Conclusions

However, the Committee recommended that work by the Department of Defence, referred to in Parliament last September, to document possible procedures for responding to a nuclear weapon accident should continue, and that the document should be publicly available when it has been completed.

In addition, the Committee considered that the public interest would be assisted if information concerning current plans to deal with shipping and hazardous cargo accidents in ports was more widely available.

Accordingly, the Committee recommended that the Commonwealth Government confirm that the State and Northern Territory Governments have adequate plans to deal with shipping accidents involving hazardous cargoes in their ports.
The Committee believes that the Commonwealth should encourage the States and Northern Territory to make these plans public where this is not already the case.

The Committee has also recommended that no dry-docking of nuclear weapons capable vessels be permitted unless either the vessel has been de-ammunitioned outside Australia or it can be guaranteed that the level of safety is at least as high as that for vessels berthed alongside a wharf, as is the normal practice.
Concluding Remarks

Finally, Mr President, I would like to thank the other members of the present Committee for their diligence and persistence in bringing the inquiry to a successful conclusion, in particular for the many hours of careful consideration they gave to the final report.
I also wish to thank the staff and advisers of the Committee for their assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to take the opportunity to make a few comments about the report, as it has been tabled, and about the debate as it has unfolded following the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the visits to Australian ports by nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered vessels.

SPEECH.PARA: The media reports about this report were generally speaking very good, comprehensive and thorough in dealing with the subject matter of the report, but a couple of major media outlets were in error when they reported the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the question of nuclear-powered or nuclear-armed vessels coming into Australian ports. For example, on 17 August last, one major newspaper said that there were, in fact, no recommendations in the report dealing with nuclear weapons, and, of course, that is untrue.

As other members of the Committee in the chamber are aware, there are in fact three major recommendations in the report: recommendations Nos. 37, 38, and 39, which deal with the question of nuclear weapons on vessels which may be visiting Australian ports. In fact, one major newspaper not only said that the report had no recommendations about nuclear weapons but then in the very same article went on to quote one of the recommendations verbatim. So there was some confusion there. I think that the difficulty was that some of the journalists had trouble filing a copy on this particular report as it was tabled at a very awkward hour of the evening in relation to newspaper deadlines.

One television report also said the report contained no recommendations about nuclear weapons. The report probably intended to say that the Committee's report had nothing in it in regard to calling for specific plans about whether weapons were on board visiting ships in Australian ports. I would like to correct that. In fact, there are three recommendations in the report which deal with the question of nuclear weapons. There are quite good reasons why the Senate Standing Committee did not go down the road of recommending specific plans in relation to nuclear weapons accidents in respect of visiting warships. The first point to be borne in mind here is that after a very exhaustive and thorough investigation the Standing Committee could not find any other country which actually had specific plans for weapons accidents during casual port visits of the sort that occur at Australian ports.

The second factor that we looked at in this regard was that the United States Navy, which is the principal force visiting our ports of course, has had no nuclear weapons accidents involving either detonation of a weapon or plutonium dispersal, two major forms of accident. None of those have occurred. The third factor engaging the Committee was that no credible scenarios were put forward by any witness who came before the Committee or in evidence to the Committee in which there could be a nuclear weapons accident in an Australian port. This was a matter which was not treated lightly. For example, there are three whole chapters in the report which deal with this question of nuclear weapons accidents. Chapters 11 to 13 outline a range of possible nuclear weapons accident scenarios. We looked at them comprehensively and in great detail. I must say that none of them stood up to examination. We looked at matters of fire, which might lead to plutonium dispersal; we looked at the possibility of ship collision in ports; we looked at the possibility of a reactor accident leading to nuclear weapons accident. None of these scenarios really stood up. After great analysis we could not come up with any credible scenario under which there could be a nuclear weapons accident in an Australian port.

One of the features of the Senate Standing Committee's report I believe is chapter 13, which is one of the most comprehensive analyses anywhere of the question of nuclear terrorism. I suggest that honourable senators when looking at the report make a point of looking at chapter 13 because there for the first time, I think, is a wide ranging and thorough analysis of this whole question of terrorism which might involve nuclear weapons. But, again, the Committee was not able to come up with any plausible scenario in an Australian context where terrorism could be seen to be at all likely.

While I was in my sick bed at home last week I happened to listen-much to my misfortune-to some of the debate that occurred last Wednesday. I heard the comments of Senator Sanders and Senator Vallentine and I thought that overall they were simply recycling the tired old arguments about the nuclear industry. They did not really advance the debate one iota with the sorts of comments that they made. For example, Senator Sanders kept on about totally hypothetical accident scenarios. He talked about the idea of fire creating a situation where plutonium could be dispersed. But clearly Senator Sanders had not read the report. He had not read the three chapters that deal with possible nuclear weapons accidents. The point that we make time and time again in that report is that we have to look at plausible causes of accidents and their risks. We cannot just look at consequences of accidents. We have to look at how they might occur and the actual risk of an accident's occurring. All Senator Sanders did, for example, was to talk about a fire and jump to a range of conclusions based on a fire. He did not say how it would occur or how likely it was. That is one of the things that have to be borne in mind in this whole debate about accidents, whether they be to reactors or to weapons. It is more important to look at the risk of an accident's occurring than just the consequences, which is one of the emotional ways of handling this very complex subject.

I would also like to point out that, as well as dealing with weapons accidents in great detail over three chapters and 110 pages, this report in total cites over 1,300 sources. It is a very thorough analysis indeed of nuclear ship visits of a casual nature to ports. Over 1,300 technical and other sources, both local and overseas, are cited in building up the report. As a result of that comprehensive detailing of the information that is available on this subject this report will be quite a valuable reference work.

I noticed very briefly also references last week to the 1975 collision between the USS John F. Kennedy and a vessel called the USS Belknap. For example, Senator Vallentine tried to use that collision to develop the argument that the United States would not tell us of an accident. I thought that was very interesting because I could not work out why the United States should have to tell other countries about such an accident anyway because it occurred many miles out to sea; in fact it was a high seas accident. There was no radiation leakage from that accident. I am not quite sure why that navy would have been required to tell other countries about that accident. Certainly Australia does not pretend to have jurisdiction over the high seas, and I am sure other countries do not either. The bottom line is that there was no radiation leak during that accident that has been documented.

Senator Vallentine also, in the context of talking about that accident, referred to a document called `Naval nuclear reactors'. I make the point again that there are a lot of irrelevancies brought forward in this debate about nuclear ships. For example, the collision that was talked about occurred at night. Senator Vallentine makes it very clear that it occurred at night. The fact is that nuclear-powered vessels coming into Australian ports are allowed to come in only in daylight hours. That is one of the conditions of entry. Nuclear-powered vessels can proceed into Australian ports only in daylight hours and when there is three-quarters of a mile visibility. So it is irrelevant to talk about night accidents in the context of this inquiry. Talk about accidents on the high seas is also irrelevant to this particular inquiry, which is about safety conditions relating to port visits. I noticed also that Senator Vallentine had a throwaway line in her speech about the Soviet navy but, of course, Soviet naval vessels are not invited to visit Australian ports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before this report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade was tabled I expected that when I rose to speak on it I would proceed directly to kick the tripe out of my fellow Committee members. However, I feel a more pressing obligation to refer first to Mr Beazley's churlish and premature reaction to the Committee's report-a reaction apparently driven more by resentment that a Senate committee had interfered in his principality of defence than by even a cursory reading of the actual recommendations in the report. As Senator Teague pointed out last week, the recommendations are not onerous. He suggested that a couple of months would be needed to implement them. I suggest a wet weekend would do. But at least the Committee members put in the time to consider the many difficult and complex issues associated with naval nuclear reactors and nuclear weapons. For political reasons the Committee applied a rubber stamp to the existing plans. But although I believe that Mr Beazley is quite well informed on the equipment that his forces deploy, I doubt that he knows very much about naval nuclear reactors or nuclear weapons. His American friends are unlikely to tell a Minister of a socialist government anything of substance. I also have good reason to doubt that he cares much about protecting the Australian public from nuclear accidents.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one point that I should like to clarify about my dissent from the majority report. The Chairman of the Committee answered a press question by saying politely that he thought I had my own agenda, or words to that effect. It is true that I believe there are strong moral and practical reasons for excluding nuclear warships that are not related to accident safety, but, like the majority of the 102 submissions, in my dissent I address the terms of reference and the evidence or, one might well say, the lack of evidence. The Committee's unstated assumptions about its safety assessment were that a serious contaminating nuclear accident was unaccept- able and that Australia had independently to assess the accident risks to its citizens. Unfortunately, this task was beyond its competence.

The existing port safety plans are directed at visiting warships powered by naval nuclear reactors. These are all United States warships. Logically, the Committee wrote to the United States (US) Ambassador for information and got a brush-off. Two more letters asking about US safety plans went unanswered. Finally, 18 months later, the US Naval Attache at the Embassy informed not the Committee but the Department of Defence that no special safety plans were necessary. He also said that the US Navy would not assist in the preparation of safety plans, nor would it comment on plans developed without its assistance. So the official US opinion on Australian safety plans is that they are not necessary: all the monitoring and the contingency planning is a waste of time and, presumably, so is the work of the Committee. Although the inquiry was well advanced the Committee could have given up at this point. I take the fact that it did not to be a tacit acknowledgment that it could not place the safety of Australian citizens in the hands of a foreign power.

The United Kingdom (UK) authorities do think that safety plans for occasional visits of nuclear-powered warships are necessary and they provided the Committee with a copy of the publicly available Port of Liverpool safety plan. However, they would not, or could not, because of US licensing arrangements, release a document with some background information on naval nuclear reactors. This document is usually available to friendly institutions and is entitled, excitingly, `BR3019'. I believe that the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) holds a copy but the Committee was not allowed to see it. Obviously, the Department of Defence and ANSTO have a special alliance relationship with these foreign powers, but the Senate, representing the people of Australia, does not. We have no naval nuclear reactors of our own. The larger of the two research reactors at Lucas Heights has some similarities to warship reactors but has many differences that we are aware of, and perhaps more that we know nothing of. The fact is that the details of these naval reactors are the subject of strict military secrecy.

It is impossible to overstate the importance of military secrecy to the Committee's whole inquiry. Military secrecy not only serves to hide information from potential enemies; just as often it is used to conceal some of the more alarming potentials of military weapons from timid civilians. The stories surrounding the one megaton bomb dropped off the USS Ticonderoga illustrates the way in which the military hides and distorts the truth. The US Navy hides information about its nuclear reactors from all of us, especially Senate committees. It appears that it lies about them, too. In the Neptune 3 papers Arkin and Handler argue that Admiral Rickover lied to the US Congress about a reactor accident on the nuclear submarine USS Guardfish.

I cannot discuss today the way in which the report misuses the civil reactor accident record; the way in which numbers like one in 104 reactor years creep into the safety assessment; or the way in which the Committee discounts the demonstrated inevitability of human error. I refer interested parties to my dissenting report. None of the Committee's sources, nor all of them together, provided a sufficient information base for the most rudimentary independent safety assessment. I find the hypothetical contained reference accident to be an arbitrary basis for accident planning. Accidents do not confine themselves to the quiet fizzle of the reference accident. They are bizarre and unpredictable by nature. Everyone agrees that the total inventory of fission products in the core of a naval reactor would make a very dangerous and unacceptable mess if it were to get out. The Committee claims to know that it cannot get out and discounts the several types of uncontained accident, even though the UK Liverpool plan makes some provision for an uncontained accident. Speaking of uncontained accidents, I should remind Senator Hamer that the Committee could not totally discount the melt-through accident referred to in Senator Vallentine's submission.

The Committee has erected a paper screen of independent responsible action behind which it has meekly accepted the assurances of our principal ally that nothing bad will happen. The report's discussion of nuclear weapons accident risks used the same badly flawed methodology as the reactor argument. The Committee required a rattling good yarn as an accident scenario before it would even consider the consequences of a nuclear weapons accident. The Committee found most suggested accidents lacked the literary qualities it was looking for, including the detailed analysis of the effects of a plutonium contamination accident presented by Professor Jackson-Davis. I agree with Senator Hamer that his story may have been a bit weak on the details of exactly how the plutonium could be distributed, but we know that every visiting naval nuclear weapon is assembled with its explosive detonator. Even in the cases where it is a very stable explosive-or IHE-it is still capable of detonation in an accident, and we have evidence that a full explosion of the detonator can widely distribute the plutonium core as a respirable aerosol.

Professor Davis evaluated the variables associated with the distribution of five kilograms of plutonium, or the contents of one weapon, over Sydney and predicted a maximum of about 11,000 casualties from plutonium induced cancers. Even if these figures are an over- estimate and it would be only 1,100, we are talking only about one nuclear device. All nuclear capable ships carry more than one weapon and United States Navy aircraft carriers carry about 100. There are eight conventionally powered United States aircraft carriers that could enter any Australian port and aircraft carriers have had some serious and instructive accidents, which I cannot go into now.

The accident aboard the USS Iowa was mentioned last week. I agree with Senator Hamer that there is a difference between naval operations and peacetime port visits, but the fact remains that the weapons are carried into our ports and, as I observed in my dissent, these ships are not festooned with safety systems because they are safe but because they are dangerous. Safety systems fail and human folly can always circumvent them. How many serious contaminating accidents can Australia afford? The answer is none. We cannot put these ships in the heart of our port cities and rely upon fallible human design and engineering to protect us from disaster, especially when there is no good reason for them to be there in the first place. Not only would a serious nuclear weapon contamination accident lead to many human fatalities but also it could render a large part of a city uninhabitable. The half-life of plutonium 239 is 24,000 years.

Compared with this, politicians, with a half-life of about three years, are like summer insects. But Chernobyl will be remembered while human history endures and in a footnote will be the name of the Ukrainian Minister for Electrification who said that there would be less than one accident in ten thousand years of reactor operation. The members of the Committee have a similar hope of immortality in a footnote to the accident that killed an Australian city.

Honourable senators will remember the risk assessment by Defence Minister Beazley during the bicentennial warship visits. `There will be no accidents' he said. This was a gamble that paid off. There would have been a lot of egg dripping from the Beazley visage if it had not. However, imagine my surprise when soon after this statement was made I discovered that there was a draft safety plan for nuclear weapons accidents that had been prepared by the Visiting Ships Panel Nuclear (VSP[N]) within the Department of Defence. I actually saw this document on the desk of the head of Queensland Emergency Services. When the Committee asked Mr Beazley to see this plan the Minister refused-something that I still find amazing. I think I could be described as generous if I described the Minister's attitude towards the Committee as one of disdain. However, sight unseen, this accident plan had a major influence on the report. If honourable senators read the argument in the report on nuclear weapons accidents they will notice that it minimises the risk of a weapons accident. Yet right at the end, in chapter 11, paragraphs 115-117, there is a sudden change of heart and it is recommended that the VSP(N) plan be completed.

These paragraphs were added late in the preparation of the report but the sudden reversal still puzzled me until quite recently when I realised that it would have no real effect on the status quo. We have a pretend nuclear reactor plan, why not have a pretend weapons plan as well? Finally, the Committee's impressive list of safety promoting recommendations will not change anything; they are embroidery on the edges of a safety net with a giant hole in the middle. The only way to be truly safe is to keep these ships out of our harbours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, how could I not stand, having heard that speech? I really came in to speak about something else but Senator Dunn has provoked me into rising for a couple of moments because she made two references which I thought were compelling in their illogical presentation. The first related to Senator Vallentine's comments to the Committee. With the indulgence of the Senate, I will read from page 196 in chapter 7 of the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade which details what Senator Vallentine told the Committee. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vallentine told the Committee that, according to a 1973 United States Navy reactor disaster control plan, the `Navy found that the melt-down could go right down through the ship spilling hot radioactive materials to the bottom of the harbour . . .'. When the Committee tried to obtain a copy of the plan, it became clear that Senator Vallentine had not seen the plan she purported to quote from. She in fact was quoting from a booklet authored by a New York peace activist. It would seem that this author had not seen the plan either but was relying on an account in a Honolulu newspaper. The journalist who wrote this account did not purport to have seen the plan, but had interviewed one of its authors. The statement about the melt through is not presented in this account as part of the plan, but as the view of the interviewee, a former shift supervisor in the radiological controls section at Pearl Harbour naval base. The knowledge of reactor design possessed by the interviewee is not stated. The Committee did not regard it as prudent to rely on this source.

Senator Vallentine quoted that document as irrefutable evidence that if there were a meltdown of the nuclear reactor it would melt a hole through the bottom of the ship and the radioactive material would then plunge to the seabed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would it stop? Wouldn't it go right through to China?

—It may well have done. Senator Vallentine presented that as the truth, at first hand, without qualification and without caveat. Can we really wonder why these people are not taken seriously? I am reminded of the inquiry that I found myself involved in with respect to the Kakadu National Park. We were told by some crazy fringe lunatic group that mussels south of Ranger mine were infected by radium. Having tested the quality and the quantity of radium in these mussels that the Aboriginal community were eating with great gusto as a new-found diet, I inquired of the level of radium in mussels found north of the mine. In other words, was the mine discharging the radium? Surprise, surprise, we discovered that the readings were exactly the same. It was simply a background count that would have been found in the buffaloes or mussels or any other living species in Kakadu National Park because of the uranium province in the area. Yet we were given this propaganda by this crazy group that had frightened the Aboriginal community white with fear.

SPEECH.PARA: Then they went on to tell us that ponds one, two, three and four were potentially able to leak. When I inquired how, I was told it was because the buffaloes would break down the walls of the ponds. Anybody who has seen these ponds knows that at the top of the walls, on the outer rim, the edges will carry semitrailer trucks running in opposite directions. They have been engineered to last a thousand years at worst risk scenario. The buffaloes in Kakadu National Park were going to break down these ponds! That is the sort of evidence that we were given on the Committee, under oath, in front of the media, who faithfully and slavishly and lazily reported it. Perhaps that is the greatest sin of these people.

The sad thing is that this radical peace group totally discredits the reasonable and decent people who purport to put forward a respectable point of view-one with which I entirely disagree but at least it is respectable. These people try to prop up their prejudices and their ideological bents by distortions and falsehoods and untruths. They seek to create hysteria; they seek to create a level of emotion, because without the emotion and the hysteria and the hype and the fear their arguments fail. Their facts will not stand up to close analytical scrutiny. Of course, with these people the truth is always the first casualty, and it is invariably discharged with reckless abandon. Sadly, and I do not say this about all the media, so often we find the media blindly aiding and abetting these people because of the very laziness of the journalists who unquestioningly are prepared to report these distortions as the truth because they are good beat-ups, because they are good headlines, because they are so outrageous and extravagant in their claims.

Perhaps the most indicting element of the hysteria and the dishonesty presented by these people is the effect upon the community. The great unwashed, who have got no other way of knowing what the truth is except to read the newspapers, are presented with this stuff in pristine form as if it were the truth, without balance and without explanation. We have all these young people running around in a depressed state because they believe the end of the earth is going to arrive or we are going to have a nuclear winter or some other devastation is going to be visited upon us. This propaganda comes from people who live on hype, hysteria, dishonesty and untruths. These same people, who kick the Yanks at every turn and who are thunderingly silent when it comes to condemnation of the Soviets, will, at the offer of a bribe of an American cap, go aboard these ships for a free lunch to be photographed next to the captain so that they can take the cap, a baseball bat and a photograph back to their kids. They wonder why, when they are given a briefing by the admiral of the fleet or the captain of the carrier, they are not told anything.

I was on one ship and Senator Vallentine said to the admiral, `Are you carrying a tomahawk sea launch missile?'. Can one really imagine the admiral saying, `Well, I'll take you into my confidence, Senator Vallentine. The truth is, that parked down the back of this ship we've got a big heap of them?'. And they wonder why, when Minister Beazley, a representative of the American Embassy or any other authority appears before the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade they sit there mute. These people are going a long way to destroying the Senate committee system simply because nobody is prepared to disclose in-confidence information for fear that it will be repeated. There are certain senators who will not give a commitment that, if they are given in confidence information of a sensitive nature, they will not repeat it. Frankly, in some cases if they did give the undertaking I still would not believe them. The tragedy, as I say, is that it is damaging to the community, it is damaging to the fabric of society, and more particularly to wit, it is damaging to the parliamentary process and the committee system.

I heard in passing Senator Sanders, and again today, Senator Dunn, talking about the accident on the Iowa. What the hell has the accident on the Iowa got to do with the porting of nuclear ships? Do they think they fire off those guns in the harbours for a birthday celebration? Of course they do not. Those ships are designed so that if they have an accident of the nature of the accident on the Iowa-it was set off deliberately by a suicidal sailor-the fire cannot spread. I assume that Senator Dunn has been on board those ships either as a tourist or as someone seeking to learn the truth. She would know if she had gone into one of those turrets that it is quite impossible for any discharge to get outside the turret. Yet we have these absurd stories, these absurd untruths. As I say, what is the relevance of a ship discharging its cannons 40 or 50 miles out to sea-they will throw a shell 25 miles-to the porting of nuclear armed ships? I ask you!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike Senator Crichton-Browne, I will try to be logical and inoffensive. I begin by reminding the Senate that we are discussing the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which is entitled Visits to Australia by Nuclear Powered and Armed Vessels: Contingency planning for the accidental release of ionising radiation. I read the title because I believe that the title cites the first contradiction and illogicality of this report. The report, in its very title, accepts the possibility of accidents and the need for contingency planning. Yet it proceeds to argue, according to what Senator Maguire has said earlier, that there is no need for contingency planning and that there is little or no possibility of an accident.

SPEECH.PARA: I am trying to be logical. Senator Crichton-Browne, I note, is not listening to this logic. Frankly, I am disappointed that the Senate committee process has produced a report which is substantial, which represents literally thousands of hours of genuine application to task, and yet which is fundamentally so flawed in its logic. I believe that there is an inherent contradiction on the very cover of the report.

Senator Maguire very reasonably and very genuinely and sincerely argues his point and puts what is really a dichotomy to us. The dichotomy is: Are accidents possible or are they impossible? He has put in front of us the choice-this calamity is either not possible or is not likely. I do not believe that anybody here is really arguing that it is not possible. I do not thing that argument is one that we have to respond to. I think there is ample evidence and ample admission that clearly it is possible. So we are then confronted with the question of how likely it is. The answer may well be, very unlikely. In fact, the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has argued that it is extremely unlikely. But, in a letter to the Minister on 22 February 1989 I took up the question of the adequacy of the contingency plan specifically in relation to Brisbane, and I quote one paragraph from my letter:

Sir, I am bewildered also by the logic that relates the adequacy of a disaster contingency plan to the frequency of exposure to the potential danger. It is apparent that a plan to cater for potential danger has to be just as adequate whether the danger occurs once a year or once in five years.

Or once in fifty years. If there is any danger at all-and this report does not argue that there is no danger, it argues that it is not likely that that danger will lead to a calamity-quite obviously there is a need for contingency plans and quite obviously it is reasonable for people like Senator Vallentine and Senator Dunn, bearing in mind that the Australian Democrats have been saying this for 12 years, to be saying that we should start to ask whether it is sensible and sane to have these ships in our ports.

I refer honourable senators to the second sentence in this report, which says that the Committee takes as its starting point the fact that these visits take place. In other words, it does not address the fundamental question of whether or not this danger should even be brought here.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are attacking the Senate now.

—I am not attacking the Senate at all. I am attacking the logic of the report which comes from a Senate committee. I respect the application to task that has gone into this but I do not have to accept that all Senate reports are necessarily logical or infallible. I am sorry, but I am not accepting that this report is logical or infallible. It then in fact proceeds page after page, chapter after chapter, to address the very dangers which Senator Maguire was arguing earlier on are of no consequence at all. In fact, if we move on it cites the fact that visiting countries will not tell us whether the ships are nuclear armed or nuclear powered or not. There must be some reason why they will not tell us. There must be some reason why they withhold that information. It does not make sense, if there is no danger or it is not of consequence, not to tell us.

SPEECH.PARA: The report then goes on to say that it is very difficult to analyse these problems. Of course it is difficult. In fact we would argue that it is not even necessary if you do not have the damned danger in the first place. The fact that you have the difficulty of analysing the degree of danger and the complexity of contingency plans is in fact every reason for not allowing such vessels into our ports. If we do not allow them in, we do not have the danger, and we do not have the need for the contingency plan. The degree of difficulty associated with it, in fact, is irrelevant. This is what I consider to be logic. I do not consider what we heard from either Senator Maguire or Senator Crichton-Browne to be logic. We heard emotional outpourings which were often quite offensive.

The report, page after page, talks about the difficulties of assessing the consequences of accidents; that is, to admit that there can be accidents; to admit that those accidents have profound consequences; and to admit that it is difficult to react to those consequences. The report goes on, page after page, chapter after chapter-presumably hour after hour-to deliberate over protective measures following accidents. It considers in depth protective measures following accidents. Yet we are being told that there is no danger of such accidents. There is no logic in what is being advanced in the report and in the arguments in support of the report.

The only logical conclusion that we can reach is that there will be no danger if we have no ships in our ports. That has always been the only logical position to take, particularly in an era in which, hopefully, we are moving into a more peaceful posture globally, in an era in which we are proving, in incident after incident, that nuclear accidents are possible. If honourable senators do not believe me, they should read the numerous examples that I quoted when we debated an urgency motion on 4 November 1988, associated with bringing nuclear ships into our harbours for the bicentennial celebrations. I gave example after example of nuclear accidents at sea, in the water. That water may well be the water of harbours. It may well be the water of Australia's harbours.

There is no logic in what is being put before this chamber today. I congratulate Senator Dunn on having the logic and the courage to produce a dissenting report, to argue it well, to argue it substantially, and to stand in this chamber and defend it. I believe that that is what Senate committees are about. I congratulate her on presenting that dissenting report. I identify our party with the dissenting report. I simply rebuff the sort of emotional, dramatic rubbish, illogical as it clearly was and is, that Senator Crichton-Browne delivered to the chamber in his contribution to the debate on an extremely important report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade had been looking at the question of visits to Australia by nuclear powered or armed vessels for some time before I joined the Committee. My first reaction when I looked at the terms of reference, the length of time the Senate had already taken to consider it, the amount of progress that had been made and the amount of work which remained to be done, was to wonder whether it was worth doing at all. The Senate does not often enough consider the cost-benefit aspects of its own actions. I wondered whether this inquiry was to keep senators busy instead of an inquiry to serve a particular public purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I think we have now produced a substantial public document, a reference work-I suspect that if one takes into account the dissenting report as well, one will see that we have a reference work for both sides of the debate; I do not have any objection to that-and a substantial body of public information on the issue. That makes a contribution to public life. It raises the possibility of substantial tightening of procedures and arrangements surrounding visits by nuclear-powered vessels, particularly where the States have been noticeably slack. I refer in particular to Tasmania, Queensland and the Northern Territory. In those States there clearly has been a substantial and evident inadequacy of planning and it is appropriate that that be brought to attention. It should have been brought to attention in the normal course of parliamentary scrutiny in those States, but it was not. So to that extent the report raises useful new matter.

I have to say that the dissenting report was predictable and I suspect it was written and put in the bottom drawer before any of the evidence was presented. It is a legitimate point of view for people to hold about matters of foreign policy. It did not bear any relationship to the terms of reference of the inquiry, which was precluded from looking at those important foreign policy questions. There is a legitimate foreign policy debate there. I do not want to get involved with abusing people who have a different foreign policy view from me or from the Government. I do not think that is very helpful to the debate and it is a pity that it was injected into the debate; but nobody takes much notice of Senator Crichton-Browne, so I will not either.

The dissenting report was very predictable. What is wrong with it is that it fails to take into account the consequences of its actions. What we have to face up to is that it may be that as a matter of foreign policy people do not wish to see any such visits. That is, as I say, a legitimate foreign policy view which I do not share. However, I think what we have to do, and what our mandate was, is deal with what should be done while these visits continue. For example, what should be done about the totally inadequate situation in Hobart, where the Tasmanian Government approved plans which had within the zone that needed to be evacuated in the event of any problem the Hobart public hospital? Those sorts of issues warrant serious consideration and the Committee did the appropriate thing in considering them. It is a pity that the dissenting report does not.

I support the comments made by others, in particular by the Chairman, in congratulating the staff of the Committee, who did an enormously difficult job very well in presenting this comprehensive report. I thank the consultants who assisted the Committee in areas concerned with the scientific validity of the material put forward where we needed substantial advice and received it. It is an issue in which emotions tend to cloud judgment, and they did for many people who came before us. They were people of goodwill, people with a substantial desire to improve the world and Australia in particular, but they were not always able to support the level of their enthusiasm with the quality of their argument.

The Committee was not presented with the option of opting out of decisions, nor were we given the brief of making surrogate foreign policy decisions. We had a brief to consider, given that there are visits to Australia by nuclear powered and nuclear armed vessels, what are the best arrangements that can be made adequately to cope with that. The recommendations should lead, if accepted, to some significant tightening of the arrangements concerning such visits. For example, with regard to land use planning, and I refer particularly there to Port Adelaide and Townsville, we had a silly situation in respect of one very simple mechanism concerning town plans in areas affected by the 1.5 kilometre zone. There was no notation on those town plans requiring Defence or the port authority to be advised of any planning changes in such areas so that they could ensure that the safety arrangements set in place at any one time continued to operate. The Committee has recommended that that should take place and I hope that that simple cost-free recommendation is taken up. There are not many cost-free recommendations around.

There are significant recommendations for enhancement of the provision of information to the public. There are, as I said earlier, the important recommendations relating to Hobart and particularly the Macquarie wharves. The situation in Hobart required attention and I am pleased that it received it. Some other legitimate concerns, for example, those of the civilian firefighters, it seemed to me had been fudged until now. Either they should be told they have no role or they should be trained for the role they have. They are left in the unsatisfactory position of uncertainty. They are entitled to have that situation clarified. The recommendations, if adopted, would provide that clarification.

I do not want to take a lot of time in this debate and, of course, I do not have the opportunity to do so because there is only 10 minutes available. I will make a brief reference to the question of nuclear weapon accidents. I do not have the time to deal with the issue in great substance but the Chairman dealt with it very adequately. We are not recommending similar special contingency plans there but the Committee does acknowledge a genuine community concern about that matter. I guess `plan' is perhaps too grand a title. But there is the need for an explanatory document. PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 August, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the House of Representatives, while supporting the legislation, the Opposition divided the House on the questions of the application of this Bill to people who separate and have children born before its commencement and on the date on which liability under the formula would commence. Since the debate in the House there have been very productive discussions between the Government and the Opposition. This statement is designed to accommodate the concerns raised by the Opposition. The Government has also held productive discussions with the Australian Democrats. Those discussions have resulted in agreement between the parties on the Bill before the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government indicates that we will accept the amendment circulated by the Opposition. It meets the concerns of both the Government and the Opposition expressed in the House of Representatives on the question of the date of commencement of liability. The Government has established the Child Support Evaluation Advisory Group to oversee the evaluation of stage 2 of the child support scheme. The members of the group are: the Honourable Justice Fogarty, senior judge, Family Court of Australia, Convener; Mr Des Black, retired Second Commissioner of Taxation; Ms Diana Bryant, senior partner, Phillips Fox, solicitors; and Ms Merle Mitchell, Vice-President, Australian Council of Social Service. The group will monitor and advise on the implementation and evaluation of the child support scheme from commencement of stage 2 of the scheme. It will subsume the monitoring function of the Child Support Consultative Group.

The Opposition has agreed not to proceed with the amendments it moved in the House in relation to the limitation of the application of the Bill to people who separate or have a child born on or after commencement of the Bill. To meet the concerns of the Opposition on this issue it has been agreed in discussions between the Government and Opposition that the priority task for the new Child Support Evaluation Consultative Group will be to examine the effect of excluding from assessment under the proposed Child Support (Assessment) Act those persons who separated before 1 October 1989 and do not have a child born on or after that date.

In particular, the group will: monitor the level of orders being made by, or registered with, the courts for the maintenance of those children excluded from the assessment process; compare maintenance levels set by, or registered with, the courts with the level of support obtainable under the formula in comparable circumstances; and monitor procedures to:
(i) maximise the coverage of child support received by the sole parent pensioner population; and
(ii) ensure that the level of child support received by sole parent pensioners is adequate.
The group will be required to report on these matters by 31 July 1990.

There is a clear equity argument pursued with vigour by the Opposition and accepted by the Government-that it is desirable for all children of separated parents to have equal access to fair, secure and regular child support. The legislation before the Senate effects substantial changes in the ways in which very sensitive issues are resolved. It implements a new system of administrative assessment by requiring the application of a formula to determine the appropriate level of child support. But it applies only to children of parents who separate or have a child born on or after its commencement. This limitation means children not covered by the Bill would continue to have their child support entitlements assessed under the Family Law Act. The Department of Social Security provides to sole parent pensioners a form to assist them to obtain an enforceable agreement for child support under the Family Law Act and comprehensive referral information to assist them to proceed to court where this is necessary.

Under recent amendments to the family law rules procedures for obtaining orders under the Family Law Act have been substantially simplified. Under these procedures it should be easier for those who do not negotiate agreements to apply for an order which could result in payment in accordance with the formula used in those cases to which administrative assessment applies.

The Child Support Evaluation Advisory Group will provide advice on whether these mechanisms result in any inequity as between children covered by administrative assessment and those not covered by administrative assessment in comparable circumstances and on the coverage of the existing sole parent pensioner population. The Government undertakes to publish that advice as soon as it is received and to table it in both Houses of the Parliament.

The Government welcomes the support of the Opposition and Australian Democrats for this most important reform. It is a credit to the Parliament that we are able to legislate to overcome one of the greatest inequities in Australian society with such a unity of purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is supporting the Child Support (Assessment) Bill 1989, as the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) has said, subject to the amendment which I will move in the committee stage and subject to the statement which the Minister has just made. The Opposition has been concerned for a long time that there is gross inequity to children who suffer when their parents separate. This Bill, in fact, starts to send messages that indeed the Government of Australia and the Opposition in Australia are serious that people who bring children into the world have an on-going and permanent responsibility to bring those children up in a reasonable way to meet the normal expectations they would have had had their parents not so separated. This is but stage two of a package which the Government has initiated, the first one being to provide for the registration, collection and enforcement of court orders for maintenance by the Child Support Agency which is controlled by the Commissioner of Taxation. The Opposition supports this package because it is consistent with our own policy and, indeed, goes back to the position taken by the Ruddock report in 1980. The concerns about unfairness and lack of equity have been with the Opposition for a considerable time.

SPEECH.PARA: The development of the formula which is outlined in the Bill is complicated but it means that there will be a degree of certainty about how much will be paid by a non-custodial parent towards the maintenance of the children that he or she has brought into this world and has an on-going responsibility for. In the debate in the House of Representatives it was pointed out by Mr Wilson that it will assist in alleviating child poverty, and that approximately 500,000 children are living in poverty. So much for the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that there would be none left in 1990. The really sad thing is that the majority of these children are the children of so-called sole parents, although that term does worry me somewhat because no child actually comes into this world with a sole parent. It takes two people to bring any child into this world and, unfortunately, under the law as it has been presently, it has been possible for one parent simply to abrogate the responsibility he or she has towards the children that they, together, brought into the world.

It is interesting that of those children 60 per cent are living in poverty as a result of being left with a so-called sole parent who has been deserted or divorced. Very often when we hear the debate about the size of the pension bill for sole parent benefits, we hear the allegation that all sole parents are unmarried mothers who have brought children into the world, outside wedlock, and therefore the Government is saddled with the burden. This is simply not true. The majority of people who are in receipt of the sole parent benefit are mothers who have been deserted by the father of their children who has left the State, the taxpayer, to pick up the tab for bringing those children through education and into adulthood. This is clearly not acceptable. The thing that is saddening is that it has taken us this long to do something about it.

In the statement which the Minister read he spoke of the Child Support Evaluation Advisory Group which is chaired by Justice Fogarty of the Family Court. It was with some anguish that the Opposition agreed not to pursue the further amendment which would have brought within the ambit of this change children of separated parents where the separation took place prior to 1 October 1989 and where the child came into being before 1 October 1989, because it is felt that those children will be disadvantaged. We accept the good faith of the Government that it will charge this evaluation advisory group with the task of monitoring the awards which are made and any fresh applications which are made for alterations in maintenance. If injustice remains by 1990, when the committee is to report, we look forward to further action being taken. A very significant paragraph in the statement that the Minister read is on page 2 and it reads this way:

There is a clear equity argument pursued with vigour by the Opposition and accepted by the Government. That is that it is desirable for all children of separated parents to have equal access to fair, secure and regular child support.

Too many times, many members and senators would become aware of constituents who come to visit them with great plight where the withdrawal of one parent from the family unit has meant that the whole lifestyle and expectation of life of the children of that family has altered. Clearly, the unilateral abrogation of responsibility of one parent towards children that have been jointly brought into the world is no longer acceptable, and that is the very strong message that comes through from the enacting of this legislation.

Going back to the Child Support Consultative Group, I think a statement which it made with regard to the establishment of the formula and why the formula was recommended is significant and is worth quoting. It took a view about the formula, which I have said is reasonably complicated. It is the child support percentage which is laid out in the proposed section 38 of the Bill, times the adjusted income amount, which is further defined in the Bill, which results from the child support income amount less the exempted income amount. All that that really means is that the non-custodial parent is entitled to have support to maintain his or her own needs, but there is a table of child support percentages which are set out in the Act which simply says that if you have one, two, three, four or five or more children, then a certain percentage of the child support income amount, less the exempted income amount, will be paid for maintenance of those children. But to go back to the reason for that formula being arrived at, the group said that:
The formula should seek to approximate the situation where parents live together, by guaranteeing the child an appropriate share in his or her parents' income.

That is saying very succinctly that there is an expectation as a result of this legislation, that indeed a child's expectation having been born into a family is not to be diminished by the unilateral and, indeed, very often irresponsible, departure of one parent from that situation which hitherto has meant that the taxpayer has picked up the tab.

It is important, though, to realise that the formula is not mandatory. It is possible to reach an agreement between parents as to the proper maintenance of those children, and the Opposition is supportive of that. Indeed, where there is a case to be made for a departure from that formula, then this matter can be dealt with by the court. So the application of the formula will not be harsh and unconscionable, but there is provision to make sure that its application brings about a fair adjustment. It is also important to realise that there is a limit on the amount of income that may be taken into account, and again that is reasonable.

I go back to say that we support this Bill because it is consistent with our own policies with regard to a fair shake of the stick for kids who, through no fault of their own, find that their expectations in life have been diminished because of the laws of the land and the signals that were sent out by governments previously.

Another important statistic is worth repeating. I know it was dealt with in the lower House, but it is important to put it on the record here. Prior to the introduction of stage one, which established the Child Support Agency, 70 per cent of non-custodial parents were not paying any maintenance at all for their children. That is clearly outrageous. We have been living in a society where we have condoned the irresponsible behaviour of parents towards their children. When we look at reports on homeless youth, again we see that children have become homeless because of splits in their family. There has been no satisfactory way of ensuring that they have an equitable share in the expectation that their parents originally brought them up to have.

Of those custodial parents who had enforceable liabilities in the form of maintenance orders, 70 per cent were not receiving any maintenance. Court orders were simply ignored by many non-custodial parents because the business of trying to enforce the order was just too painful and too difficult. There has been an improvement since the introduction of stage one and, indeed, there was the solid lobby group that argued that stage one ought to be monitored further and that stage two ought to be delayed for some time. It was the joint view of the Government and the Opposition that this was not a suitable way to go; that the need for stage two to be introduced was far too great and it was timely for it to be introduced now. As I have said, the operation date for this legislation is 1 October and although, as I mentioned earlier, we had originally said that we would like all children who were children of separated parents to have access to this new formula, we have agreed with the Government, in light of the statement that has been made, to withdraw that amendment on the undertaking that the matter will be monitored.

Whatever the level of payments under the formula, those forced to pay will always complain. There are parents who are separated and who do in fact meet all the obligations that a parent ought to meet. There are parents who take a responsible attitude when their marriages break and they maintain the responsibility that they have to families that they have created. But unfortunately they are in the minority. When stage 1 was introduced there were many who felt they were hardly done by because, in good faith, they had maintained their families in a way in which they were able to do and which was fair and just, but because so many had abused the system it was necessary to legislate to change the basic rules. That is exactly the case with stage two.

It is quite unacceptable for the community to pay, in the form of higher taxes, for the funding of so-called discretionary parents. The fact of the matter is that, if people bring children into this world in this society, they have an ongoing responsibility to bring those children up, to make them good citizens, to give them good education and to make them proud Australians. It is simply no longer acceptable to say, `I think I have had enough, I am going off to have a better time and the state can pick up the tab'.

It is hoped, I believe, that the sense of despair that many Australian children have had, those same children who live in poverty, will be relieved and they will have a better chance under this legislation. It certainly is the intent of the Opposition in giving support to the Bill that what will result is a fairer and a better life for Australian children who will then grow up to be better Australians and in turn create their own families which have a better chance of being stable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in support of the Child Support (Assessment) Bill 1989. I want first of all to congratulate the Government on proceeding through all the stages that it has had to go through to get to this, I guess, final stage in the child support legislation package. We have to acknowledge that it is the political will of this Government that has carried that through. While I take the point raised by Senator Bishop that this is not something entirely of the Government's making, and certainly the Opposition in times past has had inquiries and tried to tackle the issue, I think it is a matter of record that it was the political will of this Government that saw it through to the very important, significant and appropriate legislation we are introducing tonight. I think the sentiment conveyed by this legislation does enjoy bipartisan support, and Senator Bishop has said that very succinctly.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also important to note that not only do we have bipartisan political support but also, as was said in the second reading speech, this child support scheme has brought about a unique display of unity of purpose amongst all legislators in Australia. It is very significant to have that bipartisan support across political parties and the achievement of unanimity of purpose amongst the different legislatures in this country is unique.

That is also, associated with the increase in pensions and the recognition by government that it is the appropriate income for families, particularly that provided to the parent, that is going to best assist the children.
