It also should be said that this legislation recognises another policy of this Government, and that is to manage government expenditure in a proper and responsible way. The expenditure is targeted to those in need; it is not being paid to people who have the capacity to care for themselves in part or in whole. Stage two of the legislation will within three years be saving government expenditure of something like $160m. That is all part of the comprehensive approach by government, particularly in the areas of this legislation, not only to provide for the people in the community but also to provide that it is properly done, responsibly done and efficiently done by the departments.

Senator Bishop made the point that prior to this legislation some 30 per cent of parents were paying maintenance. Since the introduction of stage one, and I guess that is a very short time, that has changed to 70 per cent of parents paying maintenance. I think that is really a remarkable turn around and, I think, it has been done with the minimum of odium in the community. There has been very little significant outcry or backlash against that kind of requirement on parents. It is a splendid example of the comprehensive approach of this Government in addressing those issues. It has involved close working, too, between the Department of Social Security and the Australian Taxation Office, and it has involved comprehensive legislative changes under social security legislation, family law legislation and tax legislation. In fact, it probably needs to be written up as a monument to something, but I think we should start writing right now. The Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) should perhaps convey to those people involved that that should be written. I am very pleased to acknowledge the presence in the gallery of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). I place on record our appreciation of his very significant role in getting to this point so effectively.

The other part of this package includes a campaign to ensure that people know their rights under these changes. That campaign will be addressed to parents, people in the relevant departments, employers, the legal profession, accountants, and so on. Even that small campaign is another example of how this legislation is very comprehensively addressing all the bits and pieces that are sometimes not addressed and which therefore may lead to a less than optimal outcome.

The legislation addresses the rights of children and, if not the rights of parents, certainly, firstly, the needs of parents to fulfil their obligations towards their children, secondly, the needs of parents not to be forced into poverty and, thirdly, the need to recognise that custodial parents, usually mothers, have been in times past pushed into poverty. This legislation will go a long way towards assisting those families by providing a regular and known income to enable families to budget, to manage, to address all those questions that are much better able to be addressed if one has the idea of the amount of money and that it is guaranteed to continue to come to one. The legislation is prospective. This has been touched on by both the Minister and Senator Bishop. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add my remarks to the Child Support (Assessment) Bill 1989 on behalf of the Australian Democrats. This Bill is designed to implement the second stage of the child support scheme announced by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) in March 1987. The Child Support Act which came into effect on 1 June 1988 implemented the first part of the scheme. It provided for the registration, collection and enforcement of court orders for maintenance by the Child Support Agency which is controlled by the Commissioner of Taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators are aware, a range of problems existed under the previous arrangements, not the least of these being the low levels of maintenance paid and the contribution this made to child poverty and to high levels of taxation. Prior to the introduction of stage one, for example, court orders were frequently ignored by the non-custodial parent whereas, since the implementation of stage one, the record has improved. In social security terms the proportion of `sole parent' beneficiaries receiving maintenance has increased from 24 per cent to 34 per cent. Nevertheless there is still a long way to go before the cost of maintaining is properly distributed. The assessment procedures now coming into place are designed to alleviate existing problems and the formula seeks to simplify the present complex procedures.

Turning now to the details of the Bill, it provides for administrative assessment of child support by the Registrar of Child Support. It sets out the eligibility criteria which will enable a custodian to claim administrative assessment from a parent of the child. It sets out the formula which will determine the level of child support to be paid by a parent who is no longer living with the child and which takes into account different income levels of each parent. It gives courts with jurisdiction under the Family Law Act 1975 jurisdiction to hear applications relating to eligibility for administrative assessment of child support. Also it allows courts to review wrong assessments and to hear applications for departure from assessment according to the formula in certain circumstances. The development of the formula contained in this legislation emerged from the deliberation of the child support consultative group. Very properly the group took the approach that the formula should seek to approximate the situation where the parents live together by guaranteeing the child an appropriate share of his or her parent's income. In simple terms, the formula works by taking the non-custodial parent's income, reducing it by a self-support component and dividing the remainder by a relevant percentage ranging from 18 per cent to 36 per cent, depending on the number of children.

As I have already indicated, there is provision for certain matters to be referred to a court, including cases where departure from the formula is sought and the court finds grounds to justify that variation. The aim of the legislation is both to bring maintenance payments to realistic levels and to ease the burden on the social security system. The determination of appropriate levels has been arrived at by reference to numerous studies examining the costs of children, particularly studies undertaken by the Australian Institute of Family Studies. In passing, I would like to pay tribute to the invaluable work undertaken over the years by the Australian Institute of Family Studies and to acknowledge the extent to which an understanding of all aspects of family life in Australia has been enhanced by the material the Australian Institute of Family Studies has produced.

To return to the legislation, the formula is to apply from 1 October so that any couples who separate or have a child born after that date are covered by the legislation. It is also worth noting that this Bill is the result of an extensive process of public consultation, a process of particular importance on such a sensitive issue as this. In fact, over 500 formal submissions were received during the process leading to the formulation of this Bill.

Apart from commending the way in which the legislation has been formulated, the Australian Democrats are happy to support its content. This legislation is about both the community's and a parent's primary duty to maintain children. It is about ensuring that those children are maintained at adequate levels and that obligations are met where they should be met. The approach it takes is fair and flexible and it seems to us that in bread and butter terms the very worthy objectives of the Bill will be met by its implementation.

In conclusion, it is pleasing to note the cooperative approach that has been taken in relation to this Bill. The issue is not without its problems. But it is about the well-being of our children and deserves a bipartisan, or perhaps I should say tripartisan, approach. The Australian Democrats are pleased to be part of that and to support the Bill.

Frequently maintenance was all wrapped up in a property settlement and the custodial parent then sought to supplement the cash income from the social security arrangements that existed.

There is no doubt that that developed to a very fine degree as a consequence of the interpretation of one particular section of the original Act. Sections 74 and 75 dealt with the matter of child maintenance, but it was 75 (f) which in particular I believe contributed to the development that needed to be dealt with, and I believe is being dealt with in this legislation-that is, the court should take into account, when assessing the maintenance paid by a non-custodial parent to the custodial parent, any pension or other entitlement that the person might have. So for many years after it was determined that social security was one such item, the amount of maintenance that was paid under court orders was at the very minimum that would enable the custodial parent to get the absolute maximum benefit out of the social security system.

In my view things went wrong in this respect right from the start. Of course, there is never only one answer to any problem, but I believe that was a significant problem that probably was not intended. We have finished up with a situation in which, until recently, up to 70 per cent of children were not benefiting from a contribution from a non-custodial parent.

We must not overlook the fact that quite a large number of voluntary agreements have been satisfactory. Some agreements that perhaps came under the category of voluntary were not so in many respects. We have to take into account the cost of court proceedings when we assess whether some of them were really voluntary or not. Many orders have been made by the court and adjudicated upon using the criteria that were in the original Act and which are still there. One significant fact is that in the future maintenance will be assessed, on the one hand, by the court using criteria which have been laid down for some time and, on the other hand, under this legislation, by an administrative assessment which in no way takes into account these factors. This is one of the matters which I hope the Minister will ask the advisory group which he referred to earlier to look at as time passes to see whether there are significant differences.

The factors which the court is required to take into account are income; earning capacity; property; the financial resources of the child; the manner in which the child is being, and in which the parents expect the child to be, educated or trained; any special needs of the child; the capacity of the child to earn or to derive income; income earning capacity; the property and financial resources of the parties; the commitments of the parties that are necessary to enable them to support themselves; the direct and indirect costs incurred by the parent or other person who has the custody of the child; and other special circumstances. None of these is taken into account in the formula. It may not be significant in the slightest but it may well be, and I believe it is an additional aspect of the whole matter that the advisory group ought to have referred to it when reporting back on the operation of the second stage of the Government's proposals.

There is another aspect of the whole development of the Government's new proposals. Stage one, as has been referred to, I think, by all of the previous speakers, has resulted in significantly increased numbers of non-custodial parents contributing to the support of their children, as should be so, through the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Social Security. In a number of instances there have been difficulties in parents getting the money under that arrangement. I hope that those difficulties will discontinue but there have been problems for some parents. I say to the Minister that the Government needs to monitor the situation most carefully to ensure that it is providing sufficiently adequate resources to enable this administrative arrangement for the assessment, collection and payment of maintenance to allow the money to get to the parent who needs it at the right time. I will not bore honourable senators tonight in going through some of the stories that I have heard, to which I have referred previously, of delays which have occurred. A parent who needs the money certainly needs it and it is the children who suffer if it does not come in.

While it is quite clear that many more are paying, unless the money gets to the parent we are not really doing the custodial parent any favour at all. I urge the Government most strongly to see that adequate resources are given to the Taxation Office to do the job it is now required to do. In addition, as always, adequate resources should be given to the Family Court in the areas that it is still involved in. They are many and varied and I believe that that Court is not adequately resourced to achieve the outcomes that the Government is talking about.

The second stage is the operation of the formula which has been referred to. I do not think it is necessary to go into it in detail tonight. We talk frequently about the number of children living in poverty as a consequence of breakdown of marriage and lack of adequate support being paid to the custodial parent. I think we need also to monitor the operation of this formula to make quite certain that where there is adequate money to support the children it is not used to assist a non-custodial parent to pay less than he or she might otherwise have done by some other means. One has again to take into account the cost for a custodial parent of going to the Court for an order where that parent feels that the present arrangement is not adequate. That parent may well feel that he or she has to accept what is being offered in the light of the costs involved. The whole operation needs to be monitored to make sure that at one end of the scale this scheme is not used to enable people to pay less.

I refer to the article of Ian Scott, a specialist assistant at the Australian Institute of Family Studies. His article, entitled `The Child Maintenance Formula and the Costs of Children', is in the August 1989 issue, issue No. 24, of Family Matters, produced by the Australian Institute of Family Studies. I would like to read the whole article to the Senate but I will not. He says early in his article:

For this reason the level of maintenance paid under the formula will relate to the income of the non-custodial parent and will not vary with the actual cost of caring for the child (or children) for whom it is paid.

There are a number of other parts of the article that I recommend. He points out the extent to which the amount paid will be significantly less than the cost of supporting a child. The last paragraph states:

Given the distribution of earnings cited above, it is likely that under the proposed maintenance formula around 40 per cent of the non-custodial parents in the above examples will contribute less than half the direct costs associated with raising a child or children.

It was that paragraph that alerted me to the fact that it may well be possible to capitalise on that for those for whom it would be financially beneficial to do so. That is not to say that in a whole lot of other cases, of course, the benefit to supporting children under this formula will not be greatly improved. I wonder also whether or not the formula adequately takes into account the situation of a parent who has the custody of a child who is disabled or very sick. I wonder whether the formula takes into account living perhaps in the country on the one hand or in the city on the other, and things of that nature. Perhaps we cannot tell this at the present time, but they are matters which I think ought to be looked at as time passes, as the previous Act has been looked at from time to time.

In summary, the issues include the fact that under court orders where parents take the matter of custody to court, the court will be using criteria different from the bald formula which is administratively put into effect. I have mentioned examples querying whether or not we have adequately taken care of those sorts of exceptions, and the case where parents are adequately resourced to make sure that the money changing hands does so in the way that it should. I think the report of Kerry Lovering, who did excellent work on the cost of children in Australia in 1984, is a development in the assessing of child maintenance which certainly was not part of the original assessment when the Act came into being and for a number of years thereafter. That information is particularly valuable, and in looking at that I noted also that under the Child Support (Assessment) Bill 1989 the formula seems to go up only to 34 per cent for four children, and then we run into 36 per cent for five or more children. Maybe once someone gets to five it is all the same, but I would doubt it. That too would be a matter on which I hope the Minister will invite comment.

There is to be a child support evaluation advisory group to monitor the situation. The group, as has been mentioned by the Minister, is to be led by Mr Justice Fogarty. We have some terms of reference, and are told:
In particular, the group will monitor the level of orders being made by, or registered with, the courts for the maintenance of those children excluded from the assessment process;
That must be done, in my view. I recognise to change it would be retrospective but I think it is necessary for us to know what the differences are. Further, the group is to:
. . . compare maintenance levels set by, or registered with, the courts with the level of support obtainable under the formula in comparable circumstances; and monitor procedures to:
(i) maximise the coverage of child support received by the sole parent pensioner population; and
(ii) ensure that the level of child support received by sole parent pensioners is adequate.

In my view, the matters that I have referred to all really come within that. I hope that Mr Justice Fogarty and his committee will see it that way and feel free to comment to the Parliament on any other matters that come to their notice, because that is likely to happen with something like this. I hope that it works. I hope that it means that many custodial parents who now live a very precarious existence with their finances and budgeting will be better off, because if they are, the children that they are caring for in fact will be much better off also.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 13, subparagraph 31 (1) (d) (i), lines 30 to 39, leave out subparagraph, insert the following subparagraph:
``(i) beginning on:

(a) if the application was made to the Registrar within 28 days after the earliest day or the most recent earliest day, as the case requires, on which an application for administrative assessment of child support could properly be made by the custodian entitled to child support seeking payment of child support for the child from the liable parent (in this subparagraph called the `earliest entitlement day') and the liable parent did not, on or after the earliest entitlement day and before the day on which the application was made to the Registrar (in this subparagraph called the `application day'), pay or provide maintenance for the child to the custodian entitled to child support-the earliest entitlement day; or

(b) if the application was not made to the Registrar within 28 days after the earliest entitlement day and the liable parent did not, on or after the earliest entitlement day and before the application day, pay or provide maintenance for the child to the custodian entitled to child support-the day 28 days before the application day; or

(c) if the liable parent, on or after the earliest entitlement day and before the application day, paid or provided maintenance for the child to the custodian entitled to child support-the application day; and''.

I foreshadowed this amendment in my speech on the second reading. I would like to outline the purpose of the amendment. Very simply, the Bill as it stands provides that if an application is made to the Registrar for assessment within 28 days of separation, the non-custodial parent will be liable to make child maintenance payments from the date of separation. On the other hand, if the application to the Registrar for assessment is made after 28 days, then the non-custodial parent will be liable for payment from the date of application. The Opposition feels that if the Bill were to be left in that way, it would be an encouragement for people to take action pursuant to a separation to make it permanent, whereas otherwise, if they wished to wait a little more than a bare 28 days, which we feel is a comparatively short time to try for reconciliation, those people would be disadvantaged. Therefore, our amendment seeks to provide in the latter case for the maintenance to be payable by the liable parent for the 28 days prior to the date of application provided that no maintenance has been received in that period.

The Opposition, as I said in the beginning, in supporting this legislation, is concerned to see that parents meet their responsibilities to children. We are also concerned that encouragement should be given to families who find themselves in difficulties to try to work those difficulties out and to remain together as a family. We feel that the provision of this 28-day rule is part of that, in that people would not be forced to apply very quickly for an assessment within the 28-day period because otherwise they would miss out on that retrospective payment.

We are pleased that the Government is supporting our amendment and, as I said right at the beginning, the Opposition is supporting the legislation because it is in line with our own policy and indeed with the concerns of the Opposition going right back as far as 1980. Senator Crowley in her remarks acknowledged that this was an important issue and, indeed, is more important than political skirmishing. We are talking about the fundamental family unit that makes up this nation of Australia. Senator Crowley talked about the political will of the Government but I think that political will is equally matched by the Opposition.

I think the speeches that we have heard during the second reading debate have outlined, as in Senator Reid's case, areas which will require specific scrutiny by the evaluation committee. Of course this committee subsumed the consultative committee which was established to oversee stage one and that committee has a most important and ongoing function. The statement which sets out the things that the group will be required to monitor goes to the very heart of the Opposition's concern that all children of separated parents have equal access to fair, secure and regular child support. We feel that the amendment that we are moving to ensure that the 28-day rule will allow people, no matter when they apply for assessment, to receive that retrospective payment of 28 days, having been accepted by the Government, means that the Bill is improved to that degree.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Cooper Creek Expedition-Child Migrant Schemes-Live Sheep Dispute

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to place on record the story of a very exciting expedition that I am afraid I will not be able to attend, although I would love the opportunity and if the Senate was minded to allow me to go, I would take the opportunity. I refer to the Australian and New Zealand scientific exploration (ANZSES) trip to Cooper Creek. It is the second, as far as I know, all-women expedition following the `True Desert' expedition which was conducted in the area of Lake Eyre Basin last year by ANZSES, which was also an all-women venture. This time the expedition is setting off to Cooper Creek, and what better time to go, because I understand that Lake Torrens, just south of Lake Eyre in this area, is filled for the first time this century. Lake Eyre is still filling with the waters coming down from the Channel Country-indeed, in your own State, Madam Acting Deputy President.
—It was full a couple of months ago.

—I will take Senator Panizza's advice on that. I am told the waters are still coming down. It has been a very good year and it is a very exciting time to be out there. I received an invitation to accompany this expedition and I must say I would give my eye teeth to join the people out there for 2 1/2 weeks on the banks of Cooper Creek. It is a scientific expedition. Would Senator Reid like to come, too?
—If we can both get leave, yes.

—Right, you are on. That is one from either side; we should fix that with the Whips in no time at all. I think it will be a very exciting venture. I read a report in the Australian Magazine of 29-30 October 1988 of their previous expedition called `True Desert'. It would be interesting if the women who went on the first expedition were to go on the second one. SPEECH.PARA: It is, as ANZSES expeditions are, scientific in nature, so there will be considerable resource collection and examination of vegetation, birds, mammals, reptiles, insects and arachnids-which I think means spiders. I might have to take Senator Reid along to interpret. Indeed, they will also be looking at some archaeology. They expect some 40 women to attend and, as I understand from Major Fran Conlan, who is leading the expedition, the places are already filled, near enough, and that the women will come, as on the previous occasion, from a wide variety of backgrounds and experiences. SPEECH.PARA: The live sheep dispute is probably the biggest fiasco that has occurred in the sheep trade since at least 1976 and, previous to that, in the years of downturn, 1969 and 1971. The whole industry-not only the shippers that supply the live sheep market-is paying the price for the internal politics of several other countries. It is obvious that is the situation, because the alleged diseases-I stress `alleged'-sheep pox and Maltese fever have never been known to exist in Australia. Not only are they unheard of in Australia but each shipment is examined before it leaves the Australian ports and certainly no evidence of these diseases has been found. There has been no report on previous shipments either, and that is going back since live shippers have been around, at least for the last 25 years.

From reports that I have on hand I am led to believe that in Saudi Arabia shipments are not tested before disembarking in the Gulf. They are tested five days later on their feed lots. Five days is not long enough for diseases to actually evolve before they are tested, but it certainly leaves the whole subject open to questions.

Testing methods and indeed the chemical reagents used in those tests have been questioned. Not only have they been questioned but it has been proven that wrong and outdated reagents have been used. As I said, the wrong reagents were certainly used to test brucelli mallatentitus, which, incidentally, is very dangerous and often fatal in humans. If such a disease is prevalent in sheep in Australia, I fail to see where it may be.

These sheep, when their acceptance was refused in Saudi Arabia, were reloaded from the suspect feed lots and eventually sold to Kuwait. Their transport to Kuwait provided a little more time in which these diseases could have evolved and shown up. Kuwait certainly did not find any disease in them, at least not in the first shipment, but it found reasons to reject some later on. Other shipments actually went to Qatar as well. I would like to speculate, Madam Acting Deputy President, on where the sheep that went to Kuwait finished up. Maybe they got back into Saudi Arabia through the back door at a discount. I have not been able to find out from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) or anyone else in the trade how much discount there was, if any, but I suppose if they were going in through the back door there would have been a discount.

If they are going in through the back door I suppose that is quite legal but the Australian sheep industry is being used as a pawn in the game. No one can tell me, as I have said, what prices were paid by the Kuwaitis. Complaints by Australian officials-not a very high level of Australian official-have been rebuffed by the story that the Minister is on holidays and does not want to be disturbed. It is fair to say that if the Minister is away on holidays someone else, perhaps an acting Minister, could deal with it. But the whole fiasco has been accepted by this Government, I am afraid, without a whimper. Mr Kerin has done nothing and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is too busy shooting from the hip at the pilots to be worried about such an important situation as the live sheep trade.

The live sheep trade is worth some $350m a year. It takes six to seven million older sheep, aged 3 1/2 years, away from Australia and it is certainly not an insignificant trade. This case, as I have said, involves internal politics in order to depress the price of Australian sheep. For many years Saudi Arabia has been endeavouring to improve its own industry which is quite a commendable move but, of course, it is doing it with a subsidy. Perhaps the subsidy is starting to hurt now and it is looking at other methods to be able to bring its sheep production forward. Australian wethers are landed in Saudi Arabia at about $A65 and I am told that the internal price has now risen to around $A90; so at that figure I would say it could just about justify its own industry without a subsidy. But unfortunately for Saudi Arabia, its sheep numbers will not stand up for very long and it will soon have a shortage.

I believe that in this situation we have another European Common Market and United States set-up with subsidies around the world that Australian farmers are suffering. This is achieved, of course, not by honest means but by non-trade barriers. It is achieved by falsely putting down the cleanliness of the Australian sheep industry and that is what worries me the most. This we have to suffer, not only in the Gulf but on the stage of the rest of the world. If we get a name in the Gulf for having unclean products the rest of the world will certainly take notice. This will do as much damage, I believe, as the kangaroo meat fiasco did to the beef trade. I believe that the kangaroo meat fiasco was nothing but sabotage, but my beliefs have not yet been proven one way or the other. In the meantime, while all this is going on, this Government is doing nothing about it. I am sick and tired of the Government licking the boots of our trading partners. When we talk about trading partners I believe we should be partners and not weak-kneed subjectives.

This term that I use, weak-kneed, could be applied to some of our industry organisations around Australia. Some industry organisations that are supported and financed by farmers are being weak-kneed in this situation. They are preaching peace at all costs. They are saying, `Do not rock the boat'. I put them in the same category. The situation is critical, especially in Western Australia. It is critical because farmers are holding on to sheep which normally would be sold by now. I believe that a rough estimation of numbers is that some 250,000 to 300,000 sheep are being held on the farms. Normally these sheep would be in the process of going right now.

Added to this, of course, are the other sheep which would normally be turned off at this time of the year. Of course, in Western Australia there has been a record cold winter in the higher rainfall wheat belt and grazing areas and this has prevented the normal growth of feed. Farmers in those areas have been told to hang on to the sheep for a longer period and not to clog the market. Unfortunately they cannot hold on to them any longer. Australia's sheep numbers are increasing at a rate that I believe is too fast. That, of course, was stepped up because of the price of the Australian wool clip last year. A normal turn-off of six to seven million sheep per year to the Arab States helps keep things in balance.

The abattoir space at the present moment is at a premium and almost totally committed to the ewe mutton trade, so slaughtering in Australia of those shipping wethers is not an option. As happened in 1969, 1971 and 1976, I would not be surprised if there were not industrial action in the abattoirs at such a time while space is at a premium. Of course, this disaster has caused a downturn in the price of all sheep. Shippers, some three or four weeks ago, were making between $28 and $30 in Western Australia and now they are making between $12 and $14. Then, of course, this has flowed through to the rest of the sheep trade. Now we have the older type of ewes that once again are classed as NCV. For the non-initiated, that means no commercial value. This situation has been compounded too for the average farmer by the fact that there is certainly a downturn in the price of wool.

It is time that the Government acted to regain our reputation for clean products around the world. To date no-one has questioned whether the sheep carriers are not the point of infection, if any. It could be that they are. When our sheep land in Saudi Arabia our veterinarians have been testing them and not finding diseases. The sheep carriers-the boats themselves-could have been carrying infection because they are used in different parts of the world, notably Somalia and some ports out of South America. I am not saying that the diseases have come from there, but I know that in some of the cases before today the Saudis have sent shipments back to Somali because of disease.

Instead of some of our own organisations lying down, it is time to act and not listen to excuses, as this Government did when it listened to Vice-President Quayle when he was in Australia, about the wheat issue. It was all platitudes while he was here. Everything was sweet with the Government. Then when he went back we had another great sale of subsidised wheat to Russia, at the time. So it is time to act. It is time to have top level discussions to end the matter and to repair the damage that has been done. It is time that senior Ministers got involved instead of leaving it just to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation or whoever has been dealing with it. It is time that senior Ministers got into the act, including the Prime Minister. Action is needed not only to remove the question mark that has been put over the cleanliness of our sheep on world markets, or any market, but also so that farmers can plan ahead for long term stability.

A further concern is the report in yesterday's West Australian. I do not know whether it has been read over here but I will just read some part of it. The headline reads `Sheep dying in the Gulf'. It cites an official as saying that 5,000 quarantined sheep had died in Abu Dhabi in the past 10 days and that the rest were to be loaded up and returned to Australia. That is the biggest concern that worries me at present. I believe our quarantine laws would prevent their re-entry to Australia. I know live animals can be brought in after three months quarantine, but some action has to be taken now to make sure that those sheep do not come back to Australia and bring in the diseases that they have picked up over there. That has to be prevented at all costs.

So once again I call on the Government to get on with the negotiations. If the Saudis, others in the Gulf, or anyone else who have taken our sheep, do not want to trade with us, that is their business. I do not want to see that trade ended by our being put down in the eyes of the rest of the world. I would like to see it brought to a head so we can plan ahead for next year. Of course, we have to look at the fact that not only the farmers are suffering; this affects all the other industries down the line and the jobs that go with them.

Just before I came into the chamber I read in the latest telexes that another 100,000 sheep were rejected by Saudi Arabia today as the ship Al Shuwaik pulled into port there. Those 100,000 sheep were cleared by the Australian authorities when they left here, probably some 2 1/2 weeks ago. So the problem is getting more and more out of hand by the day. I make a final plea to the Government and its Ministers to do something about cleaning up the whole situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to refute a belief widely held by members of the public that the Parliament is full of hot air. I can assure them that it is not full of hot air; it is certainly full of cold air. I have been sitting here for the past almost an hour, with the wind blowing directly in from wherever it is coming. I assure them that it is far from hot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to reply to some of the remarks made by Senator Panizza because he has made a number of extraordinary observations. Since I have some knowledge of this matter, and since I am a Minister assisting the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), it behoves me to correct the impressions that Senator Panizza has left on the record, lest they remain unchallenged and thus be thought to be approved.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point that Senator Panizza has raised is that he cannot get details of a sale price for the sheep rejected by Saudi Arabia and bought by Kuwait. He put that to me in Question Time and I gave him an answer. It is true that we cannot get the information, and we cannot get the information for the reason that the transaction is commercial in confidence. I gave that reply at the time but said that, for the very sound reason Senator Panizza made in his concluding remarks, since it is not desirable to bring back to Australia those shipments once on the water, certainly once they have been in the Gulf, it is reasonable to assume that the price paid by Kuwaiti purchasers of the rejected sheep was less than the Saudis were prepared to pay in the first place. So it is entirely understand- able and very reasonable that we do not have access to the commercial in confidence information, but I think the general observation I make is soundly based.

The second question Senator Panizza raised is hypothetical. He said that maybe these sheep have found access to Saudi Arabia through the back door out of Kuwait. I do not know that that allegation has been made before. I certainly have not heard it from Senator Panizza and I do not know on what basis he assumes that to be the case, but I propose to investigate the allegation and reply. Senator Panizza observed that it would be a normal business arrangement, and that is true, and it would be a normal business arrangement beyond the control of this Government. It is one of the vicissitudes of commerce in the Gulf, I would suspect, but nonetheless, irrespective of the fact that it is an assertion made without supporting evidence, I will check it.

The third observation the honourable senator made is that the Government has done nothing. That observation is patently absurd. The first element of it is that he has said that we have sent a very low level Public Service mission to the Gulf. The head of the mission that has gone to the Gulf is Dr Gardner Murray, who is the Acting Director of the Bureau of Rural Resources. He is the Director of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and is a veterinarian of world standing and distinction. Among his peer group of international veterinarians he is regarded as a leader.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not the Minister, though.

—He is the senior and most appropriate person with the technical knowledge and experience to deal with allegations of disease and to deal with them directly. He is therefore the appropriate person to lead the delegation. That is an appropriate Government response.

SPEECH.PARA: I say, secondly, that Australia has suspended the trade with Saudi Arabia, and that is not a decision taken lightly. It is a decision taken on the basis that the trade had got to a fairly crazy situation in which sheep which were disease-free leaving Australia were diagnosed by Saudi veterinarians as diseased when they arrived there but that we do not have access to the results of the testing the Saudis have undertaken, and at this point we still are denied that access. In order not to prejudice further the trade and our reputation, it was suspended. That is not a decision taken lightly.

I say, thirdly, that Minister Duffy, Minister for Trade Negotiations, has been active, as has Minister Kerin, in communicating concern and disquiet to the Saudi Government at all levels and, indeed, the Minister for Commerce in Saudi Arabia announced publicly that he welcomed the letter from Minister Duffy setting out Australia's concerns. At this stage the matter is unresolved because the agriculture Minister from Saudi Arabia it appears is not available. Now, I accept absolutely that Senator Panizza has the best of motives. He is unhappy about what has happened. That is a genuine and reasonable motivation and I accept all of that. But to imply that he is more unhappy than we are about it, I think, is to get into a fairly silly situation. We are unhappy about it as a Government and we have taken the logical and most reasonable steps to resolve the matter.

What I think is somewhat to be deplored is the effort by some members of the Opposition to try to grandstand to their own constituencies by making calls for visits of Ministers or the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the Gulf, as if that would solve it. There is no evidence at this stage that any such visit would solve the matter. I put it to the honourable senators that simply persisting with those grandstanding calls is, in itself, not assisting the effort being made in Saudi Arabia by our various spokespeople. It suggests that they are not competent to deal with the matter. It undermines their standing in terms of their ability to deal with the Saudi Arabians. It also raises the thought in the minds of some in Saudi Arabia that they should wait until one of our senior Ministers visits, and not deal with the people who are there. I think all of those allegations undermine the effort. I implore the Opposition to join with the Government and support the actions we are taking, rather than stand off as carping critics and take a soft cop that is locally popular but internationally unhelpful in terms of the resolution of this matter.

The last observation that Senator Panizza made which I have noted is that Australia needs to act to protect our reputation for clean and disease-free products. I agree. I think the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service enjoys a reputation second to none in the world in terms of our ability to protect Australia from exotic diseases and from infection. We have a very strong place in the market because we have on the international market quality-recognised products and produce from our agricultural output. The reputation of the Quarantine and Inspection Service is without peer in terms of goods being cleared by it for export.

These sheep were cleared by qualified vets in Australia as being disease free when they left. From that point of view, rather than negatively call on the Government to do something that it already does very capably, I suggest that it would be better to make these points which are valid points to make in this debate. The sheep which were turned away by Saudi Arabia on the basis of an allegation of disease, the evidence for which was not available to our vets to assess on a scientific basis, were accepted in Kuwait on the basis that they were disease free; that is, after they left Saudi Arabia. I think that is a very strong point to make. Standards in Australia are internationally recognised as being very high. While it is always possible, since humans are involved, that there may be a mistake, the probability of a mistake of this magnitude is just mind-blowing. I do not think it can therefore be held, prima facie or on any other rational basis, that there is some error on our part.

I conclude by saying that this is a very difficult question. This is a question that does incur losses at a time when wool prices are not as strong as farmers would like. I think it is gratuitous of Senator Panizza to observe that there might be industrial relations disputes in slaughtering in the future. That is simply a gratuitous observation which I think is mischievous. Nonetheless, in getting a proper fix, it is quite right to observe those facts. The argument cannot stop there. If the honourable senator simply rests on the basis that he wants to make those points and express the displeasure he feels-relieve his spleen of the anger that he feels-that is fine, but that, in itself, is no recommendation for action to get results, to change the situation. Expressions of anger on a matter of great passion are understandable, but expressions of anger rarely, if ever, resolve tricky problems. Apart from the grandstanding calls that he would wish to make, the Australian Government has a very responsible presence in dealing with this matter which involves delicate balancings and complexities that, on the surface, sometimes people who talk in generalities do not wish to recognise. We are prepared to take whatever steps are necessary to open up the trade on a proper and responsible basis.

I would wish that this was a nationally unifying view. I call upon members of the coalition to support the Government in achieving that result. If they do so, the national viewpoint being put by Australia in the quite sensitive discussions that will follow will be at least unified and will have the most force at the most critical time and, therefore, will have the most success in achieving resolution of this matter.

Sheep dying in the Gulf
ABU DHABI: More than 5,000 quarantined Australian sheep had died in Abu Dhabi in the past 10 days, an official said yesterday.
Mohammad Ahmad, head of the municipal slaughterhouse, said between 400 and 500 sheep had died each day of Maltese fever from a shipment of about 15,700.
Abu Dhabi agreed to receive the sheep for testing 10 days ago after they were rejected by Saudi Arabia, which has refused shipments of nearly 208,000 Australian sheep since July.
But on August 30 Abu Dhabi turned back another consignment of Australian sheep on grounds that it was unfit for slaughter.

Saudi authorities had earlier maintained the animals were infected with the viral diseases blue tongue and sheep pox but Australian officials said such afflictions had been eliminated in Australian sheep.
Mr Ahmad said 5,300 sheep had died from Maltese fever and the rest were to be sent back to Australia.
